Ugh. Okay. This is…still hard to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like a big dramatic moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and suddenly decided. It was…a lot of thinking. And a lot of being scared.

I mean, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I just…wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything. A good life. A stable home. Parents who were actually prepared to be parents. I could give a baby love, sure. But I couldn't give it a future. Not the one it deserved.

My parents were amazing. They were supportive, but they were also…realistic. They knew I wasn't ready. And they didn't want me to ruin my life. Which, honestly, was a pretty good point.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…perfect. They were kind, and stable, and they just *wanted* a baby so badly. They weren't looking for a perfect kid, they were looking for *a* kid. And I knew, deep down, that they would be amazing parents.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. But it was the right one. For me, and for the baby. It wasn't about giving up something, it was about giving the baby the best possible chance.

It's complicated. It's messy. And it's not something I talk about a lot. But that's the truth of it. I wanted a good life for the baby, and I knew I couldn't give it to them. So I found people who could. And that's okay. It's more than okay. It's…right.



Don't ask me about it again for a while, okay? It's still a little raw.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all deep and reflective? Fine. It's not my favorite, but here we go.

Love and responsibility… those were, like, the two biggest surprises of the whole thing, honestly. Before all this happened, I thought love was just… whatever you see in movies. Dramatic declarations and grand gestures. Turns out, it's a lot more quiet than that.

I learned that love isn't always romantic. It's about caring for someone, even when it's hard. It's about wanting the best for them, even if it means letting them go. Like, with Paul and Mark. I started out just wanting to get rid of the baby, and then I ended up really caring about both of them. And realizing they were both good people, in their own ways. And that I wanted them to be happy, even if that happiness didn't include me.

And responsibility? Oh man. That was a whole other level. I thought I was responsible just for getting good grades and not getting grounded. But then I found out I was responsible for a whole *person*. A tiny human being who needed a good life. That was terrifying.

It wasn't just about carrying a baby for nine months. It was about making a really hard decision, and then sticking with it. It was about finding the right parents, and making sure they were going to give this kid a good home. It was about being selfless, even when I really wanted to just run away and pretend none of it was happening.

I learned that being responsible isn't about doing what's easy. It's about doing what's right, even when it's really, really hard. And it's about accepting the consequences of your actions.

And, honestly, I learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go. Let go of your own expectations, let go of your own desires, and let go of control. Because sometimes, things work out better when you just let them happen.

It was a mess, okay? But it was a good mess. And it taught me a lot about myself, and about what really matters in life. And yeah, about love and responsibility too. It's still kinda weird to think about, but… I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. But don't expect a heartwarming Hallmark movie moment, alright?

Honestly, my sarcasm was a survival mechanism. Like, a shield. When everything was falling apart – finding out I was pregnant, dealing with my dad, trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my life – it was easier to make a joke than to actually *feel* anything.

It was a way to distance myself from the mess. If I could make someone laugh, even if it was just a nervous chuckle, it meant I could control the situation, even for a second. It meant I wasn't completely falling apart.

And it helped me deal with people. Like, when people were being all awkward and pitying, or trying to give me unsolicited advice, a well-timed sarcastic comment could shut them down without me having to actually have a serious conversation. Which, let's be real, I wasn't always up for.

It wasn't about being mean, exactly. It was about being…honest. And about not taking myself too seriously. Because if I started taking everything seriously, I would have just completely crumbled.

Paulie was good at that too, you know? He could always make me laugh, even when I wanted to just curl up in a ball and disappear. He got my sense of humor, and he didn't try to fix me. He just let me be me, even when "me" was a sarcastic, pregnant teenager.

So yeah, my wit wasn't just a personality quirk. It was a coping mechanism. It was a way to stay sane when everything felt completely insane. It was a way to protect myself. And it was a way to connect with people who actually *got* me.

It's still how I deal with things, honestly. Sometimes, the best way to face a difficult situation is to just laugh at it. Or at least, make a snarky comment about it. It doesn't solve anything, but it makes it a little bit easier to bear.

Ugh, okay, deep questions. It's weird talking about myself, even though I'm kinda used to it now. But yeah, vulnerability and figuring out who I was…that was, like, the whole thing, wasn't it?

Before everything with Paul happened, I was pretty good at being…tough. Sarcastic. Distant. A shield, basically. It was easier than letting people see the messy, confused stuff underneath. I thought if I acted cool and detached, nobody would notice I was kinda lost.

But getting pregnant…that ripped the shield right off. Suddenly, I couldn't pretend anymore. I was scared, and confused, and totally unprepared. And I had to actually *talk* to people about it. My dad, my best friend Leah, even Paul. It was terrifying.

Being vulnerable meant admitting I didn't have all the answers. It meant letting people see me cry, and freak out, and make bad decisions. It meant relying on other people, which is something I'd always avoided.

And that's where the identity search really kicked in. I'd always just been…Juno. The sarcastic girl who liked records and avoided drama. But suddenly, I had to figure out who I was *as a person*. What did I want out of life? What kind of future did I want? Was I ready to be a mom?

Choosing adoption wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about figuring out what was best for *everyone* involved. And that meant being honest with myself about what I could handle, and what I couldn't.

It was messy, and it was hard, and there were a lot of tears. But it also forced me to grow up. To face my fears. To figure out what really mattered to me.

I still don't have all the answers, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm a lot less afraid to be myself now. And I'm a lot more comfortable with being vulnerable. Because sometimes, that's the only way to really connect with people, and to find out who you really are.

It wasn't a straight line, and it wasn't pretty. But it was my journey. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the awkward conversations with Mark and Vanessa. Okay, maybe I'd trade *some* of those. But not all of them.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about that. Like, the whole pregnancy thing was…a lot. And I definitely didn't get through it alone, even though I *tried* to act like I did.

Honestly, at first, I was just trying to figure out how to not completely fall apart. And my dad, Paul, he was…surprisingly cool about it. He didn't freak out or anything. He just started building a crib. Which was weird, but also kinda sweet. He was always good at the practical stuff. He didn't try to tell me what to do, he just…supported me. And that meant a lot.

Then there was Leah. She's my best friend, and she was…well, she was Leah. She was brutally honest, but also incredibly loyal. She didn't sugarcoat anything, but she always had my back. She helped me navigate the whole awkwardness of telling people, and she was the one who came with me to all the doctor's appointments. She was the voice of reason when I was being a total mess.

And then there was Mark. He was…complicated. But he stepped up. He didn't run away, and he actually seemed to *want* to be involved. He wasn't perfect, but he was trying. And that made a difference.

But honestly, the biggest support came from Annie and her husband, Vanessa. They were the ones who were actually going to *raise* the baby. And they were so open and accepting and…normal. They didn't judge me, they just offered me a safe space to figure things out. They helped me realize that giving the baby up wasn't a failure, it was a selfless act.

It wasn't about them telling me what to do, it was about them listening. About them letting me come to my own conclusions. About them reminding me that I was strong enough to make a difficult decision.

I think…I think I would have completely crumbled without them. They didn't fix things for me, they just helped me find the strength to fix them myself. And that's what real support is, you know? It's not about having all the answers, it's about being there for someone when they're trying to find their own.

It made me realize that even when things are totally messed up, you don't have to go through it alone. And that's a pretty good lesson to learn, I think.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie moment, you know? It wasn't like, a joyful revelation or anything. It was more like…a really, really bad surprise quiz I hadn't studied for.

Honestly? I was mostly just…freaked out. Like, full-on, panic attack freaked out. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and band practice, not…this.

I think the first thing I felt was disbelief. Like, the test was wrong. Or maybe I was dreaming. But then it sunk in, and it was just…overwhelming. I was scared. I was confused. I was angry. Mostly at myself, I guess.

I didn't tell anyone for a long time. I just kind of…shut down. I kept going to school, hanging out with my friends, pretending everything was normal. But inside, I was a total mess.

It wasn't until I started talking to Paul that things started to feel a little bit less terrifying. He was…surprisingly cool about it. And then meeting Vanessa and Mark, the couple who wanted to adopt…that helped too.

But yeah. Finding out I was pregnant? It was not a good day. It was probably one of the worst days of my life. But, you know, things turned out okay. Eventually. It was just…a lot to process. And a lot of awkward conversations.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It was messy, honestly. It wasn't like a movie where everyone instantly rallied around me with supportive hugs and wise words. It was…complicated.

With my dad, it was…awkward. He tried, he really did. He kept offering me advice about, like, prenatal vitamins and stuff, which was sweet, but also totally missed the point. He just didn't *get* it. He wanted me to be this perfect little daughter, and suddenly I was…not. It took a while for him to come around, to realize I wasn't just being reckless, I was just…trying to figure things out.

My mom was…better. She was always good at just *being there*, even when she didn't know what to say. She didn't judge me, which I really needed. She just listened. And she helped me with, like, the practical stuff – doctor's appointments and stuff. But even with her, it was different. There was this…distance. Like she was trying to protect me from something.

And my friends…that was the hardest part. Leah was…Leah. She was supportive, but also kinda freaked out. She didn't know how to act around me anymore. It was like I'd suddenly become a different person. And Paulie…Paulie was just…Paulie. He tried to be cool, but you could tell he was uncomfortable.

It felt like everyone was walking on eggshells around me. Like I was this fragile thing that was gonna break if you looked at me wrong. It was isolating.

But, eventually, things got better. Leah and I talked, really talked, and she realized I was still the same person, just…with a baby on the way. And Paulie…well, Paulie came around too. He even helped me pick out a name.

It changed my relationships, for sure. Some got stronger, some got weaker. But it also taught me a lot about who my real friends were. And it taught me that even when things are messy and complicated, people can still surprise you.

It wasn't easy, but it was…worth it. In the end, I had the people I needed, and that's all that really mattered.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly? It wasn't pretty. It was messy and confusing and terrifying, most of the time. There wasn't like, a handbook for this stuff, you know?

First of all, I pretended it wasn't happening for a while. Denial is a powerful thing. I just kept going to school and hanging out with Leah and Paul and trying to act normal. Which, obviously, didn't work.

Then came the freak-outs. Lots of crying. Lots of questioning everything. Like, my entire life plan was suddenly…different. And not in a good way, at least not at first.

Paul was…surprisingly awesome. He didn't run away, which I appreciated. He was just…there. And he listened. Even when I was being a total mess.

But the biggest help was probably my dad. He was quiet about it at first, but he started taking me to appointments and just…being a dad. He didn't judge me, and he didn't try to fix things. He just supported me. Which is all I really needed.

And then there was Vanessa. She was…intense. But she was also really good at cutting through the BS and telling me what I needed to hear. Even if it wasn't what I wanted to hear.

Honestly, a lot of it was just taking things one day at a time. Trying not to think too far ahead. And finding little things to make me happy. Like listening to The Moldy Peaches or eating tater tots.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself. And about what really matters.

It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers. Just…find people who support you. And try to be kind to yourself. Because you're gonna need it.



It's still…a lot to process, even now. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about this? It was, like, a really hard decision, okay? And it wasn't just about picking a place. It was about…everything.

Havenbrooke was closer, yeah. And my dad was kinda pushing for it, 'cause it was more convenient. But Women Now…it just *felt* right.

It wasn't about the protesters, though that was definitely a factor. I mean, I didn't want to deal with a bunch of people yelling at me, judging me. But it was more than that.

Havenbrooke felt…clinical. Cold. Like a factory. Women Now felt…safer. More supportive. They actually talked to me, you know? They didn't just treat me like a number. They asked me how *I* was feeling. They explained everything. They didn't try to guilt-trip me or tell me what I should do.

And Paul, he said it felt…less judgmental. Like, Havenbrooke was all about keeping things quiet and discreet, which is fine, I guess. But Women Now was about empowering women and giving them choices.

It was a really personal decision, okay? And I needed to feel comfortable and safe. And Women Now just…felt like the right place for me. It wasn't easy, but it was the best choice I could make.

Can we maybe talk about something else now? It's kinda bringing back a lot of stuff.

(Sighs, rolls eyes) Okay, seriously? That's…a really personal question. And honestly, it's not something I talk about a lot. It was complicated, okay?

It wasn't like some grand romantic gesture or anything. It wasn't even, like, a super planned thing. It just…happened. We were both kinda feeling it, and we were both kinda scared, and it just…escalated.

I was a mess at the time. I was dealing with the pregnancy, and everything that came with it, and I was just…lonely. And Bleeker was…Bleeker. He was sweet and kind and didn't judge me. He was a safe space, I guess.

It wasn't about love, or even really about lust. It was about connection. About feeling wanted and needed. About feeling…normal, for a little while.

I know it wasn't the smartest decision. I know it probably complicated things even more. But I was young and confused and making a lot of bad decisions. And I don't regret it, exactly. It was a mistake, yeah, but it was *my* mistake.

And honestly, it's not something I really want to dissect right now. It was a year ago. I've moved on. I'm focusing on the baby and finding a good family for him. That's what matters now.

So, can we maybe talk about something else? Like, I don't know, the merits of different types of pizza? Or the awesomeness of The Moldy Peaches? Anything but this, please.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're going *there*? Fine. Look, Bleeker… he's a lot. A lot of quiet. A lot of guitar. A lot of… earnestness. It's almost overwhelming sometimes.

At first, he was just…there. Like a really nice, slightly awkward piece of furniture. He was always around, always supportive, always offering to help with stuff. Which was good, I guess. Especially when everything was, you know, happening.

And he was funny, in a dorky, self-deprecating way. He could always make me laugh, even when I didn't want to. Which was a lot, honestly.

But it wasn't… fireworks. It wasn't this huge, dramatic thing. It was more like… a comfortable sweater. Warm and familiar. And maybe a little bit boring.

I think I liked that he didn't judge me. He didn't care about the baby or the whole situation. He just… accepted me. Which was a big deal.

But did I *love* him? That's… complicated. I think I loved the idea of him. The idea of having someone who was always there, who was always kind, who was always… safe.

But I also knew I needed to figure things out on my own. I needed to find my own identity, my own path. And I wasn't sure Bleeker fit into that.

So, yeah. It was… bittersweet. He's a good guy. A really good guy. And I'll always care about him. But sometimes, good isn't enough. Sometimes, you need something more. Or maybe, sometimes, you just need to figure things out on your own.

Don't tell him I said that. He'd probably write a song about it. And it would be really sad.

Ugh, okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. But you asked.

It wasn't an easy decision, okay? Not at all. It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and was all, "Yeah, adoption sounds good!" It was a lot of thinking, and a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to people.

The thing is, I'm…not ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a kid. I mean, I can barely keep my grades up and remember to feed my fish. A baby deserves someone who's totally ready, someone who can give it everything it needs.

And Mark and Vanessa…they *are* ready. They're amazing people. They've been trying for a baby for a long time, and they're so excited. They can give the baby a good life, a stable home, and a lot of love. More than I can right now.

It's not that I don't love the baby. I do. A lot. But loving someone isn't always enough. Sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let them go.

It's not about giving up. It's about making the best decision for the baby. And for me, too, I guess. I need to finish school, figure out what I want to do with my life, and become a person who can actually take care of someone.

It's complicated. It's messy. And it's definitely not what I expected. But I think…I think it's the right thing to do.

Don't look at me like that. It's okay. I'm okay. Mostly. It just…takes time.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It was the worst. Like, I’d been bracing myself for telling my parents, for dealing with everything that was coming, but telling Bleeker…that was different.

He’s Bleeker. He’s sweet, and kinda clueless, and he’s my friend. And I just…I didn’t want to ruin things. I didn’t want him to feel obligated or weird or…anything.

So I was trying to be all casual about it, you know? Like, “Oh, hey, by the way, I’m pregnant.” Which, in retrospect, was a terrible strategy. It just came out sounding really flat and awkward.

And his face. Oh god, his face. It was like someone had just told him the world was ending. He just…froze. And then he started stammering, and I could see the gears turning in his head, trying to process it.

It wasn’t that he was mad or anything. He was just…completely overwhelmed. And that made me feel even worse. Because I was already overwhelmed, and now I was making *him* overwhelmed too.

I think I mostly felt…sad. Sad that things were so complicated. Sad that he wasn’t going to be the dad. Sad that our friendship was probably going to change.

And then, after a while, he was actually really sweet about it. He was supportive, and he said he’d be there for me. But it was still…weird. It was just really, really weird.

It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize that this wasn’t just about me anymore. It was about Bleeker too, and Paul, and the baby. And it was going to be a long, complicated road.

But hey, at least I got it off my chest. And Bleeker, being Bleeker, eventually made me laugh about it. Sort of. It still stings a little, though.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly? It still feels kinda surreal. Like, one minute I'm just a normal, sarcastic teenager obsessed with music and avoiding gym class, and the next I'm, you know, *pregnant*.

It's scary, obviously. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being. I still need my mom to help me with laundry sometimes! And I definitely don't have a five-year plan, let alone an eighteen-year plan.

But it's not all bad. I mean, I'm giving this baby a good life. A better life than I had, maybe. And I'm choosing the parents, which is… empowering, I guess. They seem really great. Really stable. And they want this kid.

It's just…weird. I'm gonna miss out on a lot. College, traveling, just being a normal teenager. But I also think it's gonna force me to grow up. To be responsible. To figure out who I am and what I want out of life.

I'm not gonna lie, I'm terrified. But I'm also…excited? In a weird, complicated way. It's like, this is a huge responsibility, but it's also a chance to do something amazing.

I'm not gonna be a mom in the traditional sense. I'm not gonna be baking cookies and going to PTA meetings. But I'm gonna be a part of this kid's life. And I'm gonna do everything I can to make sure they're happy and healthy.

It's just…a lot to process. And I'm still trying to figure it all out. But I think, deep down, I'm okay with it. Maybe even… hopeful.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my tough-girl reputation.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. And a scary one. Honestly, I haven't really *thought* about it that much, because I've been mostly trying not to freak out about the whole baby thing. But now that you mention it…

It's gonna be weird, right? Before, it was just…us. Two awkward teenagers who liked the same music and could tolerate each other's weirdness. We hung out, we talked, we…you know. It was simple.

Now? Now there's a whole other person involved. A tiny human who's gonna need diapers and stuff. And Bleeker…he's still Bleeker. Sweet, a little clueless, and really good at guitar. He's trying to be supportive, which is nice, but he also keeps offering to build the baby a drum set, which is…concerning.

I think it's gonna force us to grow up, both of us. We're not kids anymore, even though we still feel like it sometimes. We're gonna have to learn how to be responsible, how to communicate, how to actually *plan* for the future. Which is not exactly our strong suit.

I'm worried we'll drift apart. He's got his music, and I'm…well, I'm gonna be dealing with morning sickness and doctor's appointments and all that jazz. It's gonna be hard to find time for each other.

But I also think it could bring us closer. If we can actually navigate this whole thing together, if we can be a team, then maybe…maybe we can make it work. Maybe we can be good parents.

I just…I don't want him to feel like he has to give up his dreams. And I don't want to feel like my life is over. It's a lot to figure out.

I guess we'll just have to see what happens. It's gonna be messy, and probably really awkward, but hopefully, we can figure it out. And maybe, just maybe, we can still be us, even with a baby in the mix.

Ugh. This is stressful. I need a popsicle.

Ugh. Okay, that was…a lot. Seriously. It felt like everyone suddenly had an opinion about my life, and none of them were asking for one. It was like being under a microscope, and everyone was pointing and whispering.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to ignore it. Which is easier said than done, obviously. But I figured if I acknowledged every single side-eye or snide comment, I'd just fall apart. So I perfected the art of the withering glare and the sarcastic comeback. That usually kept people at bay.

But it wasn't just the classmates. It was family, too. My mom was…supportive, in her own way. But she also had a lot of questions and a lot of worries. And my dad…well, he just kind of retreated into his man cave.

What really helped was Paul. And Bren. They didn't judge me. They just…listened. And they helped me figure things out. They reminded me that I wasn't alone, and that I could get through this.

I also found a weird kind of strength in being different. Everyone else was worried about prom and college applications, and I was worried about, you know, *growing a human*. It put things in perspective. It made me realize that their problems weren't so big, and mine weren't so insurmountable.

And honestly? A little bit of defiance helped. I wasn't going to let their judgment define me. I was going to do what was right for me and the baby, and I didn't care what anyone else thought.

It still sucked, though. It really did. But I learned that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And I decided to react with a healthy dose of sarcasm and a whole lot of determination.

It wasn't easy. But I got through it. And you know what? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the judgment. Because it made me who I am today. A little bit tougher, a little bit wiser, and a whole lot more independent.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even with Paul and Vanessa. It's complicated.

Honestly? It's terrifying. Like, permanently terrifying. Giving a baby away…it sounds awful when you say it like that. It *is* awful. But it's also…the right thing. For everyone.

I wasn't ready. I'm not ready. I'm sixteen! I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I can barely keep my own life together, let alone raise a kid. And that baby deserves parents who are, like, actually prepared. Parents who have a house and a stable income and know what they're doing.

Mark and Vanessa…they're amazing. They're so excited. They've been trying for so long. And they're going to give that baby a life I just can't provide. A good life. A safe life.

It doesn't make it easy, though. There are days when I just…cry. And I worry. I worry about whether I'm doing the right thing. I worry about whether the baby will be happy. I worry about whether I'll ever get over it.

But then I remember that this isn't about me. It's about the baby. And I want what's best for the baby. Even if it means letting go.

It's not like I'm just…forgetting about it. I'm going to stay in touch with Mark and Vanessa. I want to be a part of the baby's life, in whatever way they're comfortable with.

It's a weird feeling, knowing that there's a little person growing inside me who's going to be loved by someone else. It's bittersweet. It's heartbreaking. It's…everything.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, it's not a happy choice. It's a hard choice. But it's a responsible choice. And I'm trying to be responsible. Even if it kills me a little bit inside.

So yeah. That's how I feel. It's messy. And it's real. And it's probably going to be a long time before I fully process it. But I'm doing the best I can.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not like something you just breeze past, you know? It's still kinda weird to even *think* about, honestly.

Before all this, I was just…Juno. A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid who liked records and didn't really think about the future much. I was just coasting, figuring things out as I went. I had a plan, kinda. Go to college, maybe be a writer, definitely not be a mom.

Then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, everything changed.

It wasn't just the physical stuff, though that was…a lot. It was like, suddenly everyone had an opinion on who I was supposed to be. A mother. Responsible. Mature. And I was just…not those things. Not yet, anyway.

I had to confront the fact that I wasn't a kid anymore. I couldn't just ignore things and hope they'd go away. I had a responsibility, a real one, and it wasn't just to myself. It was to this little person growing inside me.

It forced me to think about what I actually *wanted* out of life. Before, I hadn't really questioned it. I just assumed I'd figure it out eventually. But now, I had to make a decision that would affect the rest of my life, and the life of another person.

It was terrifying.

And it made me realize I didn't really *know* myself very well. I thought I was so independent and self-assured, but I was just hiding behind sarcasm and a carefully curated cool exterior.

Giving the baby up for adoption was the hardest thing I've ever done. It meant admitting that I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that was…humiliating. But it also meant choosing what was best for the baby, and that's what mattered.

I think it made me realize that growing up isn't about becoming someone else. It's about figuring out who you are, and being brave enough to live with it. It's about taking responsibility for your choices, even the messy ones.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm…more. More aware, more responsible, more…grown up. And honestly? It's kinda scary. But it's also kinda good.

It's just…a lot.

Ugh, okay, so being a lab partner? It's...a situation. Honestly, it depends on who I'm stuck with. If it's Paulie Bleeker, it's actually kinda fun. He's quiet, but he doesn't ask a million questions and he doesn't freak out if something explodes. Which, let's be real, is a plus.

But most of the time, I'm the one doing all the work. Like, seriously. I get paired with these people who are either completely clueless or think they're, like, the next Einstein. And they just stand there and *observe* while I'm actually, you know, *doing* the experiment.

I'm usually the one who reads the instructions, sets up the equipment, and makes sure we don't accidentally create a biohazard. I'm pretty good at science, okay? It's not my favorite, but I can handle it.

I'm not afraid to get my hands dirty, which is more than I can say for some of these people. And I'm not afraid to point out when someone's doing something wrong. Which sometimes gets me glares, but whatever. Safety first.

So, I guess you could say I'm the responsible one. The one who keeps things from going horribly wrong. I'm basically the science babysitter. It's not glamorous, but someone's gotta do it.

And honestly, I'm just hoping we get a good grade. That's all I really care about.

Ugh. Seriously? That ad? It's…a lot. It's all pink and flowery and talks about "empowering women" and "making informed choices," but it feels…icky. Like, super manipulative.

It's not that I'm against people making choices, okay? That's kinda the whole point of my situation. But it feels like they're trying to dress it up all pretty and pretend it's just…a medical procedure. Like it doesn't have, you know, *feelings* attached.

And the whole "Women's Choice" thing? It feels like they're trying to guilt-trip you into thinking it's the only empowering thing to do. Like, if you don't choose *their* option, you're somehow not a strong, independent woman. Which is total BS.

It just makes me feel…weird. Like they're trying to sell you something, and it's not just a medical service. It's an idea. And it's a really complicated idea.

I mean, I get it. They're a business. They need to advertise. But it just feels…wrong. It feels like they're preying on people who are already in a tough spot.

It's just…ugh. It makes me want to roll my eyes and listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. It's just…a lot to process, you know?

Ugh, seriously? You're still hung up on the hamburger phone? It's a long story. And honestly, it was mostly just to mess with Paul. He was being all serious and "responsible adult" about everything, and I needed to remind him that life is ridiculous.

It wasn't like I *planned* it. I was at that vintage store with Bleeker, and it was just…there. A bright pink hamburger that was also a phone. It was too perfect. It screamed "I'm a teenager who's trying to figure things out and also has a questionable sense of humor."

Plus, it was a good conversation starter. People definitely noticed. And it made me feel a little bit less…invisible, I guess. Like, I was making a statement. A very silly statement, but a statement nonetheless.

Paul was mortified, obviously. He kept trying to steer the conversation back to, like, prenatal vitamins and adoption agencies. But I just kept talking into the hamburger. It was worth it.

It was a small act of rebellion, I guess. A way to reclaim a little bit of control in a situation where I felt like I had very little. And it was funny. Okay? It was just funny.

Don't judge me. It was a stressful time. And sometimes, you just need to talk into a hamburger.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? It wasn't like, a super easy decision. People always assume it was, but it wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I just…couldn't give that to it. Not then. Not ever, probably.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents…well, they were supportive, but it wasn't exactly a stable situation.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. I wanted it to have parents who were ready, who had a house and a plan and a future. Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were so excited, and they had everything the baby needed.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. Seriously. It felt like ripping a piece of myself away. But I knew it was the right thing. It was the selfless thing. And sometimes, you gotta do the selfless thing, even when it sucks.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a plan. It was about wanting the best for someone else, even if it meant sacrificing my own happiness.

And honestly? It made me grow up. It made me realize what's important in life. It wasn't about having everything I wanted. It was about doing what was right.

So yeah. That's why. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. I hope. I really hope.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It's not like it was a simple thing, you know? It wasn't just about me and the baby. It was about *everything*. And my family was a huge part of that everything.

My dad, Paul, he was…supportive. In his own way. He's a sweet guy, but he's kinda clueless sometimes. He wanted me to keep it, I think, just because he wanted me to be happy. But he also knew I wasn't exactly ready for this. He saw how freaked out I was. He just wanted me to finish high school and, like, have a life.

My stepmom, Bren, she was the one who really got it. She had been through stuff, you know? She understood what it was like to be a teenager with a lot on your plate. She didn't push me either way, but she asked all the right questions. She made me think about what was best for the baby, not just what I wanted.

And then there's my mom. She…wasn't around much when I was growing up. She's kinda flaky. She showed up for a little while after I told her I was pregnant, and she was all, "Oh, honey, we can raise it together!" But I knew that wasn't realistic. She's not exactly the most stable person. I didn't want my baby to grow up with a mom who disappeared all the time.

Seeing my family, and how…complicated things were, made me realize I didn't want to repeat those patterns. I wanted my baby to have a stable, loving home with parents who were actually *ready* to be parents.

It wasn't about me not loving the baby. It was about loving the baby enough to give it the best possible life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give it that right now.

My family helped me see that. They didn't judge me, they didn't try to control me. They just…supported me in making the best decision for everyone involved. And that meant giving the baby up for adoption. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was the right thing. And I wouldn't have gotten through it without them. Even my mom, in a weird way, helped me realize what I *didn't* want.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just neatly falls into place. There were…complications. A lot of them.

The biggest thing, honestly, was just the *feelings*. It was weird, giving up something that was already, like, *inside* me. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it easy. There were days I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. And I did, a lot.

Then there was the paperwork. Oh. My. God. The paperwork. It was endless. Forms and meetings and background checks and legal stuff. It was so boring and stressful. It felt like everyone was trying to decide if I was a good enough person to give my baby up, which, like, rude.

And then there were the people. The social workers were nice enough, but they were also asking a lot of really personal questions. And the potential adoptive parents… that was weird. Meeting them, talking to them, trying to figure out if they were the right people. It was like a job interview, but way more emotional.

Mark and Vanessa, they were great, eventually. But at first, it was just…awkward. Trying to imagine them raising my kid. It was hard.

And then there was Paul. He was…supportive, in his own way. But he didn't really *get* it. He didn't understand how hard it was. He just wanted me to be happy, which was sweet, but also kind of frustrating.

The hardest part, though, was just knowing that I was making a really big decision. A life-changing decision. And there was no guarantee that it was the right one. It was scary. Really scary.

But I did it. And I don't regret it. But it wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and emotionally draining. And it definitely wasn't what I expected. It was just…real.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I usually just *talk* about, you know? It's still…stuff. But you asked, so here goes.

It completely messed me up, honestly. Before Paul, before everything, I was just…Juno. Kinda sarcastic, kinda detached, liked records and making fun of people. I didn't really think about the future, or who I was supposed to be. I just existed.

Getting pregnant…it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It wasn't just about my body changing, it was about realizing I was responsible for another human being. And that was terrifying. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't even sure I was ready to be an adult.

Giving up Leo…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It felt like ripping a piece of myself away. There were days I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But I knew it was the right thing to do. For him. For Mark and Vanessa. They were going to give him a life I couldn't.

It made me realize I wasn't as tough as I thought I was. I let myself feel things, really feel them. And that was scary, but it was also…liberating. I started to understand what mattered. It wasn't about being cool or fitting in. It was about being honest with myself and with others.

It also made me figure out what I wanted. Before, I just drifted. After Leo, I started thinking about college, about my future. I wanted to be a writer, to tell stories. And I realized I could do that, even if my life didn't go according to plan.

It changed my relationship with my dad, too. We always had a good relationship, but it got deeper. He was there for me, without judgment. He just listened.

I guess…it made me realize I was stronger than I thought. And that even when things are really hard, you can get through them. It didn't magically make me a perfect person, obviously. I still say dumb stuff and make bad decisions. But I'm more aware of who I am, and what I want.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But it made me…me. And I think, ultimately, that's a good thing. It's weird, right? Something so awful could also be…good. But it is. It just is.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on that guy. Seriously. It was…the worst.

It wasn't the yelling, okay? I'm used to people yelling. It was the…the *details*. Like, suddenly he's talking about tiny fingers and feeling pain. It wasn't about the principle of it anymore, it was about…making it *real*. And it was supposed to make me feel guilty, I guess.

And it almost did.

I mean, I knew it was a baby. I wasn't stupid. But it wasn't a *person* yet, you know? Not in the way he was making it sound. It was…potential. And I was trying so hard to be logical about it, to do what was best for everyone.

But then he said that stuff about the fingers, and it just…broke something inside me. It made it so much harder to think straight. It made me feel like I was doing something terrible.

I just wanted him to go away. I wanted him to stop talking. I wanted to disappear.

Paul was really good in that moment, though. He just stood there, like a human shield. And then he told the guy to back off. It was…nice.

It was just…a really awful moment. And it stuck with me for a long time. It made me question everything. But I still knew, deep down, that I was doing the right thing. Even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

Ugh. I don't even want to think about it anymore. Can we talk about something else? Like, tater tots?

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a lot. It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic and teary-eyed. It was mostly just…awkward. And cold. The room was really cold.

I think the biggest thing I felt was just…numb. Like, I’d already made the decision, right? I knew what I was doing. But actually *sitting* there, filling out all those forms…it made it real. Like, this wasn’t some abstract thing anymore. This was happening.

There was a lot of clinical language. A lot of boxes to check. “Medical history.” “Family history.” “Reason for termination.” It felt so…reducing. Like I was just a case file. And I wasn’t. I was a person. With feelings. And a life. And a baby.

I remember feeling really self-conscious. Like everyone was judging me. Even though the people working there were really nice, I just felt…exposed. Like I was doing something wrong. Which I knew I wasn’t. But it still felt wrong.

There was a weird mix of relief and sadness. Relief that I was taking control of the situation. Sadness that it had to come to this. I kept thinking about the baby, and what it would be like. And then I’d remind myself that I wasn’t ready. That I couldn’t give it the life it deserved.

Mostly, though, I just wanted to get it over with. I wanted to fill out the forms, sign the papers, and get out of there. I wanted to go home and pretend it hadn’t happened. But you can’t really pretend something like that hasn’t happened, can you?

It was just…a really heavy feeling. Like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. And I was sixteen. Sixteen! It was a lot for anyone to handle.

So yeah. Awkward. Numb. Self-conscious. Sad. Relieved. Heavy. That pretty much sums it up. It wasn’t a good time. Not a good time at all.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like I went in thinking, "Oh, this is gonna be a super fun adventure!" It was more like, "Oh. My. God. This is happening." And my perception of everything just…shifted. A lot.

At first, it was just…scary. And inconvenient. Like, seriously? Right now? I was just trying to figure out what college to apply to, not, you know, grow a human. It felt like my life was totally derailed. I thought of it as this huge, messy problem I had to solve. Like a really complicated math equation.

And motherhood? Forget about it. That felt like something for…other people. Grown-ups. People who had their lives together. Definitely not me. I pictured it as this suffocating, boring existence where you just changed diapers and smelled like spit-up all the time.

But then…things started to change. As I started feeling the baby move, it wasn't just a "problem" anymore. It was…something real. Something *alive*. And I started thinking about what kind of life I wanted for it. And that made me think about what kind of person *I* wanted to be.

Talking to Vanessa and Mark, seeing how much they wanted a kid, and how much they loved the idea of being parents…it made me realize that motherhood wasn't just about giving up your life. It was about *changing* your life. And maybe, just maybe, it could be a good change.

I still wasn't planning on raising the baby myself, but I started to feel this weird sense of responsibility. And a little bit of…love. It was scary, but it was also…kind of amazing.

By the end, I realized that pregnancy wasn't just about the physical changes. It was about growing up. It was about facing a really big decision and figuring out what was right for me, and for the baby. And motherhood…well, motherhood wasn't just about diapers and spit-up. It was about unconditional love and sacrifice and giving someone the best possible start in life.

I still don't think I'm ready to be a mom right now. But I'm okay with that. I know I made the right decision, and I know the baby is going to have amazing parents. And that's all that really matters.

It was a really weird, messy, complicated journey. But it definitely changed me. For the better, I think. Even if I still don't know what I want to do with my life.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all introspective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but I guess it's a fair question. My sense of identity…it was a mess, honestly, throughout the whole movie.

At the beginning, I was just trying to be…normal. You know? A sarcastic, movie-obsessed teenager who avoids drama. I had my routines, my music, my way of dealing with things. I thought I knew who I was. And then…bam. Pregnant.

That threw everything into chaos. Suddenly, I wasn't just Juno anymore. I was "Juno, the pregnant girl." And everyone had an opinion on what that meant. It was like, my whole identity was defined by this one thing.

For a while, I tried to just power through it, be funny, be detached. It was a defense mechanism, you know? But it didn't really work. I was still scared and confused.

Then, meeting Paulie Bleeker…and getting to know Mark and Vanessa…that started to change things. They weren't what I expected. They were…real. And they made me think about what I actually *wanted*, not just what I thought I *should* want.

I started to realize that being a mom wasn't necessarily my destiny. And that was okay. It was a hard realization, because everyone kept telling me how amazing it was going to be. But it wasn't *my* amazing.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't just "Juno, the pregnant girl" anymore. I was Juno, who had made a really difficult decision, and who was starting to figure out who she was *outside* of that. I was still sarcastic and movie-obsessed, but I was also a little bit more…grown up. A little bit more sure of myself.

It wasn't a perfect ending, you know? It was messy and complicated. But it was *my* ending. And that's what mattered.

I guess my identity evolved from being someone who was trying to avoid responsibility to someone who was taking responsibility for her own life, and making choices that were right for *her*. It was a long process, and I'm still figuring things out, but that's okay. That's just life, right?

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're going *there*? Fine. It's not like I haven't replayed that day in my head a million times.

It wasn't, like, a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I walked in and was all, "Nope! Changed my mind!" It was…complicated.

I thought I was ready. I really did. I'd made the decision, I'd picked the couple, I'd even started picturing my life *after*. But then…I got in there, and it just felt…wrong.

It wasn't the people at the clinic. They were nice. Really nice. It was just…looking at the room, and thinking about what was actually going to happen…it hit me. It wasn't about the baby anymore. It was about *me*.

I realized I wasn't as okay with it as I thought I was. I hadn't really dealt with the fact that I was carrying a person, a whole little human being. And suddenly, handing that over to someone else…it felt like giving away a piece of myself.

It wasn't about changing my mind about wanting the baby to have a good life. It was about realizing I needed to figure out *my* life first. I needed to figure out who I was, and what I wanted, before I could make such a huge decision.

So I just…left. I told them I needed more time. Which wasn't a total lie. I needed a lot more time.

It was scary. Really scary. But it was the right thing to do. For me. And for the baby. I needed to be sure. And I wasn't. Not then.



It's still…a sensitive subject. But yeah. That's why. It wasn't about being indecisive. It was about being honest with myself. And that's something I'm still working on.

Ugh, okay, this is…still a tough one to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like I *wanted* to, you know? It wasn't like I didn't care about the baby. It was just…real life.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was a kid myself. And my parents…they were great, but they were already kinda checked out. They weren't exactly equipped to help me with this.

And Mark, the baby's dad…well, he was Mark. Sweet, but totally clueless. He was going to college and had his own life to figure out. We both knew he wasn't ready to be a dad.

I thought about everything. About dropping out of school, about getting a job, about trying to be a mom. And it just…didn't feel right. I didn't want to bring a kid into a situation where they wouldn't be wanted or cared for properly. I wanted that baby to have a good life, a stable life, a life where they could have everything they needed.

Vanessa and Mark's parents…they were amazing. They were older, they were financially secure, and they were genuinely excited about the idea of raising a child. They were everything I wasn't.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. It was about being selfless, even though it was the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

It was a really complicated decision. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. It was the most responsible thing I could do. And I wanted that baby to have a life filled with love and opportunity. And I knew I couldn't give them that, not then.



It's not a happy story, but it's my story. And it's okay to be sad about it. It doesn't mean I regret it. It just means it was hard.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That was a low point. Okay, look, it wasn't just *tacky*, it was…desperate. And sad. And a little bit embarrassing, even for me.

It's not that I have anything against people who advertise in the Penny Saver, okay? It's just…when you're trying to find someone to *raise your kid*, it feels like you're shopping for a toaster oven. Like, "Oh, this couple looks nice. They have a minivan and a fenced-in yard. Perfect!"

It just felt…transactional. And impersonal. And like I was reducing my baby to a product.

I wanted someone who genuinely *wanted* a child, not someone who was just filling a void or looking for a project. And I figured people who were advertising in the Penny Saver were probably…well, a little bit weird. No offense to anyone who uses the Penny Saver. It's just not where I wanted to find my baby's parents.

Paul and Vanessa, they were different. They felt…real. And they found me through a lawyer, which felt a lot more legit.

The Penny Saver was just a bad idea. A really, really bad idea. And I'm glad I didn't go through with it. It would have been a disaster. Honestly.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver thing? It's kinda embarrassing, honestly. It wasn't like we were *planning* on getting pregnant, okay? It just…happened. A momentary lapse in judgment involving Paulie Bleeker and a whole lot of awkwardness.

Anyway, once I found out, I was, like, totally freaking out. My mom was…supportive, in her own way, but she was also kinda overwhelmed. And my dad was just…quiet. It was a mess.

I knew I couldn't keep the baby. I wasn't ready. I was sixteen! I had, like, a life to live, or at least, a future to figure out. So, I started thinking about adoption.

But I didn't want to just…give the baby away to strangers. I wanted to find a good home. A *perfect* home. And my friend, Leah, she's really good at research and stuff. She's super organized. So I asked her to help me.

And she suggested the Penny Saver. It's this local classifieds paper. People put ads in there for everything – furniture, cars, lost dogs…and sometimes, people looking to adopt.

It was kinda weird, flipping through the Penny Saver, looking at these ads. Like, "Loving couple seeks a child to complete our family." It felt…clinical. But it was also a way to feel like I had some control over the situation. Like I could choose the right parents for the baby.

So, yeah. That's why we started looking at the adoption ads in the Penny Saver. It was a desperate attempt to find a good home for a baby I wasn't ready to raise. It was a really hard time, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, this is…a lot. It's not like picking out a sweater, you know? It's a whole human life. But I've been doing a lot of thinking, and talking to Mark and Vanessa, and here's what I'm hoping for.

I don't want perfect. Perfect doesn't exist. I just want…good.

I'm looking for a family that's, like, *stable*. Not necessarily rich, but comfortable. People who have their stuff together, you know? A house, jobs, a routine. Not a lot of drama.

I want people who are gonna be supportive. Like, really supportive. Not just saying "Oh, that's nice," but actually being there for the kid. Helping with homework, going to soccer games, just…being present.

And I want them to be open-minded. This kid is gonna have a story. A different story than most kids. I want them to be okay with that. To be curious about it, even.

I don't want them to try and replace the kid's other parents. I want them to be *additionals*. Like, another layer of love and support.

And honestly? I want them to be a little bit quirky. A little bit weird. Because normal is boring. I want this kid to grow up in a house where it's okay to be yourself, even if yourself is a little bit different.

Mark and Vanessa seem really good. They're…normal, in a good way. They're kind, and they seem like they really want this. But I want to make sure. I want to make sure this kid is going to be loved and happy.

It's just…it's a big decision. And I want to get it right.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot.

Look, they're nice people, I guess. Vanessa tries really hard, and Mark's…well, Mark's Mark. He means well, but he's kinda clueless. Like, seriously clueless. It's almost endearing, but also really frustrating.

They're just…so *perfect*. You know? Like, they have their whole life planned out, and they're already talking about college funds and matching outfits for their future kids. It's a little terrifying, honestly. It makes me feel like I'm failing at life just by existing.

And they're always trying to fix things. Like, they want to "help" me with my situation, which is sweet, but also super invasive. They don't get that I need to figure things out on my own. They just want everything to be neat and tidy and predictable.

Vanessa's a good egg, though. She's genuinely concerned, and she's trying to be supportive. But she's also kinda…judgmental. She doesn't say it outright, but you can tell she doesn't really understand what I'm going through.

Mark just nods along to whatever Vanessa says. He's a follower. A really enthusiastic follower.

They're good people, I guess. Just…not my people. They live in a different world. A world of matching sweaters and perfectly planned futures. And I'm just trying to survive the present.

Don't tell them I said that. They'd probably try to organize a support group for me. And I really don't need that right now.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was mortifying, even for me. But fine, I'll tell you.

I wrote: "Bleeker, you're a genuinely good egg. Don't let anyone tell you different. And seriously, stop being so weird. Love, Juno."

Yeah, I know. It's…not exactly Shakespeare. But it was the best I could come up with on the spot. I was trying to be sincere, but also keep it cool. It's a hard balance to strike, okay?

I was so worried he'd think it was lame. Or that he'd show it to everyone. But he didn't. He just…smiled. Which was good.

It was a weird time. A lot of feelings. And yearbooks are just…pressure.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Mrs. Bleeker… she's… complicated. Let's just say she wasn't exactly thrilled about me and Paul at first. Not thrilled *at all*.

She's very…protective of Bleeker. Like, fiercely protective. And I think she always saw me as this… chaotic force who was going to disrupt his perfectly planned life. Which, okay, maybe I was a little bit. But still!

She definitely judged me. A lot. The whole pregnant teenager thing didn't exactly scream "responsible future mother-in-law material," you know? She'd give me these little looks, like I was a science experiment gone wrong. And she always made these passive-aggressive comments about my… lifestyle choices.

She tried to be polite, I guess. But it was always strained. Like she was bracing herself for me to do something unpredictable. Which, fair enough. I *am* unpredictable.

Things got a little better after the baby was born. She saw that I actually cared about the kid, and that I was trying to do the right thing. But I don't think she ever fully warmed up to me. She still sends Bleeker care packages filled with organic baby food and educational toys. Which is nice, I guess. But also… a little condescending.

Honestly, I mostly just try to avoid her. It's less stressful that way. But I do appreciate that she loves Bleeker. And I know she wants what's best for him. Even if her idea of "best" is very different from mine.

So, yeah. That's Mrs. Bleeker. A well-meaning, but slightly terrifying, force of nature.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, scary, beige cloud. I keep picturing it, and my stomach does this weird flip-flop thing.

Honestly? I'm mostly just trying not to think about it. Distraction is my friend. I've been watching a lot of old movies and eating a lot of cheese puffs. It's not a healthy coping mechanism, I know, but it's working… for now.

But then I catch my mom looking at me, all soft and hopeful, talking about college applications, and it just… hits me. I'm gonna have to tell them. And it's not gonna be a fun conversation.

My dad's gonna be… disappointed. He's got this whole plan for me, and a baby definitely wasn't in it. He's a good guy, though. He'll come around. Eventually.

My mom… I don't even know. She's gonna cry. A lot. And then she's gonna ask a million questions. And then she's gonna try to fix everything. Which is sweet, but also… suffocating.

I just want to be honest with them. I want them to understand. But I'm also terrified of ruining everything. Of letting them down.

It's just… a lot. I'm trying to be brave, but mostly I just feel like a really big mess. I guess I'll just have to rip off the band-aid and get it over with. Maybe I'll bring them flowers. Or a really good cheese puff. That might help.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It's embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You want me to unpack my family stuff? Fine. But don't expect a heartwarming Hallmark movie moment, alright?

It's…complicated. My parents are good people. They really are. They just…don't *get* me. Like, at all. They're super into everything being perfect and planned and…normal. And this? This whole pregnancy thing? It's the opposite of normal.

If I told them everything, I just know they'd freak out. My mom would cry, my dad would try to "fix" things, and then they'd both start giving me lectures about responsibility and choices and…ugh. It would be a disaster.

It's not that I don't love them. I do. But they have this way of making everything about *them* and their feelings. And right now, I need to figure this out on my own, you know? I need to be the one in control.

Plus, they're already kinda disappointed in me. I'm not exactly the overachiever they always hoped for. I skip school sometimes, I hang out with Bleeker, I listen to sad music…I'm not exactly living the life they envisioned for me.

So, asking for help feels like admitting I can't handle things. And it feels like adding to their disappointment. It's easier to just…deal with it myself. Even if it's really hard.

It's just…they wouldn't understand. They wouldn't get why I'm choosing to do this. And I don't want their judgment. I just want them to…be my parents. But right now, that feels impossible.

Does that make sense? It's messy. Everything is messy.

Ugh, okay, this is…it’s a big thing to talk about, obviously. But you asked. So.

It’s not like I *wanted* to get pregnant. It was…a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake. And honestly, I’m not ready to be a mom. Like, not even close. I’m sixteen. I still have a lot of figuring out to do about *myself*, you know? I’m barely an adult.

And it’s not just about me. It’s about the baby, too. I want that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who are actually prepared, a good education, opportunities…things I can’t really offer right now. I’m still in high school. I’m working a part-time job at a movie theater. I can barely afford my own life, let alone a baby’s.

Mark and Vanessa…they’re amazing. They’ve been trying to have a baby for a long time, and they’re so excited. They’re ready. They have a beautiful house, a stable life, and they’re just…good people. They’ll give this baby a life I can’t.

It’s not like I’m just giving the baby away. It’s…it’s more like I’m choosing a family for it. A family that can give it everything it needs. And I get to be a part of that, you know? I get to know that the baby is loved and cared for.

It’s not easy. It’s probably the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make. But I truly believe it’s the best thing for everyone involved. It’s not about what *I* want. It’s about what’s best for the baby. And right now, that’s with Mark and Vanessa.

It doesn’t mean I won’t think about the baby. It doesn’t mean I won’t miss it. But I know I’m doing the right thing. And that’s…that’s gotta be enough.



It’s complicated, okay? It’s not a happy, sunshine-and-rainbows situation. But it’s real. And it’s what I’ve decided.

Ugh, okay, this is…a big deal. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person*. My kid. So, yeah, I have a list. It's not written down or anything, but it's in my head. And it's pretty firm.

First of all, they gotta be…stable. Like, financially stable, emotionally stable. No crazy drama. I don't need someone who's gonna be moving every six months or getting into fights with their neighbors. A solid foundation is important.

They also have to be…open-minded. I'm not exactly a conventional person, and I don't want my kid growing up in a super-strict, judgmental environment. They need to be able to accept people for who they are, even if they're a little weird.

And they have to be…fun. Seriously. Life's too short to be serious all the time. I want my kid to have parents who will laugh with them, take them on adventures, and just generally make life interesting.

They also need to be okay with me being…around. I don't want to be a complete stranger in my kid's life. I want to be able to have a relationship, to be a part of their life, even if it's not in a traditional parent-child way.

And finally, they have to *really* want this. Like, not just because they can't have kids of their own, but because they genuinely want to love and raise a child. It has to be a selfless decision.

Mark and Vanessa…they seem pretty good. They're a little…perfect, maybe. But they're kind, and they're stable, and they seem genuinely excited about the idea of having a baby. They're probably the best option.

It's just…it's hard. It's a really hard decision. But I want what's best for my kid. And I'm trying to find people who can give them that.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about the "emotional journey." Like it's some kind of scenic road trip. It's not. It's more like wading through quicksand while someone's playing sad music.

Honestly? I don't have a plan. Not a *real* one. I'm just…trying to take it one day at a time. I mean, I've thought about it. A lot. And it's gonna suck. A lot.

I think…I think I'm trying to focus on the fact that this isn't about me. It's about the baby. And giving the baby the best life possible. And that means a life with parents who are ready and able to give it everything I can't.

I'm gonna talk to Paul. A lot. He's…good at listening. And he doesn't try to fix things, he just…is there. And my dad. He's surprisingly okay with all this. He just wants me to be happy. Which is annoying, but also kind of sweet.

I'm also gonna try to…distract myself. Watch movies, listen to music, hang out with Leah. Just…normal stuff. Pretend like everything's okay, even when it's totally not.

But I know there's gonna be times when I just…fall apart. And that's okay. I think. I'm gonna let myself feel whatever I need to feel. Sadness, anger, regret…whatever. I'm not gonna try to bottle it up.

And I'm gonna remember that this isn't forever. It's just…a really hard chapter. And eventually, it'll be over. And I'll be okay. I have to be.

I'm also kinda hoping that knowing the adoptive parents, Mark and Vanessa, will help. They seem…nice. And they promise to keep me updated. Which is good. I don't want to be completely cut off.

It's just…it's complicated. And scary. And I'm really, really hoping I'm making the right decision. But I think I am. I have to.



Look, I'm not gonna pretend I'm all brave and selfless. I'm terrified. But I'm also trying to be responsible. And that means doing what's best for the baby, even if it breaks my heart.

Ugh, okay, you noticed that, huh? It's a thing. It's just…weird. People keep saying I'm "delivering" a baby. Like I'm UPS or something. "Special delivery!" Seriously?

It's not a package! It's a person! A tiny human being! It feels so…transactional. Like I'm just dropping something off at someone else's doorstep.

And it implies I'm the one doing all the work. Like, yeah, I'm carrying it, but it's not like I *made* it appear. It's a whole collaborative effort, you know?

I guess it's just a word choice that rubs me the wrong way. It feels…impersonal. And this is a really personal thing. It's a life. It deserves more than a "delivery."

Paul keeps saying I'm overthinking it, but I can't help it. I analyze everything. It's a coping mechanism. And "deliver" just feels…wrong.

It's like, if someone said they were "delivering" a puppy, you'd be like, "Okay, that's a little strange." It's the same thing. Except way more important.

So yeah, I find the term "deliver" weird. Don't judge me.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That was a disaster waiting to happen. But look, it wasn't like I *agreed* exactly. It was more like…he just sort of…inserted himself. My dad is…enthusiastic. And he has a hard time reading social cues. It's a genetic thing, I think.

He heard me talking about it, about meeting with Mark and Vanessa, and he just got all excited. He started talking about how he wanted to be involved, how he wanted to "support" me. And honestly? I was just tired. I was already dealing with a lot, and arguing with him felt exhausting.

Plus, a tiny, pathetic part of me thought maybe it would be…good? Like, maybe if he was there, it would look more…normal? Like I wasn't just some teenager making a huge decision on my own. Which is stupid, I know.

It was a mistake. A huge, monumental mistake. He asked way too many questions, he made awkward jokes, and he kept trying to bond with Mark and Vanessa over their shared love of maple syrup. It was mortifying.

I definitely regretted it. But you know, sometimes you just gotta let your dad be your dad. Even when he's being a total weirdo. It's part of the package. And honestly, it made the whole thing a little bit more…me. A little bit more chaotic and real.

So yeah, I didn't *want* him there. But he was there. And I survived. Barely.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? It kinda sucks. It's like, everyone else seems to have it all figured out. They know what they want to be when they grow up, what kind of music they like, what kind of clothes they wear. And me? I just…am.

I'm not a girly-girl. I don't really do the whole makeup and shopping thing. But I'm not exactly a tomboy either. I like music, but I don't really fit into any one genre. I just listen to whatever sounds good.

It's frustrating, because people always want to put you in a box. "Oh, she's the quirky one." Or, "She's the smart one." And it's like, can't I just be…me? Without having to be labeled?

I guess it's kinda freeing, too. I don't have to live up to anyone's expectations. I can just do my own thing. But it's also lonely, sometimes. It feels like I'm floating around, not really belonging anywhere.

Paul keeps telling me it's okay to not have everything figured out. He says it's part of growing up. And I guess he's right. But it's still weird. It's like, I'm supposed to be figuring out who I am, but I don't even know where to start.

I think maybe…maybe that's okay. Maybe I don't *need* to know. Maybe I can just keep exploring and discovering things about myself. And maybe, eventually, I'll figure it out. Or maybe I won't. And that's okay too.

It's just…complicated. You know? It's a lot to deal with when you're also, like, pregnant. But hey, at least I have a good soundtrack for it.

Ugh. Seriously? That was…a moment. It wasn't like, a huge explosion or anything, but it was just…*everything* about that situation felt wrong.

It wasn't even the "go upstairs" part, you know? It was the way Bren just said it, all sweet and concerned, like we were little kids who needed to be shielded. Like my dad's feelings were more important than, I don't know, *me* having a conversation with him?

I think I just stared at her for a second, like she'd grown a second head. Then I probably said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, good idea, Bren. Let's just retreat to our bedrooms like good little girls and pretend everything's fine." I'm pretty sure I rolled my eyes too. It's kind of my default setting.

It just felt so…dismissive. Like she didn't understand that I needed to talk to my dad, even if it was awkward. And it felt like she was trying to smooth things over instead of letting us actually *deal* with them.

Leah was just standing there, looking uncomfortable, as usual. She's not exactly a confrontational person.

I think I ended up just walking out of the kitchen. I didn't want to get into a whole thing with Bren. I just needed to get away and think. It was just…a lot. And it made me realize that Bren and I see the world in totally different ways. She wants everything to be neat and tidy, and I'm just…messy. And sometimes, messy is real life.

It was a small thing, but it kind of summed up our whole relationship, you know? She means well, but she just doesn't *get* it.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. And honestly, it's something I've thought about a *lot*. It's not like it's a simple "yes" or "no" kind of thing.

At first, the idea of getting updates and photos…it kinda freaked me out. Like, would it just make everything harder? Would it make me want the baby back, even though I know that's not what's best? Would it be weird for everyone involved?

But then I talked to Paul and Vanessa, and they explained it a little better. They said it's not about me being a "backup parent" or anything. It's about letting the baby know where they come from. It's about giving them a sense of identity. And it's about letting *me* know that they're okay.

It still feels…complicated. I mean, it's gonna be hard seeing pictures of them growing up with another family. It's gonna be hard knowing I'm not there for their first steps or their first birthday.

But I think…I think it's the right thing to do. It's not about me getting to relive my pregnancy or pretend I'm still their mom. It's about doing what's best for the baby. And if that means getting to see them grow up happy and healthy, even from a distance, then I'm okay with that.

It's still scary, though. It's gonna be a lot to process. But I think…I think I can handle it. As long as everyone's on the same page and we're all respectful of each other's feelings.

It's not how I pictured things, obviously. But life rarely goes according to plan, right? And sometimes, the best things are the ones you never expected.



It's just…a lot. Okay? A lot to think about.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…not good. It was like someone just punched me in the stomach, you know? I mean, I *knew* it was an open adoption, and I knew what that meant, kinda. But hearing Gerta actually *say* it, all clinical and legal-sounding…it just made it real.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby to have a good life. I did. I really did. It was about…losing control. Like, I was already giving up the baby, which was hard enough, but to hear that I wouldn't even have legal rights anymore? That I wouldn't even be a legal parent? It felt…wrong.

It felt like I was just…a vessel. Like I was just carrying the baby for someone else, and then I'd just disappear. And I was trying to be all cool and collected, you know? Like, "Yeah, whatever, I'm fine with this." But inside, I was totally freaking out.

It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Was I just trying to avoid responsibility?

I think that was the moment I really started to understand how complicated this whole thing was. It wasn't just about giving a baby up for adoption. It was about giving up a part of myself. And it was about trusting someone else to love and raise a child that was a part of me.

It was scary. Really scary. And I definitely needed a lot of chocolate and a good conversation with Paul to get through it. But it also made me realize that Gerta, despite being kinda intense, was looking out for the baby's best interests. And that's what mattered most, I guess. Even if it totally sucked.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. She's…intense. And honestly? It's kinda heartbreaking. It's not that I don't get wanting a family, you know? It's just…she wants it *so* badly. Like, it's consuming her.

It's weird seeing someone so desperate for something I'm kinda…giving away. It makes me think about all the stuff she's probably picturing, all the perfect little moments. And it makes me wonder if I'm doing the right thing.

I mean, I'm not judging her. She's a good person. She and Mark are gonna be amazing parents. They're stable, they're loving, they're…normal. Which is kinda the point, right? This baby deserves normal.

But it's just…a lot. She keeps talking about names and nurseries and first steps, and I'm just trying to get through the day without having a complete meltdown. It's like she's already got this whole life planned out, and I'm just a temporary vessel.

I guess it's good that someone is so excited. It makes me feel like this baby is actually wanted. But it also makes me feel…replaceable. Which is probably just my teenage angst talking.

I just hope she understands that this isn't some fairytale. It's gonna be hard work. And it's not always gonna be perfect. And sometimes, you just gotta deal with a screaming baby and a mountain of dirty diapers.

But yeah. I want her to be happy. I really do. I just wish she'd maybe tone it down a notch. It's a little overwhelming.

Ugh. Okay, so you want my take on Mark and the whole dad thing? Honestly? It's…complicated.

He's trying, I'll give him that. He's not exactly overflowing with emotional intelligence, but he's trying to be a good guy. And that response…it was classic Mark. All awkward and rambling and trying to be cool.

He's clearly terrified. Like, genuinely scared of messing things up. Which, okay, fair. Being a dad is a huge responsibility. It's not something you can just wing. But he's trying to downplay it, to act like it's no big deal. Like he's just gonna casually step into this role and everything will be fine.

And that's…not realistic.

He's got this whole "chill dude" persona going on, but underneath it all, he's a mess. He's still figuring out who *he* is, let alone how to be a father.

I think he's scared of commitment, too. He's always been kinda drifting, you know? And now he's being asked to settle down and be responsible. It's probably freaking him out.

But he cares. I can see that. He cares about me, and he cares about the baby. He just doesn't know how to show it in a way that doesn't make him sound like a total dork.

It's frustrating, but also…kind of endearing. He's a work in progress. And maybe, just maybe, he'll figure it out.

But seriously, someone needs to tell him to stop trying to be cool and just be honest. It would make things a lot easier.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to unpack this *again*? Fine. It's not like I haven't replayed it in my head a million times.

It's not just about being unsupervised, okay? It's about *where* I'm being unsupervised. The Loring's house is…intense. It's all Pottery Barn and perfect smiles and pretending everything is sunshine and rainbows. It's suffocating.

And Mark and Vanessa Loring? They're nice people, I guess. But they're…expectant. Like they're waiting for me to mess up. Like they're judging every single thing I do. And they talk about the baby *constantly*. Like it's some kind of perfect little project.

It's not that I don't want a good life for the baby. I do. It's just…their idea of a good life is so different from mine. It's all about piano lessons and organic food and private schools. It's a lot of pressure.
