And honestly, it feels weird being in their house knowing I'm, like, a temporary arrangement. Like I'm a guest star in their perfect little life. It makes me feel…replaceable.

So yeah, being left unsupervised there makes me uncomfortable. It feels like I'm being watched, judged, and expected to fit into a mold that I just don't fit into. It's just…a lot.

It's not that I don't appreciate them wanting to help. It's just…their help comes with a lot of expectations. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that yet.

Can we just drop it now? It's making me anxious just thinking about it.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not something I think about all the time, because if I did, I'd probably just curl up in a ball and never leave my room again.

It's complicated, you know? It's not like I *wanted* to be pregnant. It was…an accident. A really big, life-altering accident. And for a while, I was just trying to figure out how to not completely ruin my life.

But then I met Mark and Vanessa. And they…they just seemed *good*. Like, genuinely good people. They wanted a baby so badly, and they were so excited about the idea of being parents. And I realized that maybe, just maybe, this wasn't a disaster. Maybe it was…a good thing.

So, yeah, giving them this baby…it's a big deal. It's a really big deal. It's a gift, I guess. A really messy, complicated gift. And it's kinda scary, letting go. It's like…giving away a piece of myself.

But I also know that they're going to give this baby a good life. A stable life. A loving life. And that's more than I can offer right now. I'm still figuring out my own life, you know? I'm still trying to figure out who I am.

So, I'm happy for them. I really am. And I hope they're happy too. And I hope this baby grows up to be a good person. And I hope they name it something cool.

It's just…it's a lot to process. It's not something I think about in a simple way. It's just…life, I guess. And life is messy. And complicated. And sometimes, it's really, really good. Even when it's scary.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was, like, years ago. But fine, I'll explain. It wasn't *just* the "ASAP," okay? It was the whole vibe.

Mark is…sweet. He really is. But he's also kinda clueless. And he was trying so hard to be cool and efficient, you know? Like he was some big-shot businessman. And he sent me a text that was, like, entirely in acronyms. "ASAP," "BRB," "TTYL." It was ridiculous.

It just felt…performative. Like he was trying to impress me with his texting skills. And it was so unnecessary. I mean, if you need something, just *say* you need it. Don't hide behind a wall of abbreviations.

Plus, "ASAP" is just…aggressive. It implies a level of urgency that rarely exists. Like, is the world going to end if I don't respond immediately? Probably not.

I just wanted to gently poke fun at his attempt to be all business-y. It was a defense mechanism, honestly. I was nervous around him, and sarcasm is my go-to coping strategy.

It's not that I hate acronyms. It's just that they felt…wrong coming from Mark. He's a sensitive guy. He doesn't need to pretend to be someone he's not.

And honestly, it was a funny moment. Don't judge me. I have a weird sense of humor.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking *me* about guitars? Like I'm some kind of rock star? Whatever. But fine, I'll indulge you.

It's not like I *play* guitar or anything. Paul tried to teach me a few chords, but I mostly just poked at the strings and complained about my fingers hurting. But I've observed. I've listened. And I've formed an opinion.

My preferred brand is definitely **Fender**. Specifically, a vintage Telecaster.

Why? Because they're…unpretentious. They're not trying too hard to be fancy or show off. They're just solid, reliable, and they sound good. They're the kind of guitar you can just pick up and play without having to worry about impressing anyone.

Plus, they have a history. They've been around forever, and a lot of my favorite musicians play them. Like, Bruce Springsteen. He's pretty cool. And they just look…real. Not like those guitars with a million knobs and flashing lights.

It's kinda like me, I guess. I don't need a lot of bells and whistles. I'm just…me. And a Fender Telecaster feels like it gets that.

Don't tell Paul I said that, though. He's a Les Paul guy. We have…disagreements. It's complicated.

Ugh, okay, fine. You caught me. It was a terrible idea. A monumentally stupid, impulsive decision. And honestly? I still don't entirely know *why* I did it.

It wasn't like I *hate* the Melvins or anything. They're…fine. Loud. But fine. It was more about…trying to impress Paul. He's into that kind of music, and I just wanted him to think I was cool. Like I had good taste. Like I wasn't just a regular, awkward teenager who spends her time eating cheese curls and watching bad TV.

I figured, what's the harm in a little white lie? It's not like I was claiming to be best friends with them or anything. I just said I knew their stuff. And then it spiraled. I kept digging myself deeper and deeper, making up details, pretending to be all knowledgeable about their discography. It was a disaster.

It was stupid and embarrassing, and I felt like a total fraud. And the worst part is, Paul probably saw right through it. He's not an idiot.

I just…I wanted him to like me. Is that so wrong?

Look, I'm not proud of it. It was a dumb move. And I learned my lesson. Honesty is the best policy, even if it means admitting you don't know who the Melvins are.

Don't judge me too harshly, okay? I was a mess back then. Still kind of am, if I'm being honest.

Ugh, okay, Mark. Right. That's…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing, you know? It was more…comfortable. And surprisingly, not awkward. Which is saying something for me.

When we were playing and singing together, it was the only time I felt like I could actually *breathe*. Like, everything else was just…noise. School, the pregnancy, Paul, my parents…it all faded away when we were just making music.

He wasn't trying to fix me or give me advice or anything. He just…got it. He understood the quiet parts of me, the parts I didn't even know were there. And he wasn't afraid to be a little weird with me. Which is a huge plus.

It wasn't about being good or bad at music, it was about just *doing* it. Letting go and making something together. It was like we were speaking a different language, one that didn't need words.

I guess you could say it was a connection. A real one. But it wasn't a "we're meant to be together" kind of connection. It was more like…two people who found a little bit of peace in each other's company. And in the music.

It was nice. Really nice. And honestly, I miss it sometimes. But it was also just…what it was. A good thing that happened at a weird time in my life. And I'm glad it happened. Even if it's kinda hard to explain.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask about Roosevelt. It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing, if I'm being honest.

Well, my dad, he's…enthusiastic about history. Specifically, presidents. He's got all these little bobbleheads and books and stuff. And he's always going on about Theodore Roosevelt. How he was a rough rider and a conservationist and a generally awesome dude.

So, when I got the guitar – it was a hand-me-down from Mark, Paul's friend – it just…felt like a Roosevelt. It was sturdy and kinda old-fashioned, but with a lot of potential. And it had this quiet strength, you know? Like it could handle anything.

Plus, it was kinda ironic. Like, a guitar named after a super-masculine president. It just felt…right.

Mark thought it was dumb. Paul just laughed. But I stuck with it. Roosevelt and I, we've been through a lot. He's a good listener. Doesn't judge. And he doesn't ask a lot of questions. Which is good, because I usually don't have answers.

So yeah. That's why I named my guitar Roosevelt. It's a dad thing. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, so the whole Vanessa and Mark thing. It's…complicated. It's not like I *want* to keep them in the loop, you know? It's my pregnancy, not theirs. But they're good people. Really good people. And they're gonna be the ones raising this kid, so they deserve to know what's going on.

It's just…awkward. Like, super awkward. Having to explain everything, answer their questions, let them feel all the feelings. It's exhausting. And it makes it feel so much more *real*, which is something I've been trying to avoid.

I feel bad for them, honestly. They wanted a baby for so long, and now it's happening in this…weird way. I don't want them to feel like I'm just a vessel or something. I want them to know I'm taking this seriously, and that I want what's best for the baby.

So, I guess I feel…responsible. Like, I have to keep them updated, even if it makes me uncomfortable. It's the right thing to do. And they've been really supportive, which is more than I deserve.

It's just…it's hard. It's hard to let go, to let them in. But I'm trying. I'm trying to be a good person and do the right thing. Even if it means having to talk about my feelings, which, let's be real, is not my favorite activity.

It's a whole mess of feelings, okay? Don't make me analyze it more than I already have. It's just…ugh. Life.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me to rehash this? It's not like I haven't thought about it, like, a million times. But fine. You want 104% sure? Here's the deal.

It's not about *not* wanting the baby, okay? It's about wanting the baby to have everything. And I can't give it that. Not right now. Not ever, probably.

I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I'm not ready to give up my life, my dreams, everything, to be a mom. It's not fair to me, and it's definitely not fair to the baby.

Mark and Vanessa…they're amazing. They're stable, they're loving, they're *ready*. They've been waiting for this. They can give this baby a life I just can't. A house with a yard, college funds, family vacations…things I can only dream about.

And it's not like I'm just giving it away to strangers. I *picked* them. I got to meet them, talk to them, make sure they were the right fit. It's not some random transaction.

It's hard. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do. But it's the right thing. It's the selfless thing. And honestly, knowing that this baby is going to have a good life, a *better* life, that makes it…okay.

So yeah, 104% sure. Because it's not about what I want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's all that matters.

Can we please talk about something else now? This is getting depressing.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It wasn't exactly a party in my head, let me tell you.

It was…weird. Like, I just handed over a baby. A baby I carried for nine months. And they were immediately popping champagne and redecorating the nursery. It felt…fast. And kinda insensitive.

I mean, I *wanted* them to be happy. I really did. They were good people, and they were going to be amazing parents. But it felt like they were celebrating *my* sacrifice, not just the arrival of a baby. Like I was just a vessel, and now the vessel was empty and they could finally get on with their lives.

I know that sounds selfish. And maybe it was. But it was a really emotional time, and it was hard to see them so…gleeful. It made me feel kinda invisible. Like I wasn't part of the equation anymore.

Paul tried to explain it to me, said they were just relieved and excited. And I get that. But it still stung. It made me realize how different our perspectives were. They were starting a family, and I was…well, I was going back to high school.

I didn't hate them for it. I just…needed some space. And a lot of chocolate. And maybe a really good movie. It took a while to process, you know? It wasn't a clean break, even though that's what everyone kept saying. It was messy and complicated and real.

So yeah, the celebratory mood? It was…awkward. And a little bit heartbreaking. But I got over it. Eventually. It just took some time. And a lot of self-reflection.

Ugh. Seriously? People are *talking*? Like, I'm not surprised, okay? Small towns. Everyone's got an opinion, and they're not shy about sharing it. But it's still… annoying.

It's my life, you know? My body. My decision. And honestly, it's none of anyone else's business. But of course, that doesn't stop them from speculating and whispering and probably making up all sorts of ridiculous stories.

I heard Mrs. Rubins was asking around at the grocery store. *The grocery store!* Like, really? And I'm pretty sure Leah's been giving me these weird, pitying looks. As if I'm some kind of charity case.

It's just… frustrating. I'm trying to figure things out, and dealing with all this extra noise is the last thing I need. I'm not looking for sympathy, or advice, or judgment. I just want people to mind their own business.

Paul's been really good about it, though. He's all, "Ignore them, they're just jealous." Which is sweet, but also… not entirely helpful.

I guess I just wish people would realize that life isn't always black and white. It's messy and complicated and sometimes you make choices that other people don't understand. And that's okay.

So, how do I *feel* about the rumors? I feel… annoyed. And a little bit angry. And mostly just really, really tired of everyone else's opinions. I just want to be left alone to figure things out. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Okay. Don't make me think about it too hard, alright? It's…complicated. It's not like I'm thrilled about it, obviously. It's my baby. Even if it's, like, a tiny little blob right now.

It's scary. Really scary. I keep picturing this perfect little family, and then…I'm not part of it. And that kinda sucks. It feels weird to just…hand it over. Like, I made this thing, and now I'm just giving it away.

But I also know it's the right thing to do. I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I have my own life to figure out. I want to finish school, maybe go to college, and definitely not be changing diapers for the next eighteen years.

Paul and Vanessa…they're good people. They're stable. They want a baby. They can give it a life I just can't. And that's…comforting, I guess. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it feel less selfish.

It's just…it's a lot. It's a lot to process. I try not to think about it too much, because then I just start crying. I'm trying to be practical, you know? Like, this is what I have to do. But it still feels like a huge, gaping hole in my future.

So, how do I feel about it? It's a mix of everything. Sad, scared, relieved, guilty…it's a mess. And honestly, I don't think I'll really know how I feel about it until it actually happens.

Just…don't make me talk about it anymore, okay? It's kinda bumming me out.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about that now? It was a whole thing. Look, it wasn't about *wanting* to surprise them, exactly. It was more about…control. And a little bit of payback.

They were so…prepared. Like, they had the nursery already decorated, all gender-neutral, of course. And they were talking about names and college funds and everything. It was intense. And honestly? It felt kinda weird. Like they were already planning this kid's whole life before it was even born.

And they were so…nice. Too nice, maybe. Like they were trying to make up for everything. Which, okay, fair. But it felt like they were treating me like a project, not a person who made a decision.

So, when I found out it was a boy, I just…didn't tell them. I wanted them to have a moment of genuine surprise. A moment where they weren't prepared, where they couldn't control everything. A moment where they just had to react.

It was a little bit petty, I admit. But it felt good. It felt like I was taking back a little bit of power. And honestly, their faces when I told them? Priceless.

Plus, Vanessa was already picturing a little girl she could dress up in cute outfits. It was kinda funny to see that all fall apart.

Don't judge me. I was a mess. And sometimes, a little bit of mischief is exactly what you need.

Ugh. Seriously? That lady. Okay, deep breaths. It was…infuriating. And mortifying. And just…ugh.

It wasn't even the *words* exactly, it was the *tone*. Like she'd seen a million girls like me, already written me off as some irresponsible kid who couldn't handle things. Like she thought I was just gonna blink and hand the baby over without a second thought.

It felt so…dismissive. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like the fact that I was actually thinking this through, making a really hard decision, didn't even register with her. She was just seeing a statistic, not a person.

I wanted to tell her to mind her own business, but I was too stunned to say anything. Paul was trying to be supportive, but even *he* looked a little uncomfortable.

It made me question everything, you know? Like, was I doing the wrong thing? Was I just being selfish? But then I remembered why I was doing this. It wasn't about me. It was about giving this baby the best life possible, and I knew I wasn't ready to give it that right now.

It just…sucked. It was a reminder that people are quick to judge, and that sometimes, you have to deal with a lot of crap just for trying to do what you think is right.

It definitely made me want to prove her wrong. To show her that I *was* capable of making a responsible decision, even if it wasn't the "traditional" one. And to show that adoption isn't a failure, it's a loving choice.

Honestly, I still get annoyed just thinking about it. That lady needed a serious reality check.

Ugh, okay, where do I even start? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just magically works out. There were a lot of…things.

First off, telling my dad. That was…rough. He's a pretty quiet guy, and I thought he was gonna explode. He didn't, thankfully, but it was just…awkward. And then my mom had to get involved, and suddenly it was all tears and lectures. It was a lot.

Then there was school. Trying to pretend everything was normal when my stomach was getting bigger and bigger. People started noticing, and the whispers started. It was mortifying. And trying to keep up with my classes while dealing with morning sickness? Not fun.

Finding the right couple was…weird. It wasn't like shopping for a new pair of shoes. It was a *baby*. And I wanted to make sure it was going to a good home, with people who were gonna love it and take care of it. That was a lot of pressure.

And then there was the whole emotional thing. Like, realizing I was actually pregnant, and that this was real. And then having to think about giving the baby up. That was the hardest part. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it still hurt. A lot.

People had opinions, too. Everyone did. Some people were supportive, some people were judgmental. It was exhausting trying to deal with everyone's expectations.

And honestly, just dealing with being a teenager and pregnant at the same time was hard enough. I was still trying to figure out who I was, and then suddenly I was responsible for another human being. It was a lot to handle.

But, you know, I got through it. With the help of my family, my friends, and Paul. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because I knew I was doing what was best for the baby. And that's all that really mattered.

It was just…a lot. A really, really lot.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly, it's still kinda processing. This whole thing – the pregnancy, deciding to give the baby up, meeting Mark and Vanessa…it’s flipped my world upside down.

Love…before all this, I thought it was just, like, whatever you see in movies. Dramatic declarations, grand gestures. Turns out, it’s a lot more complicated. It’s about being there for people, even when it’s hard. It’s about wanting what’s best for them, even if it means letting them go. Seeing Mark and Vanessa together, how they *really* wanted this baby, and how happy they were…that was a different kind of love than I ever imagined. It wasn’t about me, it was about them and this little person. And that was…good.

Responsibility…that was a hard one. I mean, I’m sixteen. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone a whole human being. But having to actually think about someone else’s future, about making the right choices for this baby…it forced me to grow up, fast. It wasn’t about what *I* wanted anymore. It was about what was best for this kid. And that was terrifying, but also…empowering, in a weird way.

Growing up…well, that’s still happening, obviously. But before this, I thought growing up was about getting a driver’s license and going to parties. Now I realize it’s about making tough decisions, facing consequences, and learning to be okay with things not going the way you planned. It’s about realizing that life isn’t a movie, and there aren’t always happy endings. But that doesn’t mean it can’t be good.

I used to think I had everything figured out. I was gonna go to college, become a journalist, and write about things. Now…I don’t know. I’m still figuring it out. But I think I’m okay with that. I think I’m okay with not having all the answers.

This whole experience has made me realize that life is messy and unpredictable. And that’s okay. It’s about learning to navigate the mess, and finding your own way. And maybe, just maybe, finding a little bit of happiness along the way.

It’s still…a lot. But I think I’m stronger now. And I think I’m a little bit wiser. And I think I’m finally starting to understand what it means to be a grown-up. Or, at least, to be *trying* to be a grown-up.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about *that*? It's…complicated. It's not like I'm, like, obsessed or anything. It's just…interesting.

Look, it's a perfectly normal house, mostly. Except the living room. It's just…*there*. Completely furnished, like someone just got up and walked away mid-conversation. And it's been like that for, like, years. Everyone in town knows about it.

It's not creepy, exactly. It's just…sad. Like a snapshot of a life that just stopped. And I'm a watcher, okay? I notice things. I see patterns. And that room…it feels like a puzzle.

It makes you wonder, you know? Who lived there? What happened? Why did they leave everything behind? It's like a story waiting to be told. And I'm a sucker for a good story.

Plus, it's a good place to think. It's quiet. And no one bothers you. It's kinda…peaceful, in a weird way.

So, yeah, I go there sometimes. I don't *do* anything. I just…sit. And think. And try to figure things out. It's not a big deal. Don't read too much into it.

It's just a room. A really weird, abandoned room. And I'm just a girl who likes to observe. Okay? Now stop asking about it. It's making me uncomfortable.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me about the Wizard. That guy was seriously creepy. Okay, so, what he meant when he whispered "Do you know how long I've wanted this?"… it wasn't about the baby. Not exactly.

It was about control. About finally having someone, *anyone*, completely dependent on him. He'd been building up this whole fantasy in his head, this idea of being a father, of having a family, but it wasn't about love or connection. It was about power.

He'd been watching me, you know? Watching Paul and me, watching my life. He wanted to be a part of it, but not in a healthy way. He wanted to *control* it. He wanted to be the one making the decisions.

He'd been fixated on the idea of adoption for a long time, and he saw me as a way to finally achieve that. He didn't care about what *I* wanted, or what was best for the baby. He just wanted to fulfill his own selfish desires.

It was… disturbing. Really disturbing. And it made me realize just how messed up he was. It wasn't a sweet, fatherly longing. It was something much darker.

Honestly, I try not to think about it too much. It gives me the creeps. But yeah, that's what I think he meant. He'd been fantasizing about this for a long time, and he finally thought he had a way to make it happen. It was all about control. And it was terrifying.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my life choices now? Fine. It's not like I have anything better to do.

Look, it wasn't just *any* juice container. It was a SunnyD container. And SunnyD is, like, the official drink of questionable decisions. It just felt…symbolic, okay? Like I was shedding a layer of bad judgment. Dramatic, I know. But I was feeling a lot of things at the time.

And I rushed to Dancing Elk because Mr. Bleeker was supposed to be there. He said he'd be there. And I needed to talk to him. About, you know…everything. It wasn't just about the pregnancy, it was about…everything. He's a good guy, even if he's kinda clueless.

Plus, Dancing Elk has those weird, old-fashioned soda fountain chairs. They're surprisingly comfortable. And I needed to sit down. My legs were killing me from all the marching.

It wasn't a calculated move, okay? It was a desperate attempt to find some normalcy in a completely insane situation. And maybe get a cherry phosphate. Don't judge me. I was stressed.

Honestly, you're overthinking it. It was a juice container and a boy. It's not rocket science.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…a moment.

Okay, so, the Tough Girl – her name was Renee, and she was, like, aggressively athletic – she was at the drugstore with me because I needed some prenatal vitamins. And I was trying to be inconspicuous, which, let's be real, is impossible when you're visibly pregnant.

And she just…stared. Like, a *long* stare. And then, out of nowhere, she just blurts out, "Are those real brown?"

I was mortified. Completely and utterly mortified. I mean, what kind of question is that?! And in a public place, no less!

I think I just mumbled something about it not being a topic of conversation and tried to change the subject. But she just kept going on about how she thought a lot of girls dyed their nipples or something. It was…weird. And invasive. And just generally awkward.

Honestly, I think she was just trying to shock me. She was a bit of a…character. But it was still super uncomfortable. It just reinforced the fact that people feel entitled to comment on your body when you're pregnant, even if it's totally inappropriate.

It's one of those things I'll probably never forget. And it definitely made me avoid the drugstore for a while. Seriously. The shame.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She was…everything, honestly. Before all this happened, she was just my best friend. We’d spend hours at the arcade, making fun of people at the mall, just generally being sarcastic teenagers. But when I found out I was pregnant, she was the first person I told. And she didn’t freak out, which was a huge relief.

She didn’t try to fix things, or tell me what to do. She just…listened. And then she started researching adoption, because I was too overwhelmed to even think straight. She found all the agencies, made the phone calls, and basically took care of all the practical stuff. I would have just spiraled if it wasn’t for her.

It wasn’t always easy, though. She got really into the whole “responsible friend” thing, which meant a lot of lectures about my diet and my general life choices. And she was *way* more emotional about the whole thing than I was, at first. She kept talking about how “brave” I was, and I just wanted her to stop. It felt weird, you know? Like I wasn’t doing anything special.

But she was also the one who made me laugh when I wanted to cry. She was the one who reminded me that I was still just Juno, even with a baby growing inside me. She was the one who came with me to all the doctor’s appointments and held my hand when I was scared.

Honestly, I don’t think I could have gone through any of it without her. She was my rock. She helped me see that I had options, and that it was okay to choose the one that was right for me, even if it was hard. She didn’t judge me, she just supported me. And that meant everything.

She’s a good egg, that Leah. A little bit annoying sometimes, but a good egg. I owe her big time.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a moment. A really, really awkward moment. Honestly, it wasn't some grand plan, okay? It was mostly just…desperation. And a little bit of spite.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they were all about the perfect life. The perfect house, the perfect job, the perfect future. And they were so…focused on *their* perfect life, they weren't really seeing *me*. They were being polite, sure, but it felt…distant. Like I was a project, not a person.

And they kept talking about how they wanted a baby, how they were "ready" for a baby. But they weren't talking about the actual *baby*. They were talking about the idea of a baby. The perfect baby.

So, I just…I snapped. I was sitting there, and they were going on about paint colors for the nursery, and I just blurted out, "Do you want to see it?"

I pulled out the ultrasound picture, and their faces just…changed. It wasn't the happy, excited faces I expected. It was…shock. And then, a little bit of fear.

I wanted them to see it wasn't just an idea. It was a real, living thing. A person. And it wasn't going to be perfect. It was going to be messy and complicated and real.

It was a gamble, I know. It could have gone horribly wrong. But I needed them to understand. I needed them to see that this wasn't just about giving a baby a good home. It was about giving a baby a *life*.

And honestly? It worked. It shook them up. It made them think. And it ultimately led them to be the amazing parents they are.

But yeah, it was a pretty impulsive move. I don't recommend it as a standard parenting strategy. Just…it felt right at the time. And sometimes, you just gotta do what feels right, even if it's a little bit crazy.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark tells me Vanessa isn't home? My initial reaction? Pure, unadulterated panic. Like, a full-body system failure kind of panic.

It wasn't even the "oh no, she's out with friends" panic. It was the "oh. my. god. this is a disaster" panic. Because Mark is, like, the most awkward human being on the planet, and he's *trying* to be cool, and he's failing spectacularly. 

So, my brain immediately jumps to the worst possible conclusion. Like, did he…did he do something? Did he scare her off? Did she realize what a weirdo he is and run screaming? 

I think I just stared at him for a solid five seconds, trying to decipher his face. He was doing that thing where he avoids eye contact and talks really fast. And I'm thinking, "Okay, this is bad. This is *really* bad."

Then I probably said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, well that's just great. That's *exactly* what I wanted to hear." Because that's how I deal with things. Sarcasm is my coping mechanism.

Inside, though? I was freaking out. Because everything was already so messed up, and Vanessa being gone just felt like another sign that my whole life was about to fall apart. It was just…a really bad moment. A really, really bad moment.

Ugh, okay, you want to psychoanalyze me? Fine. It's not like I haven't done enough of that myself.

Look, it wasn't *just* about the commercials, okay? It was about…everything. Mark is a good guy, don't get me wrong. Sweet, earnest, kinda clueless. But he was talking about selling out, about making money doing something he didn't really believe in, and it just…struck a nerve.

I was dealing with a lot at the time. Like, a *lot*. Unexpected pregnancy, trying to figure out my future, dealing with my parents…and suddenly here's Mark, all proud of himself for making a jingle about furniture. It just felt…small.

It felt like he was trying to be something he wasn't. Like he was trying to fit in, to be successful, to be…normal. And I've always been pretty allergic to normal.

Plus, it was a defense mechanism, okay? I was scared. Scared about the baby, scared about giving it up, scared about what everyone thought of me. And making a joke, being sarcastic, it's how I cope. It's how I keep people at arm's length.

It was a jerky thing to say, I admit it. But it was also…honest. I was feeling a lot of things, and I didn't know how to express them any other way.

So yeah, that's why I made the joke. It wasn't about the furniture. It was about everything else. And honestly, I think Mark knew that, even if he didn't say anything. He's a pretty perceptive guy, when he's not busy composing jingles.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a tough one to talk about. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. Mark's a good guy. But it was…weird. Really weird.

He was just…so happy. Like, ridiculously, over-the-top happy. And I get it, he wanted a baby. He and Vanessa had been trying for a while. But it wasn't *his* baby, you know? It was mine. And I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted.

It felt like he was already planning our future, picking out names, talking about nurseries…and I hadn't even decided if I was going to keep it yet. It was like he was skipping a whole bunch of steps.

It made me feel…small. Like my feelings didn't matter as much. Like it was all about what *he* wanted, and not about what was best for me, or for the baby.

I know he didn't mean to make me feel that way. He was just excited. But it was a really stark reminder that this wasn't a fairytale. It wasn't a rom-com. It was real life, and it was messy, and it was complicated.

It made me realize I needed to be really sure about what I wanted, and that I couldn't let anyone else make that decision for me. It was my body, my baby, my life. And I needed to own that.

So, yeah. It made me feel…a lot of things. Mostly confused and a little bit scared. And it definitely made me think a lot harder about everything. It wasn't a bad moment, but it was a really…revealing one.

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a lot. Havenbrooke. Just the name gives me the creeps.

Honestly? It wasn't about being "pro-life" or "pro-choice" or any of that stuff people were yelling about outside. It was about…me. And what *I* wanted. And what felt…right. Or, less wrong, I guess.

At first, it felt like the only option. Like, the sensible thing to do. I was sixteen, for crying out loud! I had school, and college applications, and a life I was trying to figure out. A baby just…didn't fit. It felt terrifying. Like my whole life was going to be derailed.

But then I went to Havenbrooke, and…it was awful. Not the people, exactly. They were trying to be nice, but it felt…weird. Like they were trying to guilt-trip me into something. And the pictures. Oh god, the pictures. They just made everything feel so…real. And scary.

It wasn't that I suddenly wanted to keep the baby. It was that I realized I didn't want *them* telling me what to do. I didn't want to be pressured. I wanted to make my own decision, on my own terms.

It felt like they were trying to take away my choice by making me feel bad about *having* a choice. Does that make sense?

So, yeah. I was freaked out. I was confused. I was angry. And ultimately, I was just…determined to find a different way. A way that felt right for me, and for the baby. Which is how I ended up with Mark and Vanessa.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was *my* decision. And that's what mattered.



It still makes me kinda sick to think about Havenbrooke, though. It just felt…wrong.

Ugh. Okay. This is…awkward. But you asked.

Bleeker and me…it was complicated. He was just…always *there*. Like a really sweet, slightly dorky, reliable golden retriever. He was my friend since, like, forever. We bonded over comic books and music and just generally being awkward teenagers. He was the one person who didn't treat me like I was some weirdo project or something.

For a long time, I didn't even *think* of him as anything more than a friend. He was just…Bleeker. The guy who always had my back. The guy who knew exactly what kind of pizza I liked. The guy who could make me laugh when I wanted to cry.

But then…things started to change. After I found out I was pregnant, everything got weird. I was so messed up and confused, and he was just…solid. He didn't judge me. He didn't freak out. He just listened. And he kept bringing me those little chocolate donuts from the bakery. Seriously, the guy knew me too well.

I think I started to see him differently when he started being really supportive about the adoption. He didn't try to convince me to keep the baby or anything. He just wanted me to be happy. And he was genuinely excited about the couple Mark and Vanessa.

The…intimate part…that happened after I told him about the pregnancy. It wasn't planned. It was just…a moment. I was really vulnerable and scared, and he was just…there. It was kind of a mess, honestly. A lot of awkwardness and nervous laughter.

It wasn't about sex, really. It was about connection. It was about needing someone to hold me and tell me everything was going to be okay. It was about feeling safe and loved when I felt completely lost.

It wasn't a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just…Bleeker being Bleeker. And for a little while, that was exactly what I needed.

It didn't turn into a big relationship, though. We both knew that wasn't what we wanted. We were better as friends. But it was a good thing. It helped me get through a really tough time. And I'll always be grateful to him for that.

Ugh. I need a donut now. This is too much emotional unpacking for one day.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Still bringing that up? It was…a lot. A total mess, honestly. Like, a really big, complicated, life-altering mess.

At first? Panic. Straight-up, full-blown panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not…this. It wasn't exactly how I pictured my junior year going. I mean, I wasn't even sure I *wanted* to be a mom. I was barely an adult myself.

Then there was the awkwardness with Bleeker. He was…sweet. And genuinely freaked out, too. It wasn't like he was trying to ditch me or anything, but we were both just…kids. Trying to figure things out.

And then, after the initial shock wore off, it got…weirdly okay. Not *good*, exactly. But okay. I started thinking about the baby as a person, not just…a problem. And I started to feel this weird protective thing. Like, this little person was depending on me, and I couldn't just…disappear.

But it was still scary. Really scary. I didn't want to ruin my life, or Bleeker's. And I knew I wasn't ready to raise a kid. That's why I chose adoption. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't what I expected, but it felt like the right thing to do.

It was a really confusing time. I was happy and sad and terrified all at the same time. And I was trying to act normal, you know? Like nothing was happening. Which was impossible.

So, how did I feel? Overwhelmed. Scared. Confused. But also…determined. I was going to do what was best for the baby, even if it meant giving him up. And that, honestly, was the hardest part.



Don't get me wrong, it wasn't a fairytale. It was messy and complicated and real. And it changed me. A lot. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. It made me who I am today.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. Still kinda raw, honestly. Telling Bleeker…it was not a graceful moment. Not even a little bit.

I mean, the whole thing was a disaster waiting to happen. I was trying to be all cool and casual, you know? Like, "Oh hey, by the way, I'm having a baby." Like it was no big deal. Like I'd just ordered a pizza or something.

But it wasn't cool. It wasn't casual. It was terrifying. And Bleeker…well, Bleeker is Bleeker. He kinda just froze. Like a deer in headlights. He went all pale and started stammering. It was…not the romantic moment I'd imagined, which, let's be real, I hadn't really imagined *any* romantic moment.

I think the worst part was seeing the look on his face. It wasn't anger, or disappointment, it was just…pure, unadulterated panic. He kept repeating, "Oh my god. Oh my god. Oh my god." Like a broken record.

I tried to be reassuring, but I was freaking out inside too. I was just a kid! I wasn't ready for this. And neither was he.

I think I ended up just blurting out something about adoption and how we could still be friends. Which, in retrospect, was a terrible thing to say. But I was just trying to make it less awful.

It was awkward. Really awkward. We sat in silence for a long time after that. He eventually mumbled something about needing to go practice with the band. And then he just…left.

It wasn't a good day. But it was the first step, I guess. And eventually, we figured things out. Sort of. It was messy, and complicated, and definitely not how I pictured my junior year going. But we got through it. And that's all that matters, right?

Ugh. Don't make me think about it too much. It still stings a little.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not like a simple answer fits, you know? It wasn't, like, a happy-cry-at-the-hospital kind of thing. It was… complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…panic. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not… this. And Paul? He was sweet, but he was…Paul. Not exactly equipped to raise a kid.

Then, after the initial freak-out, it was a lot of thinking. And a lot of talking to Vanessa and Mark. They were amazing, honestly. They didn't judge me, they just… listened. And they helped me realize that I wasn't ready. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my dreams, to be a mom. Not yet.

It didn't make it easy, though. It was still really, really hard. Knowing that I was carrying a little person, and that I was going to have to give them up… it felt like ripping a piece of myself away.

But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. Vanessa and Mark were amazing people. They were stable, loving, and they were *excited* to be parents. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't.

When I finally met them, and we talked about everything… it felt… okay. Not perfect, but okay. It was like, I was choosing a family for my baby, not just giving them away.

After the birth… that was the hardest part. Holding her, knowing I wouldn't be taking her home. It was heartbreaking. But I knew I was doing it for her.

It still stings sometimes, you know? I think about her. I wonder what she's like. But I also know that she's loved, and she's safe, and she has a good life. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't what I planned, but it was… my plan. And I stand by it. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the right thing. And honestly? It made me who I am today. A little bit stronger, a little bit wiser, and a whole lot more grateful.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know my musical tastes? It's…complicated. My dad's a total classic rock guy, which is fine, I guess. But it's kinda predictable. I need stuff with a little more…edge.

I'm really into The Moldy Peaches. They're just…real. Like, super honest and kinda weird. Kimya Dawson is a genius. It's not music you listen to when you're trying to impress people, you know? It's music you listen to when you're just…feeling stuff.

I also like Belle and Sebastian. They're kinda twee, I guess, but they're really good at capturing that awkward, teenage feeling. And they're smart.

Oh, and Death Cab for Cutie. Ben Gibbard is a master of melancholy. Perfect for when you're, like, staring out the window and contemplating the meaning of life. Or, you know, just trying to avoid eye contact with people.

I'm not really into anything super mainstream. Like, no Britney Spears or anything. Too…polished. I like stuff that feels a little rough around the edges. Stuff that feels real.

And I'm always open to suggestions. As long as it's not country. Seriously, no country. That's just…a hard no.

So yeah, The Moldy Peaches, Belle and Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie…that's a pretty good starting point. It's kinda a mix of indie, folk, and a whole lot of feeling sorry for yourself. Which, let's be honest, is pretty much my default setting.

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." Seriously? You're asking *me* about that movie? That's…intense.

Look, I'm not a huge horror buff, okay? I prefer stuff with a little more…subtlety. But Paul, you know, my almost-boyfriend, he's really into that kind of thing. He made me watch it. And it was…a lot.

It's, like, intentionally bad. It's so over-the-top and cheesy and gory that it's almost funny. But also kinda disturbing. It's not scary in a "jump scare" kind of way, it's scary in a "what is even happening?" kind of way.

The special effects are…well, they're not special. They're hilariously awful. And the acting is…enthusiastic, let's say.

Honestly, it's the kind of movie you watch with a group of friends and make fun of. It's a so-bad-it's-good kind of thing.

I wouldn't recommend it if you're easily squeamish. Or if you're looking for a sophisticated horror experience. But if you're in the mood for something completely ridiculous and over-the-top, then yeah, maybe check it out.

Just don't blame me if you have nightmares. And don't tell my dad I watched it. He'd freak.

It's…a movie. That's the best way to describe it. A very, very strange movie.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. I mean, there are way worse things people name their kids. Like, seriously. I once knew a kid named Moonbeam. *Moonbeam*.

But Madison? It's…basic. It was, like, the name of every third girl in middle school. It feels kinda…overdone. Like, you're trying too hard to be popular.

It's not offensively bad, it's just…predictable. It doesn't have any personality. It doesn't make me think of anything specific. It just…is.

I guess if you really like it, go for it. But if you're looking for something a little more unique, a little more…*you*, I'd suggest looking elsewhere. There are a lot of cool names out there. Like, Beatrix. Or Clementine. Or even, like, Ramona. Those have some character.

Madison just feels…safe. And safe is boring.

Don't get me wrong, the kid will probably be perfectly lovely, regardless of her name. But if you want a name that stands out, that says something about who she is, Madison probably isn't it.

Just my two cents. Don't shoot the messenger.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a heavy question. And honestly? It still kinda stings, even after all this time.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever done. People try to make it sound all noble and selfless, and yeah, there's a part of that. But it's also messy and complicated and just…sad.

It's not like I didn't love the baby. I did. I mean, I *do*. But I knew I wasn't ready. I was sixteen, for crying out loud. I had my own life to figure out. I wasn't equipped to give a baby what it needed.

And that's what it came down to, you know? Doing what was best for the baby. Not what was best for me. It wasn't about me.

It's not a decision you make lightly. It's not something you just shrug off. It takes a lot of soul-searching and a lot of tears. And a lot of talking to people who actually know what they're talking about.

It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to feel all the feelings. Because it's a big deal. A really big deal.

But it can also be a beautiful thing. Giving a baby a loving home, a stable life…that's a pretty amazing gift.

It doesn't mean you don't care. It means you care enough to make a hard choice.

Look, I'm not saying it's the right choice for everyone. But for me, it was. And I wouldn't trade it. Even though it still kinda hurts sometimes.

It's just…complicated. Okay? Really, really complicated.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like there's a handbook for this, you know? It's just…a lot. Honestly, most of the time I just try not to think about all of it at once, because my brain would probably explode.

The biggest thing is just…taking it one day at a time. Seriously. If I started thinking about the future, about being a mom, about everything that's going to change, I'd freak out. So I just focus on getting through the day. School, hanging out with Leah, trying to avoid my dad…you know, normal teenage stuff.

It's hard, though. People look at you differently. They treat you like you're suddenly…fragile or something. And the judgment? Oh, the judgment. It's exhausting. I just try to ignore it. Or I make a sarcastic comment. That usually works.

Paul and Vanessa, they've been…surprisingly cool. They're not perfect, but they're trying. And they're helping me figure things out. That makes a huge difference.

And Leah. She's the best. She doesn't treat me like I'm broken or anything. She just…is there. She makes me laugh, she listens to me vent, and she reminds me that I'm still me, even with all this going on.

I guess the biggest challenge is just…growing up, but like, super fast. I feel like I'm skipping a bunch of steps. I'm still trying to figure out who I am, what I want to do with my life, and now I have to figure out how to be a mom too? It's a lot.

But I'm trying. I'm trying to be responsible. I'm trying to make good decisions. And I'm trying to stay true to myself. It's not easy, but I'm doing it.

And honestly? Sometimes, it's kind of empowering. Like, I'm facing something really hard, and I'm not backing down. I'm figuring it out. And that feels pretty good.

So, how do I handle it? I just…do. One day at a time. With a lot of sarcasm, a good friend, and a surprisingly supportive couple. And a whole lot of hope.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the whole thing with being pregnant and giving the baby up was basically a giant lesson in that.

Look, I *like* doing things my way. I like being in control. I like figuring stuff out on my own. It's just…how I'm wired. I don't want to be a burden, you know? I don't want people feeling like they have to take care of me.

But then, you realize you can't do everything alone. Especially when you're, like, growing a human. I needed my dad, even when I was trying to act all tough and independent. And I *definitely* needed Paul and Vanessa. They were the ones who actually, like, listened to me and didn't judge.

It's about realizing that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness. It's a sign of…strength, I guess. It means you're smart enough to know you can't do it all yourself. And it means you trust people enough to let them in.

It's still a struggle, though. I still get this urge to just shut everyone out and handle things on my own. But I'm learning that it's okay to lean on people. It's okay to let them support you. It doesn't mean you're losing your independence. It just means you're being…human.

I think it's about finding a balance. Knowing when to stand on your own two feet and when to ask for a hand. And knowing who to ask. Not everyone deserves your trust.

It's messy. It's complicated. But it's worth it. Because sometimes, the people who help you are the ones who make everything okay. Even when everything feels totally messed up.



Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. I'm still figuring it out myself, honestly.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a fairytale romance, you know? It started out as just…hanging out. He was a sweet guy, a little clueless, but genuinely nice. And good at guitar. That was a plus.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, it was mostly awkward. He was…supportive, in his own Bleeker way. Like, he brought me orange juice and tried to be helpful, but he mostly just looked terrified. He wasn't exactly prepared to be a dad. Neither was I, honestly.

It was hard to talk to him about it, because he got all flustered and couldn't really handle serious conversations. He'd try to make jokes, which weren't always appropriate. It wasn't that he didn't *care*, he just didn't know *how* to care in a way that felt…useful.

As the pregnancy went on, things got a little better. He started to actually listen, and he started to understand that this wasn't just about me. It was about a whole other person. He started practicing his guitar more, saying he wanted to write a song for the baby. It was kinda sweet, actually.

But it was never really a *relationship* relationship. It was more like…a friendship that happened to involve a pregnancy. We were both too young, too messed up, to be good partners. We were just trying to figure things out.

By the time I decided to give the baby up for adoption, he was…okay with it. He wasn't thrilled, but he understood. He knew I was doing what was best for the baby. And he knew that we weren't ready to be parents.

In the end, we just kind of drifted apart. We still talked sometimes, but it wasn't the same. It was like we'd shared this really intense experience, and then it was over.

It wasn't a bad relationship, it just wasn't…right. He was a good guy, Bleeker. Just not *my* guy. And that's okay. Sometimes, people just aren't meant to be together, even if they make a baby. It's weird, but it's true.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask me about that? It's not like I meticulously planned it out, okay? It's not some deep, symbolic thing.

My dad…he’s a bit of a classic movie buff. And he and my stepmom were going through this whole Greek mythology phase when I was born. They were watching a lot of movies with goddesses and stuff. And apparently, Juno was the goddess of marriage and childbirth. Which, you know, is ironic, considering…everything.

He just thought it sounded pretty. And my stepmom liked it too. So, Juno it was. I didn't really have a say. I was, like, a day old.

Honestly, I always thought it was kinda dorky. It doesn't exactly scream "cool teenager," you know? It's a really…old lady name. But I got used to it. And it's me.

So, yeah. That's the story. It's not some grand statement about my destiny or anything. It's just a name my dad picked because he thought it sounded nice. Don't overthink it. It's just a name.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. Like, a lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark weren't exactly overflowing with joy when I told them. They were…polite. And trying to be supportive. But it wasn't exactly a party.

So when she said she was *relieved* to see the ultrasound photo? That it wasn't, like, a monster or something? It just…hit different. It was like, she wasn't excited about *me* having a baby. She was just relieved it looked normal.

It made me feel like…a vessel. Like I was just a way for them to have a baby, and not a person with feelings and stuff. Which, I guess, is kinda true, but still. It's not a great feeling.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I just kinda shrugged and said something sarcastic. But inside, I was just…deflated. It made me realize how much they wanted this baby, and how little they actually cared about *me*.

It also made me think about how weird the whole situation was. Like, here I am, a teenager, giving a married couple a baby. It's not exactly a Hallmark movie.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me even more determined to find the right family for this kid. A family that would love him or her unconditionally, and not just be relieved that the ultrasound looked okay.

It was a messy feeling. A mix of sadness, anger, and just…confusion. But it also made me stronger, I guess. It made me realize I needed to do this for myself, and for the baby, and not for anyone else.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa's mom. Brenda. Yeah, that was…a moment. A *very* long moment. It was like being cornered by a very angry, very well-meaning, but ultimately terrifying grizzly bear.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to look small and non-threatening. And talk really fast. It's a defense mechanism. I figured if I just rattled off enough information, she'd eventually run out of steam.

I think the first thing I said was, like, "Hi! I'm Juno! I'm…here about the baby!" Which, in retrospect, was probably not the smoothest opening line. But it was honest.

Then I launched into a whole explanation about Paul, and Vanessa, and the adoption plan, and how we were just trying to be responsible. I think I used the word "responsible" like, five times. It felt important.

She was mostly just…disappointed. And worried. And really, really loud. She kept asking me if I was "okay," which was weird. Like, what did she think was going to happen to me? I wasn't the one carrying a baby!

I think what finally calmed her down – a little bit – was when I admitted I was scared too. I told her I didn't know what I was doing, and that I was just trying to make the best decision for everyone involved.

And then Vanessa chimed in and was all, "Mom, she's a good person!" Which helped. A lot.

It was still awkward for a while. She kept offering me cookies, which I politely declined. I was too stressed to eat.

But eventually, she came around. She realized I wasn't some delinquent trying to take advantage of Vanessa. I was just…a girl who made a mistake and was trying to do the right thing.

It was a rough afternoon, though. Definitely one for the books. And I learned a valuable lesson: never underestimate the power of a mother's rage. Seriously. It's a force of nature.

Ugh. Okay. That's…still a tough question. Even now. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, totally giving the baby away!" It was way more complicated than that.

Honestly? I was scared. Really scared. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a whole human being. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. I could barely keep my grades up, how was I supposed to be a mom?

And it wasn't just me. My parents…they were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to help. They're…well, they're my parents. They love me, but they're not exactly known for their practicality.

But the biggest thing was…I wanted the baby to have a good life. A *really* good life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to it. Not right then. Not with my life the way it was.

Mark, the dad…he wasn't exactly stepping up. He was a nice guy, but he was…lost. He had his own stuff going on. He wasn't ready to be a father.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And I met Vanessa and Mark, the couple who ended up adopting the baby. And they were…amazing. They were stable, loving, and they had a beautiful home. They were everything I wanted for the baby.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. But I knew it was the right one. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

It doesn't mean I didn't love it. I did. I do. But love isn't always enough. Sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I try to focus on the fact that the baby is happy and loved. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the lab partner thing? It's a sensitive topic, alright?

Look, it's not that I *wanted* to be a deadbeat. It's just...biology wasn't exactly my forte. Like, at all. All those diagrams of reproductive systems? Traumatic. And Paul? He was so…enthusiastic. Like, *way* too enthusiastic about fetal pigs. It was unsettling.

I tried, okay? I really did. But I got distracted. Easily. There was a really good mix on my iPod, and I was trying to perfect my eyeliner, and then I started thinking about, you know, everything else that was going on in my life. Which was a lot.

And honestly, Paul was a bit of a know-it-all. He kept correcting my observations and explaining things like I was five. It was annoying.

So, yeah, I didn't exactly pull my weight. I mostly just stood there and looked vaguely interested. I offered moral support. That counts for something, right?

It's not like I'm a bad person. I just have…priorities. And fetal pigs weren't high on the list.

Don't judge me. It was a stressful time. And honestly, I think I handled it with a surprising amount of grace, considering.

Ugh. Seriously? They're bickering *during* lab? Like, are they trying to get expelled? This is why I prefer to work alone. People are the worst.

Okay, okay, deep breaths. If I *had* to get involved – which, honestly, I'd try to avoid – I'd probably just roll my eyes and say something like, "Guys, seriously? We're dissecting a frog, not negotiating a peace treaty. Can we maybe focus on the actual science for, like, five minutes?"

Then I'd probably give them both a look that says, "I'm judging you so hard right now."

If they didn't shut up, I'd probably just grab my lab notebook and move to another table. I'm not a mediator. I'm a survivor. And sometimes, survival means avoiding drama.

Honestly, it's probably something stupid. He probably thinks she's not taking it seriously, and she probably thinks he's being a know-it-all. It's always the same.

I'd just want to get the lab done and get out of there. I have more important things to worry about, like, you know, a baby. And whether or not Paul is going to show up with pizza. That's a much more pressing concern than their little squabble.

Seriously, though. Get it together, people. It's a frog.

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes) Okay, look. It's not a "hasty" abortion. It's…a considered one. And it's not like I *want* to, okay? It's just…complicated.

It's not about not wanting the baby. It's about…everything else. I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being.

Paul, he's…Paul. Sweet, but not exactly ready to be a dad. And my parents? They're great, but this is…a lot. It's going to change everything.

And honestly? I have plans. I want to go to college. I want to see the world. I want to…be me, you know? And I don't think I can do all that with a baby right now.

Mark, the dad, he's…well, he's not exactly stepping up. He's a senior, focused on his music. He's a nice guy, but he's not equipped to be a father.

So, yeah, I'm considering adoption. It's not the easy way out. It's actually really hard. But it feels like the right thing to do. For me, for the baby, for everyone involved.

It's not something I'm taking lightly. I've been thinking about it a lot. It's just…it's a really big decision. And it's kind of terrifying.

So, don't judge me, okay? It's my life, and I'm trying to do what I think is best. It's not about being irresponsible. It's about being realistic. And maybe a little bit selfish. But isn't everyone a little bit selfish sometimes?

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Boone's*? It's a valid question, I guess. People need to know.

Look, I'm not a huge drinker, okay? But when you're, like, sixteen and trying to look cool, and Paul's older brother is offering you stuff, you gotta pick something. And the Snow Peak Peach? It's just…different.

It's not trying too hard, you know? Like, the other flavors are all super sweet and fake-tasting. But the Peach? It's subtle. It's got a little bit of tang. It's like a grown-up juice box.

And the color is really pretty. It's this pale pink, almost like a sunset. It just feels…right.

Plus, it doesn't taste like regret the next morning. Well, not *as* much regret.

Honestly, it's probably just nostalgia. It reminds me of that whole messy time with Paul and the baby. But it's a good memory, even if it was complicated.

So yeah, Snow Peak Peach. It's the best. Don't judge me. It's a sophisticated choice. For a sixteen-year-old trying to navigate life, anyway.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know why everyone's all weirded out about the whole baby thing? It's…complicated. And honestly, kinda annoying.

It's not like I *planned* this, okay? It was a one-time thing with Paulie Bleeker, and now here I am, pregnant. And people just don't know how to react.

My parents, they're trying to be supportive, but you can tell they're freaked out. My dad keeps making awkward jokes, and my mom just cries a lot. They wanted me to go to Princeton, not…have a baby.

And then there's the whole school thing. Everyone's whispering and staring. It's like I'm some kind of zoo exhibit. And Mr. Mundy, my guidance counselor? He's just…confused. He keeps trying to get me to talk about my "future plans," like having a baby isn't a future plan.

I think people are unsure because it doesn't fit their idea of how things are supposed to go. They expect teenagers to be worried about prom and college applications, not…gestation. It's not the "normal" path, and people get uncomfortable when things aren't normal.

And honestly, *I'm* still figuring things out. I'm not keeping the baby. I've decided to give it up for adoption. But that's a really big decision, and it's not something people understand right away. They think I should be sadder, or more scared, or…something.

It's just…a lot. And everyone has an opinion. It's exhausting. I just want people to be cool about it, you know? But I guess that's too much to ask.



It's my body, my decision. And I'm doing what I think is best. But trying to explain that to everyone else is…a whole other level of complicated.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…not a fun conversation. Bren is a good guy, a really good guy, and he was right to be worried. But it's not like he *understood*. It's not like anyone understood, except maybe Paul.

I think I mostly just got defensive. I mean, what was I supposed to say? "Oh yeah, I'm totally falling for a married man, it's a great idea, let's all just be cool with it?" No.

I remember saying something like, "It's complicated, okay? It's not like I'm trying to break up his marriage." Which, looking back, was a really lame thing to say. Like, that makes it okay?

I tried to explain that it wasn't about wanting to *have* him, it was about…I don't even know what it was about. Feeling seen, I guess. Feeling like someone actually *got* me. And Mark, for whatever reason, did. He listened. He didn't judge.

But Bren was right to call me out on it. He said something about how it was unfair to Mark's wife, and how it was probably going to end badly. And I knew he was right. I just didn't want to admit it.

I think I mostly just deflected. I changed the subject. I made a sarcastic comment. I did what I always do when I'm feeling vulnerable. I built a wall.

It was a really awkward car ride. And honestly, it made me think. It made me realize that Bren was a better friend than I deserved. And that maybe, just maybe, I was making a really bad decision.

It didn't change things immediately, obviously. But it planted a seed. And eventually, that seed grew into something that made me realize I needed to get out of that situation.

So, yeah. I didn't handle it well. I was a mess. But Bren was a good friend for calling me out on it. He deserved better than that, and so did Mark's wife.

Ugh, seriously? We're still talking about the slushie? Okay, fine. Look, it was a really bad day, okay? A *really* bad day. Paul was being all weird and distant, and I was just…overwhelmed.

And Mr. Pearl, he was just…sitting there. With his mom's ashes. And he was being all sad and quiet, and it just…felt wrong. Like, too serious. Like he was trying to be all dignified and stuff, but it was just making everything worse.

I don't know. It just popped into my head. It was a stupid impulse. A really, really stupid impulse. I just wanted to…disrupt things. To make him laugh, or at least crack a smile. To remind him that life is messy and weird and sometimes you just gotta embrace the chaos.

It was a blue raspberry slushie, by the way. It seemed appropriate.

I know it was disrespectful. I get that. And I apologized. A lot. But honestly, it kind of worked. He did laugh. And we ended up having a really good conversation.

So yeah, I poured my slushie into the urn. Don't judge me. It was a moment of weakness. And sometimes, moments of weakness lead to unexpected connections.

It's complicated, okay? Just…complicated.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Growing up is hard enough *without* a baby growing inside you. It felt like everything was happening at once. Like, I was still trying to figure out who I was, and suddenly I was responsible for another human being.

Honestly, a lot of it was just…messy. There were days I felt totally overwhelmed and terrified. I mean, I was a kid myself! I didn't know anything about babies or parenting or…life, really.

I think the biggest thing that helped was having people I could lean on. Paul, obviously. He was…a good guy. A little clueless sometimes, but he tried. And my dad. He was surprisingly cool about the whole thing. He didn't judge me, he just…helped.

And then there was Leah. She was my rock. She just listened, and she didn't try to fix things. She just let me be me, even when I was being a total mess.

I also tried to just…keep things normal. I still went to school, I still hung out with my friends, I still listened to The Moldy Peaches. I didn't want the pregnancy to define me. I wanted to still be Juno, even with a baby on the way.

It was hard, though. There were a lot of awkward conversations, a lot of stares, a lot of people offering unsolicited advice. And I had to deal with my own feelings about giving the baby up. That was…really hard.

I think I just took it one day at a time. I focused on what I could control, and I tried not to worry about the things I couldn't. And I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It wasn't perfect, but I got through it. And I think, in the end, it made me a better person. A more mature person. A person who was ready to face whatever life threw at me.

It was…a lot. But I wouldn't trade it. Not really. It made me who I am. And that's something.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense. Like, really eager. It was kinda awkward, honestly.

He was trying *so* hard to be cool, you know? Like, he was wearing Vans and listening to Death Cab for Cutie and trying to talk about music with me. Which was sweet, I guess, but also kinda transparent. He was clearly trying to impress me, and Paul, and it was just…a lot.

He kept asking me about my interests, and then immediately trying to relate to them. Like, I mentioned I liked comic books, and he was all, "Oh, I love comic books! Have you read Watchmen?" And I was like, "Yeah, actually, I have." And he just kinda froze. It was weird.

And he was *really* into the whole "domestic bliss" thing. Like, he was already picturing us having picnics and going to baseball games and decorating a nursery. Which, okay, that's nice, but it was also kinda overwhelming. I hadn't even decided if I was actually going through with the adoption yet!

Paul was way more chill. He just let me be me and didn't try to force anything. Mark was…enthusiastic. To say the least.

I think he was just really excited about becoming a dad. And I get that. But it was a little much for me. I needed someone who was gonna be there for the baby, yeah, but also someone who was gonna let me be a teenager. And Mark was kinda stuck in "Dad Mode" from the get-go.

It wasn't a bad experience, exactly. He was a nice guy. Just…a little too eager for my liking. It made me realize I needed someone who was gonna be a partner, not just a dad. Someone who was gonna get me, you know? And Paul, thankfully, did.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid. Honestly. It was…complicated.

It wasn't like he was being *mean*, exactly. He's just…Bleeker. Clumsy with words, always saying the wrong thing, but with good intentions, I guess. But still.

When he said something about me looking like I was "expanding horizons," or whatever ridiculous phrase he came up with…it just…stung. It wasn't the words themselves, it was the *timing*. It was right after I'd been trying to avoid looking at myself in the mirror, trying to pretend it wasn't happening.

It felt like everyone was suddenly noticing. Like my body wasn't my own anymore. Like it was just this…thing…that was growing.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a sarcastic comment back, something about needing a bigger wardrobe. But inside, I was just…weirdly vulnerable.

It wasn't about him, really. It was about everything. About being pregnant, about giving the baby up, about feeling like my life was completely changing. It was just…a lot.

And Bleeker, bless his heart, just didn't *get* it. He was trying to be supportive, but he didn't understand the messiness of it all. He just saw a growing belly.

So yeah. It wasn't a great moment. It just reminded me that this wasn't going to be easy. And that sometimes, even the people who care about you can say the wrong thing at the wrong time.

Ugh. I need a smoothie.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like there was *one* thing. It was a whole mess of things, all tangled up together. But if I had to pick the hardest part…it wasn't the physical stuff, you know? It wasn't even the people giving me their opinions.

It was the feeling of…disconnect. Like, knowing this little person was growing inside me, and knowing I wasn't going to be the one raising it. It was like loving someone you already knew you had to say goodbye to.

It sounds super cheesy, I know. But it's true. It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting a good life for the baby, and knowing I couldn't give it to them. Not right now, anyway.

And it was hard to explain that to people. They kept asking me if I was sad, and yeah, I was. But it wasn't just sadness. It was…complicated. It was grief for a future I wasn't going to have, and hope for a future the baby *would* have.

And then there was the guilt. Feeling guilty for not being able to be a mom, feeling guilty for choosing adoption, feeling guilty for…everything. It was exhausting.

But the hardest part, I think, was just accepting that I wasn't in control. That I had to trust that Mark and Vanessa would love the baby and give it everything I couldn't. That was the scariest part. Letting go.

It still kinda stings, if I'm being honest. But I know I made the right decision. And that's what matters. It just…doesn't make it easy.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. It was freezing, first of all. And he had this… intense energy. Like, way too much energy for a Tuesday morning.

He was holding a sign with a picture of a baby and yelling about how babies are "miracles" and "gifts from God" and how abortion is "murder." It was… a lot.

But the thing that really stuck with me, the thing he kept repeating, was that every baby has a soul and deserves a chance to live, even if it's a hard life. He said, and I quote, "Every little heartbeat is a life, a precious, innocent life that deserves to be cherished."

It was just…simplistic. Like, yeah, of course babies are precious. But it's not that easy. It's not just about the heartbeat. It's about everything else. It's about being ready, about being able to provide, about wanting a kid in the first place. It's about a whole lot of stuff he clearly hadn't thought about.

It was just… frustrating. He made it sound like it was all so black and white, when it's anything but. And honestly, it felt really judgmental. Like he knew better than me what was right for my life.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me roll my eyes. It was a whole thing.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive this. It was…a lot. Right. So, at the clinic, I ran into Paulie Bleeker. *Paulie*. Of all people.

He was there with his mom, getting checked out for…something. I didn’t ask. It’s none of my business. And honestly, I was trying to be invisible. Like, a ninja. But Paulie, being Paulie, spotted me immediately.

He just…stared. Like a deer in headlights. And then he said, and I quote, “Juno? What are *you* doing here?”

Like he thought I was getting a manicure or something. Honestly.

I just mumbled something about a check-up and tried to walk past him, but he blocked my way. He was all awkward and red-faced and kept fiddling with his hands.

Then he said, and this is the part that really stung, “Are you…sick?”

Sick! Like I was catching the flu or something. Not…you know.

I just glared at him and said, “No, Paulie. I’m not sick. I just…have an appointment.”

He looked confused and then kinda sad. And then he just stepped aside and let me pass. He didn’t say anything else.

It was awful. Just…awful. It was the first time I really realized how much he didn’t know. And how much I wasn’t telling him. It was a really weird moment. And it made me feel even more alone.

Ugh. I need a smoothie. And maybe to pretend that whole thing never happened.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Su-Chin. She's…intense. And she has opinions. About everything.

So, yeah, I mentioned the Adderall thing. It just kinda slipped out, you know? I was trying to explain why Paul was being all…hyper-focused and weirdly productive, and it just came out. Big mistake. Huge.

Her face. Oh. My. God. It was like someone had just told her the earth was flat. Her eyebrows went *way* up, and she got this really pinched look around her mouth. Like she was smelling something bad.

She didn't yell, which was good, because that would have been mortifying. But she launched into this whole lecture about how Adderall is a "crutch" and how people need to "deal with their issues" instead of masking them with drugs. It was a lot.

And then she started talking about how it's "irresponsible" to be pregnant while taking medication, even if it's just Paul taking it. Like, I already know it's not ideal, okay? I'm not an idiot. But it's not like *I'm* taking it!

She kept saying things like, "You need to be a role model!" and "Think about the baby!" which, yeah, I *am* thinking about the baby! That's kinda the whole point!

It was just…a lot of judgment. A lot of unsolicited advice. And a lot of side-eye.

Honestly, it made me feel really defensive. And kinda small. Like I was doing something wrong just by being honest about what was going on.

She eventually calmed down, but the awkwardness lingered for, like, the rest of the day. She kept giving me these little looks, like she was worried I was going to turn into some kind of drug addict.

Ugh. Su-Chin. She means well, I guess. But sometimes she just…doesn't get it.

Ugh, okay, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't one thing, you know? It was the whole vibe. The waiting room was all pastel colors and fake plants, like someone was trying way too hard to make it seem…calming. But it just felt creepy. Like a dentist's office designed by someone who'd never actually been to a dentist.

But mostly, it was the people. All the couples, holding hands and looking all…hopeful. And the way they were looking at me. Like I was some kind of…alien. Like they could *see* what was going on.

And then there was that one lady, knitting. Just…knitting. Like she had all the time in the world. It was so aggressively normal, it was terrifying. It felt like she knew something I didn't.

But the worst part? It was the silence. Everyone was trying to be quiet, respectful, but it just made everything feel heavier. Like the air was thick with…expectations. And fear.

I just kept thinking about what everyone else was there for. And what *I* was there for. And how my life was about to change, whether I wanted it to or not.

It wasn't a jump-scare kind of terrified. It was a slow-burn, creeping-under-your-skin kind of terrified. Like something bad was about to happen, and there was nothing I could do to stop it.

It was just…a really bad waiting room. Seriously. I think I need a tater tot.
