Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been…a while. Look, it's complicated.

Do I still…*think* about him? Yeah, sometimes. He was a good guy. Sweet. A little clueless, maybe, but genuinely good. And he played the guitar, which is always a plus.

But "feelings"? That's a strong word. It wasn't like some epic, sweeping romance, you know? It was…comfortable. Safe. He was a friend, and for a little while, maybe something more.

But I was, like, a mess at the time. Dealing with a lot. And he was…Bleeker. He was happy just being Bleeker. And that's okay. It's good, even. But I needed someone who could handle all my…stuff. And Paul, well, he could.

So, no, I don't think I have *romantic* feelings for Bleeker anymore. It's more like…fondness. A little bit of nostalgia. I hope he's doing okay. I hope he's still playing music.

It's just…we were at different places in our lives. And sometimes, that's just how it goes. It doesn't mean it wasn't real, or that it wasn't important. It just means it wasn't meant to be.

Can we talk about something else now? This is getting weirdly emotional. I need a slice of pizza.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Vanessa's decorating choices. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not that it's *bad*, exactly. It's just...not what I would have pictured. At all.

She went full-on woodland creatures. Like, every surface is covered in owls and foxes and little deer. It looks like a Disney movie threw up in there. And everything is pastel. Pastel everything. It's aggressively cute.

I mean, I appreciate the effort, I guess. She's trying to make it a welcoming space for the baby. But it's a little overwhelming. It feels like the baby's gonna be born with a sugar rush just from being in the room.

Paul keeps saying it's "adorable" and "whimsical," but I think he's just trying to be nice. He's a good guy, but he has zero taste.

I suggested maybe toning it down a little, adding some more neutral colors, but Vanessa just gave me this look. Like, I'm ruining her vision. It's her first baby, she's allowed to go a little crazy, I guess.

Honestly, I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a crippling fear of woodland creatures. Or pastel colors. It's gonna be a weird childhood, that's for sure.

I'm just trying to stay out of it. It's her room, her baby. I'll just bring the practical stuff, like diapers and wipes. And maybe a black and white mobile. For balance.

Ugh. Okay, so people keep asking me about "nesting." It's…intense. Like, suddenly everyone expects you to be all gushy about tiny socks and coordinated wall colors. And honestly? It kinda freaks me out.

It's not that I don't want the baby. It's just…it feels so *permanent*. Like, once you start building a nursery, it's real, real real. And I'm still trying to wrap my head around that.

Paul and Vanessa are super into it. Vanessa's already got a whole Pinterest board dedicated to organic cotton everything. It's cute, I guess. But it also feels…overwhelming. Like, there's so much stuff you *need* to buy. And so much pressure to create this perfect little world for a tiny human.

I'm more of a "let's just get the basics" kind of person. A safe place to sleep, some clothes, and a lot of diapers. That's all it really needs, right? I don't need a themed room with a mobile and a rocking chair and a miniature version of everything.

I guess I'm just not a naturally "nesting" person. I'm more of a "winging it" kind of person. Which, I know, is probably not the best quality in a soon-to-be mom. But hey, I'm trying.

I'm helping a little bit. I picked out a few books. And I'm trying to be supportive of Vanessa's enthusiasm. But mostly, I'm just trying not to get too stressed out about it all.

It's a weird feeling. Like, you're preparing for something huge, but you're also kinda scared of losing your old life. It's a lot to process.

So, yeah. Nesting. It's…a thing. And I'm trying to deal with it. But honestly? I'd rather be listening to The Moldy Peaches.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on those women at the mall. Seriously. It was…a whole thing. Like, a different planet.

It wasn't even the shopping, it was the *way* they shopped. All perfectly coordinated outfits, like they were going to a gala, not just to buy a sweater. And the attitude! Like, they were doing *me* a favor by gracing the store with their presence.

And the kids! Oh my god, the kids. All dressed in miniature versions of their moms' outfits, looking completely miserable. Like, "Please, just let me play with a Lego." It was depressing.

It just felt so…fake. Like, they weren't actually enjoying anything. It was all about appearances and status and having the right brands. It was exhausting just watching them.

I mean, I get wanting to look nice. But it's like, relax. It's just clothes. It's not a personality. And honestly, a little bit of ripped denim and a band t-shirt is way more comfortable.

It made me appreciate Paul and Vanessa even more, you know? They're just…real. They don't care about labels or impressing anyone. They just care about being happy.

So yeah, the well-heeled women at the mall? Not my vibe. At all. I'd rather hang out with people who are comfortable in their own skin, even if their skin is covered in thrift store finds. It's just…more authentic. And less stressful.

Ugh. Okay, deep breaths. It's…a lot to process, still. Honestly? Terrifying. And also…kind of amazing? It's a weird mix.

When I first found out, it was just…panic. Like, my life was already kinda messy, and then BAM, suddenly I'm responsible for another human being. It's not exactly something they teach you in health class.

The changes are…everything. My body, obviously. But also my priorities. I used to be all about music and movies and just, like, figuring out who *I* was. Now, it's about making sure this little person has everything they need. It's a huge shift.

And the responsibilities? Don't even get me started. It's not just about feeding and changing diapers (which, let me tell you, is a whole thing). It's about shaping a person. Teaching them right from wrong. Helping them become a decent human being. That's…a lot of pressure.

I'm not gonna lie, I'm scared I'm gonna mess it up. I'm not exactly a role model. I say what's on my mind, I'm sarcastic, I'm not always the most responsible person. But I'm trying. I'm really trying.

I'm lucky to have Paul and Vanessa. They're gonna be amazing parents. And they're helping me figure things out. But ultimately, it's my decision, and I'm gonna do everything I can to give this baby a good life.

It's not what I expected my life to be like. But sometimes, life throws you curveballs. And sometimes, those curveballs turn out to be…okay. Maybe even good.

It's still scary. But it's also…exciting. And I guess that's enough for now. I'm just gonna take it one day at a time. And try not to overthink things too much. Which, let's be real, is gonna be a challenge.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. It’s not like I’m just picking someone out of a catalog, okay? It’s not about finding the “perfect” parents. It’s about finding the *right* parents. For *this* baby.

It’s just…I want someone who gets it. Someone who isn’t gonna try to mold the kid into something they’re not. Someone who’s okay with a little weirdness. Someone who’s…chill.

Mark and Vanessa, they’re not, like, super-traditional. They don’t have a bunch of expectations. They’re already a little bit outside the box. Vanessa’s a lawyer, but she’s also into pottery. Mark’s a doctor, but he plays in a band. They’re…real.

I’ve met a lot of couples through the agency, and a lot of them seem…intense. Like, they have this whole plan for the kid’s life already mapped out. Piano lessons, soccer practice, Ivy League schools… It just feels…suffocating.

I want this kid to have a chance to be themselves. To figure things out. To make their own mistakes. And I think Mark and Vanessa would let them do that.

It’s not about judging other people. It’s just about what I think is best for the baby. And honestly, it’s also about what I need. I need to know that the kid is going to be loved and accepted for who they are, even if they’re a little bit…different.

It’s not easy, okay? It’s the hardest thing I’ve ever had to do. But I want to make the best decision possible. And right now, that means choosing Mark and Vanessa. They just…feel right.

Ugh. Okay, so, hypothetically speaking, if I decided to…keep the baby. Which, like, is a *huge* if. But if I did… it wouldn’t be all sunshine and daisies, that’s for sure. There’s a whole mountain of stuff I’d have to deal with.

First off, school. I’m a junior. I’m supposed to be thinking about colleges and stuff, not diapers and…well, everything. I’d probably have to drop out, or at least take a really long break. Which means my plans for…whatever I was gonna do with my life…would be totally derailed.

Then there’s the money thing. My dad works construction, and my stepmom’s a nurse. They’re good people, but they’re not exactly rolling in dough. I don’t want to be a burden, and I definitely don’t want my kid to grow up worrying about money all the time.

And then there’s…me. I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out who *I* am. I’m not exactly known for being responsible. I like music and movies and hanging out with my friends. I’m not exactly equipped to be a mom. I mean, I can barely keep my room clean.

Paul, he’s…sweet. But he’s also sixteen. We’re both kids. We’re not ready for this. We’d be struggling, and the baby would be struggling too.

And honestly? I’m scared. Scared of messing it up. Scared of not being a good mom. Scared of losing my own life.

It’s not that I don’t want a kid, exactly. It’s just…now is not the time. I need to finish school, figure out what I want to do with my life, and be a little more…grown up.

It’s a lot to think about. A *lot*. And it’s not a decision I’d take lightly. It’s just…complicated. Really, really complicated.



It's not like I haven't thought about it, okay? It's just...a lot.

Ugh, okay, so you want to revisit *that* conversation? Fine. It wasn't exactly a fun memory.

Leah, being Leah, immediately jumped to the whole "keep it and we'll raise it together" thing. Like it was just *that* simple. She was all, "We can figure it out! We're young, we can make it work!" and started talking about how we could move in with her parents and get jobs.

It was...a lot. And honestly, it was kind of overwhelming. She was picturing this perfect little family, and I was just trying to figure out how to get through the next five minutes without completely falling apart.

She kept saying it was "our baby" and that we had a responsibility to it. Which, yeah, I knew that. But I also knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then, and probably not for a long time.

It wasn't that I didn't care about the baby, it was just...I wasn't equipped to give it the life it deserved. And Leah, bless her heart, just didn't seem to get that. She was all about feelings and instincts, and I was trying to be practical.

It led to a pretty big fight, actually. But eventually, she came around and understood that adoption was the best option for everyone involved. Even if she didn't like it.

Ugh. Okay, look. That was…not my finest moment. And I get why people would be, like, rightfully annoyed by that. It was stupid. And mean. And honestly, I was just trying to deflect.

It was a really weird day, okay? I had just found out…things. Big things. And I was freaking out internally. And those women were just…so *enthusiastic*. About everything. And it was just…a lot.

I know it wasn't cool to make fun of them. It was a really immature way to deal with my own stuff. I was projecting, basically. Taking my anxiety out on people who were just trying to have a good time.

I'm not proud of it. I really wasn't. And I definitely wouldn't do it again. I mean, I *try* not to be a jerk, but sometimes I just…say things. Without thinking. It's a problem.

Paul called me out on it, obviously. He's good at that. And he was right. It was insensitive and unnecessary.

So yeah. I apologize. To those women. And to anyone else who was offended. I was being a total idiot. It was a bad day, and I handled it badly. I'm working on it, okay? I'm trying to be a better person. It's a process.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was…complicated. And honestly, a little mortifying.

Look, Vanessa was being…Vanessa. All enthusiastic and helpful and just generally overwhelming. And I was, like, completely overwhelmed *already*. I mean, I was pregnant, okay? My body was doing things I didn't even know it could do. And Paul was being…Paul. Supportive, but also kinda clueless.

She just…reached out. And I froze. I didn't know what to say. I didn't want to be rude. And honestly, I was kinda numb. It wasn't like I was *excited* about someone touching my belly. It just…happened.

It was a weird moment. A really weird moment. And I definitely regretted it afterwards. It felt…invasive. But I didn't say anything. I just kind of stood there like a deer in headlights.

I guess I just wanted to be polite. And maybe I was a little bit scared to assert myself. I was still figuring things out, you know? Still trying to figure out who I was and what I wanted.

It wasn't a good moment. And I definitely wouldn't let anyone do that again. But it happened. And it's over. Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of tater tots? Or maybe the existential dread of being a teenager? Anything but my belly. Please.

Ugh, seriously? It's like, people see this bump and suddenly I'm invisible, except for the fact that everyone's staring at my stomach. It's weird. It's like I'm a walking, talking bowling ball or something.

It's mostly older people, honestly. They'll just...veer out of the way. Like I'm gonna accidentally roll over their feet or something. And then they give you this look, like, "Oh, you poor thing, you're so *big*." It's not helpful.

And then there are the people who try to be helpful and offer you a seat on the bus. Which is nice, I guess, but I'm not *incapacitated*. I'm just pregnant. I can still walk.

I think they just assume I'm super uncomfortable and about to collapse. Which, okay, sometimes I am. But most of the time, I'm just trying to get from point A to point B without being treated like a fragile porcelain doll.

It's like, I'm still me. I'm still Juno. I just happen to be carrying a tiny human inside me. It doesn't change the fact that I can navigate a crowded hallway without needing a personal escort.

It's a little dehumanizing, honestly. Like I'm just a vessel. But whatever. I just try to ignore it and keep walking. And maybe give them a sarcastic side-eye. That usually works.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. Everyone keeps saying Mark and Vanessa are “wholesome.” And they *are*. Like, ridiculously wholesome. Perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect smiles. It’s…intense.

And that’s kinda the problem. It’s not that they’re bad people, it’s that they’re…too perfect. It feels like they’re picking a baby out of a catalog. Like, “Oh, yes, a baby will complete our perfect life.”

I’m not saying they wouldn’t be good parents. They probably would be. But it feels…sterile. Like the baby is a project, not a person.

Paul and Vanessa, they want a baby to *fix* something. To fill a hole. And I get that, I really do. But I want this baby to be wanted for who it *is*, not for what it represents.

Mark and Vanessa, they’re…safe. And safe is good, right? But it’s also kinda boring. I want this baby to have a little bit of messiness in its life. A little bit of weirdness. A little bit of…me.

I know it sounds selfish. And maybe it is. But I just…I don’t want this baby to be raised in a bubble. I want it to be loved unconditionally, flaws and all. And I’m not sure Mark and Vanessa are equipped to do that. They seem like they need everything to be just so.

It’s not about them being bad people. It’s about them being…too good. And sometimes, too good isn’t good enough. It’s just…weirdly unsettling.

It's like, I want this baby to have a life, not a picture-perfect Instagram feed. Does that make sense? It's just...a feeling. A really strong feeling.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa Loring. Honestly? They're…a lot. Like, a whole *situation*.

Look, Vanessa seems nice enough, I guess. A little…perfect. Like, aggressively perfect. And Mark? He's trying. You can tell he's trying to be a good dad. But he's also kinda clueless. And really into model trains. Which, okay, whatever floats your boat, but it's a little…intense.

They're just…so *together*. You know? Like, sickeningly sweet and always agreeing with each other. It's kinda weirds me out. It's like they're living in a movie. And I'm just…not a movie person. I prefer reality, even when it's messy.

I feel bad for them, though. They really want a baby. And it's kinda sad that they can't have one on their own. But I also think they have this…idealized vision of what a family should be. And I'm not sure I fit into that vision.

I mean, I'm a teenager who got pregnant. I'm not exactly the picture of domestic bliss.

So, yeah. They're okay. I guess. I just…don't really get them. And I'm kinda nervous about them getting too attached. It's complicated. Everything is complicated.



Don't tell them I said that. Seriously. They'd probably knit me a sweater and try to make me drink herbal tea. And I'd rather eat dirt.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Still bringing that up? It's been, like, years. But fine, I'll explain. It's complicated.

Mrs. Bleeker… she's…particular. And she has a very specific vision for her son, Paulie. She wants him to go to Princeton, become a doctor, marry a nice, preppy girl who went to the same private school as him. Basically, the whole nine yards of perfect suburban life.

And I… well, I'm not that. I'm a bit of a mess, okay? I skip school sometimes, I listen to punk rock, I say what's on my mind, and I definitely don't fit into her idea of a "suitable" girlfriend.

She thinks I'm a bad influence on Paulie. She thinks I'm going to distract him from his studies and ruin his future. She's convinced I'm just a phase. She's also not thrilled about the whole… pregnant thing. That definitely didn't help.

She's always making little digs at me, passive-aggressive comments about my clothes or my music. She tries to be polite, but you can tell she thinks I'm beneath Paulie. It's super awkward.

Honestly, I think she's just scared. She wants the best for her son, and she doesn't think I'm good enough for him. But Paulie loves me, and that's what matters. And eventually, she came around… a little. It took a while, and a lot of awkward family dinners, but she eventually realized I wasn't going to ruin her son's life.

But still. She's always watching me. It's creepy.



Don't even get me started on her Christmas decorations. They're aggressively cheerful. It's unsettling.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture moment, you know? It was more…awkward. And a little bit sad.

See, I was avoiding him. Like, actively avoiding him. After…everything. The whole pregnancy thing, the adoption, it was just…a lot. And I needed space. And he was just…*there*. Being Mark. Which is sweet, I guess, but also suffocating.

So, I was sitting in my room, trying to do homework, and it was just…quiet. Too quiet. And I saw the CD case sitting on my desk. He'd left it when he dropped off the…stuff. The baby stuff. It was just sitting there, staring at me.

And I was being a total jerk, honestly. I was trying to prove to myself that I didn't care. That I was fine. So I thought, "Fine. I'll listen to it. It'll be terrible. And then I'll feel justified in ignoring him forever."

But it wasn't terrible. It was…good. Really good. It was all those songs we'd talked about, the ones we'd bonded over. The Moldy Peaches, obviously. And some other stuff I hadn't even heard before.

It was like…he was trying to say something without actually saying it. Like, "I get you. I understand what you're going through." And it was stupid, but it made me feel…less alone.

So, I listened to it. And then I listened to it again. And then I started actually *thinking* about him. And realizing that maybe, just maybe, he wasn't the worst person in the world.

It wasn't the CD itself that made me change my mind. It was what it represented. It was him trying to connect with me, even when I was pushing him away. And that, I guess, was kind of hard to ignore.

Ugh. Don't tell him I said that. It'll go straight to his head.

Ugh. Okay. Almost eight months. It's…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not exactly glamorous, let me tell you. People keep saying I'm "glowing," and I'm pretty sure that's just sweat.

It's mostly just uncomfortable. Everything is uncomfortable. Sitting, standing, lying down, even *thinking* is uncomfortable. I feel like a whale. A very, very tired whale.

And the cravings! Don't even get me started on the cravings. Pickles and ice cream is so cliché, but honestly? Sometimes it's the only thing that hits the spot. Paul just stares at me when I eat it. He doesn't get it.

But it's also…weirdly amazing. Like, there's a tiny human *inside* me. That's insane! And I can feel it moving now, which is both cool and terrifying. It kicks a lot when I'm trying to sleep. Little jerk.

I'm also starting to get, like, nesting instincts. I've been rearranging the furniture and obsessively cleaning. It's a control thing, I think. Like, if I can get everything perfect, then maybe I'll be ready for this.

I'm still scared, obviously. This is a huge responsibility. But I'm also…excited. I think. It's a complicated feeling.

Mostly, I just want it to be over. But also, I don't want it to be over. It's a mess. A big, hormonal, uncomfortable mess. But it's *my* mess. And that's…something.

So yeah. Almost eight months. It's a trip. A really weird, exhausting, and slightly terrifying trip.

Ugh, seriously? This is, like, my *life*. People staring. It's so annoying. I mean, I get it, I'm not exactly blending in. I wear band tees and combat boots and I say what's on my mind, which apparently is a crime against humanity.

But it's not like I'm trying to be noticed, you know? I'm just…being me. And apparently, "being me" is fascinating to some people.

I think it's a combination of things. Maybe it's the whole pregnant-teenager thing. People are always curious, and sometimes they're just plain judgmental. I can see it in their eyes. They're probably thinking, "Oh, look at that poor girl." Or, "What was she thinking?"

And then there's the fact that I'm not exactly…conventional. I don't fit into any of their little boxes. I don't try to. And I think that freaks some people out.

Plus, I'm pretty good at giving people the side-eye. Maybe they're staring because they're afraid I'm going to judge *them*. Which, let's be honest, I probably am.

It's just…exhausting. I wish people would just mind their own business. But they don't. They never do. So I just try to ignore it. Or, you know, give them a really withering look. That usually works.

Honestly, it's probably better to be stared at than to be invisible. At least then you know you're making an impression. Even if it's a bad one.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's…a choice. A *bold* choice.

Look, I'm not saying it's a terrible idea. Katrina's…intense. And Bleek is, well, Bleek. He's a sweet guy, but he's kinda oblivious. They're both definitely on the spectrum of "unique," so I guess there's a certain logic to it. Like attracts like, or something.

But it's also kinda terrifying. Those two together could create a black hole of awkwardness. It'd be like watching a train wreck in slow motion. And I'm pretty sure Katrina would spend the entire night analyzing the structural integrity of the decorations.

Honestly, I just feel bad for whoever has to chaperone. That's gonna be a long night.

I mean, good for Bleek for putting himself out there, I guess. It takes guts to ask someone out, even if that someone is Katrina De Voort. But I'm just saying, I'm not holding my breath for a fairytale ending. It's probably gonna involve a lot of uncomfortable silences and maybe a debate about the merits of different types of duct tape.

It's…a situation. A very Bleek and Katrina-esque situation. And honestly, I'm just here for the drama.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. It's…a lot to unpack, honestly. Before all this happened, I thought I had things pretty figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, and perfectly content just kinda floating through life, observing everyone else. Turns out, I was mostly just avoiding stuff.

This whole pregnancy thing has been…a crash course in growing up. And not the fun kind with, like, learning to drive. More like the kind where you realize you're responsible for another human being and suddenly all your carefully constructed walls feel really flimsy.

I learned I'm way more capable than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I can handle a lot more than I ever gave myself credit for. I mean, I'm carrying a baby! That's kinda insane when you actually think about it.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so determined to do everything myself. But I realized I can't do this alone. I need Paul, I need my dad, I need my friends. And that's not a weakness, it's just…being human.

And maybe the biggest thing I've learned is that it's okay to not have all the answers. I don't know what the future holds. I don't know if I'm making the right decision. But I'm doing the best I can, and that has to be enough.

I used to think defining myself meant being different, being quirky, being…me. But now I'm realizing that defining myself means figuring out what I believe in, what I stand for, and what kind of person I want to be. And that's a work in progress.

It's still scary, don't get me wrong. But it's also…good. It's complicated, messy, and terrifyingly beautiful. And I think, maybe, I'm starting to figure out who I am, even if it's not exactly who I thought I'd be.

So yeah. That's what I've learned. It's a lot. And I'm still learning. But I think I'm okay with that.

Ugh, okay, seriously? It's just… frustrating, you know? Katrina is a genuinely sweet person. Like, a little naive, maybe, but she deserves someone who's gonna be straight with her. And Bleeker? He's…complicated.

He's a good guy, I guess. A little clueless, a little awkward, but he means well. But he's also kinda using her to feel better about himself. He's all, "Oh, I'm so sad about my band, Katrina's so supportive," and it feels… manipulative.

She's clearly into him, and he's just letting her think whatever she wants without actually saying anything. It's like he's enjoying the attention without being willing to commit. And that's just not fair to her.

I've been through enough drama myself to recognize a messed-up situation when I see one. And I don't want to see Katrina get hurt. She's a good friend, and she deserves someone who's gonna treat her with respect and honesty.

It's not my place to tell her what to do, obviously. She has to figure that out for herself. But I can at least point out that something feels off. And maybe, just maybe, she'll see it too.

It's just…ugh. Boys. They're all messes.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so you're finally old enough to go, and suddenly it's...lame? Yeah, I get it. It's a total bait-and-switch.

When you're younger, it's this huge deal. Like, the pinnacle of high school. The movie montage moment. But then you actually get there, and it's just...awkward.

It's like everyone's trying *so* hard to have a good time, that it ends up being the opposite. Everyone's dressed up in these ridiculous outfits, pretending to be something they're not. And the music is always terrible. Seriously, who picks those songs?

And the pressure! The pressure to find a date, the pressure to look perfect, the pressure to have a magical night. It's exhausting. It's like, can't we just chill and be ourselves for once?

Plus, once you're old enough to actually *think* about stuff, you realize it's all kinda manufactured. It's a tradition for the sake of tradition. It doesn't actually mean anything.

It's like, when you're little, you think Santa Claus is real. And then you find out the truth, and it's kinda disappointing. Prom is the same thing. It's a fantasy that doesn't live up to the hype.

Honestly, I'd rather stay home and watch a movie with my friends. Or just, you know, exist. It's way less stressful.

So yeah, prom's not cool anymore once you're old enough to go. It's just...a thing you do. And then you move on.

Ugh, okay. Here we go. It's…not exactly a fun topic, but people always ask. It wasn't like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I was a kid, having a kid. It didn't make a lot of sense.

And my parents…they were supportive, but they weren't exactly thrilled. They were trying to be cool, but I could tell they were scared. And honestly, I was scared too. I didn't want to mess up my life, or the baby's life.

So, I started thinking about adoption. It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. A life I couldn't give it at that point. I wanted it to have parents who were ready, who were financially stable, who had a house and a plan.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were just…normal. They wanted a baby so badly, and they were so excited. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for *a* baby. And I knew they would love it unconditionally.

It was still really hard. Like, the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye was…brutal. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about me. It was about the baby.

I still think about it sometimes. I wonder what it would be like if things were different. But I also know that the baby is happy and loved. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't a selfish decision, even if it felt selfish at times. It was a responsible decision. And it was the best decision I could have made.

It's just…complicated. Okay? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's messy and real and heartbreaking and hopeful all at the same time. And I'm still figuring it all out.

Ugh, okay, so Dad being Dad. It's… frustrating, honestly. Like, yeah, I get it. He's worried. He always worries. It's his thing. But it's also kinda insulting.

It's not like I'm completely clueless, you know? I'm not just handing my baby over to the first people who offer me a slightly nicer minivan. I've been doing a lot of thinking about this, and I've been talking to Vanessa and Mark, and they seem… good. Really good.

But he keeps bringing it up, like I'm some naive idiot who's gonna get swindled. He keeps asking me if they're "really good people" and if they're "financially stable" and if they're gonna "give the baby a good life." Like, duh! That's the whole point!

I know he's just trying to protect me, and I appreciate that, I guess. But it feels like he doesn't trust my judgment. And it feels like he's implying that I don't care enough about the baby to make a good decision. Which is totally not true.

I mean, this is *my* decision. And I'm doing this because I want what's best for the baby. And I think Vanessa and Mark can give the baby a life that I can't.

It's just… annoying. He needs to chill. And maybe stop watching so much true crime. It's clearly messing with his head.

I love my dad, but sometimes he just doesn't get it. And right now, I really wish he would just trust me. It's my life, and my baby, and I'm trying to do the right thing. Is that so hard to understand?

Ugh. Seriously? My dad. Always with the subtle digs. "Not knowing when to say when." Like, oh, I'm sorry, am I inconveniencing your perfectly curated life with my…choices?

It's just…so typical. He thinks because he's all quiet and builds things, he's somehow superior. Like, building a chair is harder than, I don't know, navigating a completely unexpected pregnancy and deciding what's best for everyone involved?

It's not about *not knowing* when to say when. It's about not being afraid to make a decision, even if it's a hard one. It's about taking responsibility for my own life. He just doesn't get that. He wants me to be…smaller. Quieter. More predictable.

And honestly, it's annoying. It's always been annoying. He thinks he's being supportive by being…vaguely disapproving. 

I just rolled my eyes, you know? What else are you gonna do? Argue with him? It'll just turn into a whole thing. Sometimes it's easier to just let him think he's right. It saves a lot of energy.

But yeah, it stung a little. It always does. He just doesn't *see* me, you know? He sees the daughter he *wants* me to be, not the person I actually am.

Whatever. I'll figure it out. I always do. And I definitely know when to say when. I just have my own definition of "when" than he does.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Loring? That place is…a lot. It's like stepping into a Stepford Wives convention. Everything is so…perfect. And beige. And aggressively cheerful. It's unsettling.

It's not that I have anything against people having nice things, okay? It's just…it feels fake. Like everyone is trying *so hard* to be happy and successful and…normal. And it's exhausting to be around.

It's all manicured lawns and matching mailboxes and people who judge you for not having a minivan. Like, chill out, people. It's a house, not a personality.

And the gates? The *gates*! It's like they're trying to keep something out, or keep something in. Probably both. It just feels…isolating. Like they're building a little bubble and pretending the rest of the world doesn't exist.

Mark and Vanessa are nice enough, I guess. But they're…Loring people. They have expectations. And they're really into organic gardening and matching family outfits. It's a whole thing.

Honestly, it makes me appreciate my own slightly chaotic life even more. I mean, my dad's a little weird, and my stepmom's a little…enthusiastic, but at least they're *real*. They're not trying to be something they're not.

So yeah, Loring. It's…fine. But I wouldn't want to live there. It's just too…polished. I prefer a little bit of grit. A little bit of mess. A little bit of *life*. You know?

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? She was…intense. Like, really put-together. And kinda intimidating, honestly. I mean, she had a whole *plan*. A scrapbook. A *scrapbook*, people! Who even *has* scrapbooks anymore? It was like she was auditioning to be a mom, and I was just…this mess.

She was super nice, don't get me wrong. Polite. Asked all the right questions. But it felt…rehearsed. Like she'd been practicing her "compassionate prospective parent" face in the mirror. 

Paul was totally smitten, obviously. He's a sucker for a good plan. And she was definitely organized. Which, after my mom, was a welcome change. But it also felt…a little too perfect. Like she had everything figured out, and I was just a problem to be solved.

I remember thinking she was probably really good at color-coding and making lists. And that she probably owned a lot of floral-print things. Which, no offense to floral prints, but it just wasn't my vibe.

I wasn't trying to be judgy, but it just felt like she was from a different planet. A planet where everything was neat and tidy and everyone had a five-year plan. And I was just…floating around in space, trying not to crash into anything.

It took me a while to see past the perfect exterior, you know? But eventually, I realized she was just scared. And trying her best. Just like everyone else. But those first impressions? Definitely a little overwhelming.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Bleeker. It was…complicated.

Honestly? It was mortifying. Like, intensely mortifying. Here I am, trying to be all cool and independent and sarcastic, and this sweet, awkward kid offers to carry my backpack? It was the opposite of cool. It was…nice. And nice is not a vibe I was going for.

But it wasn't just the niceness of it, it was the *way* he offered. All shy and stumbling over his words, and looking at me like I was, I don't know, a fragile porcelain doll or something. It was embarrassing for both of us.

And it was heavy! That backpack was full of textbooks and art supplies and just…life. So, part of me was like, "Yes, please! My shoulders are killing me!" But the other part of me was like, "No way! I can handle it! I'm a strong, independent woman!"

I think I mumbled something sarcastic back, like, "Oh, you think I can't handle a little weight?" which was a terrible thing to say, now that I think about it. I was just trying to deflect, you know? To make it seem like I didn't need his help.

But secretly? It was kind of sweet. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, he wasn't as clueless as I thought he was. It was a tiny little crack in my armor, and it was…weird.

So yeah, mortifying, awkward, and secretly a little bit nice. That pretty much sums up my feelings about Bleeker in a nutshell. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about that? It's kinda embarrassing to talk about, honestly. But fine.

It wasn't just the comic itself, okay? It was…everything. I was just feeling really lost and gross about myself, you know? Like, I was pregnant and my body was changing and everyone was looking at me differently. And I was just…a mess.

Then I read "Most Fruitful Yuki," and it wasn't about being skinny or perfect or anything. It was about this girl who was just…comfortable in her own skin. She was weird and quirky and didn't care what anyone else thought. And she was *happy*.

And it just…clicked. I realized that being a "fat dork," as you so eloquently put it, wasn't the worst thing in the world. It was just…me. And maybe me was okay. Maybe me was even good.

It wasn't like, suddenly I loved my body or something. It was more like…I stopped hating it so much. I stopped comparing myself to other people. I just started to accept myself for who I was.

And it wasn't just the comic, either. It was the timing. It was everything happening at once. It was realizing that I was about to be a mom, and that I needed to be strong and healthy for my baby. And it was realizing that I deserved to be happy, no matter what my body looked like.

So yeah, "Most Fruitful Yuki" helped me feel less like a fat dork. It helped me feel…more like Juno. And that was a good thing. A really good thing.

Don't judge me, okay? It was a confusing time. And sometimes, all you need is a weird comic book to help you figure things out.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That was…a moment. A really awkward moment. And honestly, it's still kinda bugging me.

Okay, so, Mark was trying to be nice, I guess. He was trying to say I was…strong? Capable? Like, I could handle this whole pregnancy thing, even though I'm, you know, a teenager.

But comparing me to a pregnant superhero? It's just…weird. Like, I'm not saving the world or anything. I'm just trying to figure out how to finish high school and not completely ruin my life.

I think he meant the part about having a secret identity. Like, I'm trying to act normal and pretend everything's fine, but inside I'm totally freaking out. And I guess the whole "unexpected power" thing, too. Like, suddenly I'm responsible for another human being. It's a lot.

But superheroes have, like, superpowers and a clear mission. I just have morning sickness and a lot of complicated feelings.

It was a really clumsy analogy, honestly. And it made me feel like he didn't really *get* what I was going through. Like he was trying to make it seem cool and dramatic when it's just…messy.

I think he was just trying to be supportive in his own dorky way. But yeah. Pregnant superhero. Still weird. I'm definitely not wearing a cape.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. And kinda raw, honestly. People keep asking me about open adoption, like it's some kinda perfect solution. And look, I get it. It sounds nice, on paper. Letting the birth parents stay in the kid’s life, knowing where they’re at…it’s supposed to be better for everyone.

But for me? It just…wasn’t the right fit. And it’s not about being selfish, okay? It’s about what I thought was best for the baby, and for me.

See, with a closed adoption, it’s clean. It’s a fresh start. It allows the adoptive parents – Paul and Vanessa – to be the *parents*. Not just…caretakers with a side of birth mom visits. It allows the kid to grow up without feeling like they’re split between two families. Like they’re not fully belonging to either one.

I know, I know, open adoption is supposed to prevent that. But I just…I couldn’t handle it. The thought of seeing the birth parents regularly, of explaining things, of potentially having them question my parenting…it was too much. I needed to be able to focus on raising the baby, on giving them a stable and loving home, without that extra layer of complication.

It wasn’t about not caring about the birth parents. I did. I do. But I needed to create a clear boundary. I needed to be able to move forward and build a life without constantly looking over my shoulder.

And honestly? It was about me needing to grieve. I needed to be able to process my feelings without having to put on a happy face for the birth parents. It was a messy, complicated situation, and I needed space to heal.

I know a lot of people have had really positive experiences with open adoption. And that’s great. But for me, a closed adoption felt like the most responsible and loving thing to do. It allowed me to give the baby the best possible start in life, without sacrificing my own emotional well-being.

It wasn’t easy. It still isn’t easy. But it was the right choice. For me. And for the baby. And that’s all that really matters.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It's not like I *set out* to have some big, transformative journey, you know? It just…happened. But yeah, looking back, it definitely changed me.

Before all this pregnancy stuff, I was just kinda drifting. I was sarcastic, I hid behind my music and my wit, and I didn't really think about the future. I was just trying to get through high school without being totally embarrassed. I didn't really *know* who I was, I just knew who I wasn't – I wasn't like those other girls, obsessed with prom and popularity.

But then, suddenly, I was facing this huge decision. And it wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person, and what was best for *them*. That forced me to grow up, like, a lot.

I had to deal with my parents, and Paul, and Mark, and all their opinions. And I had to figure out what *I* wanted, not what everyone else thought I should do. It was terrifying, honestly. But it also made me realize I was stronger than I thought.

Finding Mark and Vanessa…that was huge. They weren't perfect, but they were genuinely good people who wanted to give this baby a loving home. And seeing them, seeing how excited they were, made me feel okay with my decision. It wasn't giving up, it was giving the baby the best possible life.

And through it all, I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to not have all the answers. I used to think I had to be tough and independent all the time, but I realized that it's okay to lean on people you trust.

So, yeah, my journey helped me find strength. Not in some grand, heroic way, but in a quiet, everyday kind of way. I learned that I could handle tough situations, that I could make difficult decisions, and that I could be a good person even when things were messy.

I still don't have everything figured out, and I'm still kinda sarcastic. But now, I have a better sense of who I am, and what I believe in. And that's pretty good, I guess. It's a work in progress, but I'm getting there.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up prom? Okay, fine. It was…a moment. A weird, awkward, surprisingly sweet moment.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know, super cliché. But it was Mark's pick. He was all, "It's about finding someone who makes every day feel new," and I was rolling my eyes, but secretly…it kinda fit. 

It wasn't like a graceful, romantic dance or anything. We were both super clumsy and kept stepping on each other's feet. And I was trying not to laugh the whole time. But it was…nice. For a few minutes, everything just felt…okay.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be cynical and sarcastic, not all mushy and sentimental. But yeah. Bright Eyes. "First Day of My Life." Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing I think about, honestly. People always ask me about that. It wasn't an easy decision, okay? It was the hardest one I ever made.

Look, Mark was a good guy. Really. Sweet, kind, a little clueless, but good. And Vanessa…well, Vanessa was…Vanessa. Complicated. But she was stable. She had her life together. She wanted a kid. Mark wanted a kid. They were already a unit, you know? A weird, slightly dysfunctional unit, but a unit nonetheless.

If Mark had left Vanessa, it would have been a disaster. She would have been heartbroken. He would have been lost. And the baby…the baby would have been caught in the middle of all that mess. That's not fair to anyone.

I wasn't trying to save their relationship, okay? That wasn't my place. I was trying to give the baby the best possible life. And that meant giving it two parents who were committed to raising it, even if they weren't perfect.

Vanessa wasn't my first choice, obviously. But she was willing to be a mom. She was willing to give the baby a good home. And Mark…Mark was willing to be a dad. He was scared, but he was willing.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And sometimes, the best thing to do is to let go and trust that things will work out.

It still stings sometimes, thinking about it. But I know I made the right decision. They loved that baby. And that's all that matters.

So yeah, I insisted on them adopting together. It wasn't about fixing their problems. It was about giving that baby a family. And that's what I wanted more than anything.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even get me started. It…sucked. Like, a *lot*. It wasn't even the "not ready" part, exactly. It was the way he said it. All hesitant and quiet, like he was afraid to hurt my feelings, which, newsflash, he totally was.

It felt like…everything I'd been building up in my head, all the plans I'd been making, just kind of crumbled. I mean, I knew it was a possibility, right? I wasn't expecting him to be jumping for joy or anything. But I thought…I thought he'd at least be a little bit more…involved in the decision.

It wasn't about *him* not wanting the baby. It was about him not being ready to be a dad. And that's different. But it still felt like he was checking out. Like he was letting me deal with everything on my own.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be all sarcastic and detached, like, "Oh, well, whatever." But inside, I was just…really sad. And scared. And angry. Mostly angry.

It made me realize that I was doing this mostly for me. And that was okay. It was actually…good. Because I didn't need him to be a dad to want to give this baby up for adoption. I wanted to do it because it was the right thing to do.

But it still stung. It just…stung. It made me realize that sometimes, people aren't who you think they are. And that's just life, I guess. It's messy and complicated and sometimes really disappointing.

So yeah. It sucked. Big time. But I got through it. And honestly? It made me stronger. It made me realize I could handle anything. Even a clueless boyfriend.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about Mark? That's…complicated. He was definitely a project. A really, really weird project.

Honestly, at first, it was just…interesting. Everyone at school had their little cliques, and Mark was just…outside of all of it. He collected vintage records, he built robots, he was just genuinely *himself*, you know? And that was kinda refreshing. Everyone else was so busy trying to be cool, and he didn't even seem to care.

But it was more than just that. He was…kind. Like, genuinely, unassumingly kind. He didn't judge me for anything. He didn't care that I was a sarcastic, cynical teenager with a questionable taste in music. He just…accepted me. And that was a big deal, especially when everything else in my life was kinda falling apart.

He was also funny, in a really dorky way. He didn't try to be funny, he just *was*. And he had this way of looking at the world that was just…different. He saw beauty in things that other people overlooked.

And yeah, his life was weird. Really weird. But it was *his* weird. And he was proud of it. And I guess I kinda liked being a part of that. It was a distraction, for sure. But it was also…nice. To be around someone who wasn't trying to be anyone else.

He didn't try to fix me, or tell me what to do. He just listened. And he offered me a safe space to be myself, even when I didn't really know who that was.

So yeah, I liked being a part of Mark's weird life. He was a good friend. A really good friend. And sometimes, that's all you need. Even when you're dealing with, you know…everything.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark. That guy. Honestly? It's a mess in his head, I can tell. He's trying to be all chill and supportive, which is good, I guess. But underneath all that, he's totally freaking out.

I think he's mostly scared. Like, really scared. He's still figuring out his own life, you know? He's a musician, which is cool, but not exactly a stable career path. He's not exactly prepared to be responsible for a tiny human.

He wants to be a good dad, I know he does. He's got a good heart. But I think he's worried he'll mess it up. He's worried he won't be able to provide for the baby, or that he'll be a terrible father, or that he'll lose his freedom. All the usual stuff, I guess.

He's also probably a little overwhelmed. He didn't exactly plan on this. It's a lot to process. And he's trying to be supportive of *me*, which is sweet, but I think he needs to deal with his own stuff too.

I think he's trying to convince himself he'll be okay. He's putting on a brave face, but I can see through it. He's probably lying awake at night, staring at the ceiling, wondering what he's gotten himself into.

It's gonna be a learning process for both of us, I guess. And I think he'll be a good dad, eventually. He just needs to get over his fear and embrace the chaos. Which, let's be real, is gonna be a lot of chaos.



Don't tell him I said any of this, okay? He'll kill me.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment. Don't judge me.

Look, I was stressed. Like, *super* stressed. I'd just found out I was pregnant, and everything was spinning out of control. I was at Loring's, trying to be supportive of Vanessa, and she was being all…Vanessa. And the bathroom smelled amazing. Like, ridiculously amazing.

It was this really expensive perfume, "Le Fleur," and it just…calmed me down. It smelled like everything was gonna be okay, even though it clearly wasn't. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. I wasn't thinking. I just grabbed it and shoved it in my bag.

I didn't even *want* the perfume. I just wanted to feel…something other than terrified. It was a weird coping mechanism, okay? I wasn't trying to be a thief. I was just trying to survive a really awful day.

And honestly, it wasn't about the perfume itself. It was about feeling like I had some control over something, anything, in my life. It was a dumb move, I know. But I was a mess.

Paul found out, obviously. He was not impressed. But he understood. He always did.

So yeah, that's the story. A stupid, impulsive, stress-induced perfume theft. Don't make a big deal out of it. It's not like I robbed a bank.

Ugh. Okay, that whole Mark and Vanessa situation? It's a mess. A total, predictable mess. Honestly, it was pretty obvious from the start they weren't, like, *compatible* compatible. Not just "we have different hobbies" compatible.

I think Mark wants a divorce because he's…suffocating. Vanessa is *a lot*. She's got this whole perfect life thing going on, and she needs everything to be just so. The house, the garden, the kids, the *everything*. It's exhausting just being *around* her, and I'm not even married to the guy.

He's a chill dude, Mark. He likes things easy. He likes to build stuff in the garage and drink beer and not have to worry about whether the napkins are color-coordinated with the floral arrangements. Vanessa needs a life that looks like it came out of a magazine.

And I think he's just…lonely. Like, he loves his kids, obviously, but he doesn't really *connect* with Vanessa anymore. They don't talk about anything real. It's all about appearances and keeping up the facade.

He probably feels like he's living with a Stepford Wife or something. It's creepy.

Plus, she's kinda controlling. I mean, she's always trying to fix things, even when they don't need fixing. It's like she can't just let people be themselves.

So yeah, I think he wants a divorce because he wants to be happy. He wants to be with someone who accepts him for who he is, not who she wants him to be. It's sad, but it's also kinda…inevitable. Some people just aren't meant to be together, you know? It doesn't mean they're bad people, it just means they're not right for each other.

It's complicated. Life is complicated. And sometimes, the best thing to do is just…move on.

Ugh. Okay, look. That was…complicated. Vanessa is nice, really. And she was being all concerned and motherly, which is sweet, I guess. But it was just…too much.

It wasn't that I didn't *want* to talk about it. It's just that I didn't know *how* to talk about it. Like, how do you explain to someone that you're pregnant and trying to find a family for the baby without completely falling apart? It's not exactly a casual conversation starter.

And Vanessa, she's all sunshine and rainbows and "everything happens for a reason." Which is fine, if you're into that sort of thing. But I was feeling…messy. And vulnerable. And I didn't want her to look at me with pity or judgment.

It was easier to just…escape. To pretend like everything was fine. To go find Paul and just…be.

I'm not good at talking about my feelings. It's a work in progress, okay? And sometimes, the best thing to do is just to remove yourself from the situation before you say something you regret.

So yeah, I rushed out. It was a bad move, I know. But it felt necessary at the time. Don't judge me too harshly. It was a lot to process. And I was just trying to survive.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa still thinks Mark's gonna magically transform into a responsible adult? That's… optimistic. Like, aggressively optimistic.

Look, I get it. She loves him. And she wants this to work. But Mark? He's…Mark. He's a good guy, I guess. But he's also kinda clueless and definitely not ready to change a diaper, let alone raise a human being.

It's not about him being a bad person, it's about him not being *present*. He's still figuring out his own life, and bringing a baby into that mess? That's just… selfish, honestly.

Vanessa is sweet, she really is. But she's letting her heart rule her head. She's building this whole fantasy in her mind about how he'll suddenly grow up and become this amazing dad. And it's just not realistic.

I mean, I'm in a similar situation, right? But at least Paul is actually *trying*. He's scared, yeah, but he's willing to step up. Mark? He's just…avoiding the whole thing.

I feel bad for Vanessa. She deserves someone who's excited about this, someone who's gonna be there for her and the baby. Not someone who needs to "come around."

She needs to stop waiting for him to change and start thinking about what *she* wants. And what's best for the baby. Because a baby deserves a dad who's ready and willing, not one who needs convincing.

It's just… frustrating. People are so complicated. And sometimes, love isn't enough. It just isn't.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want to know my favorite genre of music? It's…complicated. It's not like I have a carefully curated Spotify playlist or anything. But if I *had* to pick, I'd say indie rock.

Don't roll your eyes. It's not just because it's, like, cool or whatever. It's because it feels…real. A lot of the stuff is kinda messy and imperfect, and it doesn't try to be something it's not. It's not all polished and overproduced like a lot of pop music.

And the lyrics are usually pretty honest. They're not afraid to talk about awkward feelings and complicated relationships and just…life. Which, you know, is what I'm dealing with right now.

The Moldy Peaches are definitely up there. They're just…weird and wonderful. And Bright Eyes, too. They're kinda depressing, but in a good way. Like, they get it.

I guess I just like music that feels authentic. Music that makes me think and feel things. And music that doesn't take itself too seriously. Because honestly, life is too short to listen to music that's all about pretending everything's perfect.

So yeah. Indie rock. It's my thing. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know my feelings on pilates and exercise? Honestly? It's…complicated.

Look, I'm not exactly a gym rat, okay? I prefer a good movie and a bag of chips to, like, sweating and straining. But, um, things have changed a little. Being pregnant kinda does a number on your body. And Paul, he's really into the whole "healthy lifestyle" thing. So, I've been…persuaded.

Pilates is…okay. It's not as awful as I thought it would be. It's kinda boring, though. A lot of lying on your back and squeezing things. But it does make my back feel better, which is a plus. And the instructor is nice. She doesn't judge me when I complain.

Exercising in general? It's mostly just annoying. It takes up time I could be spending doing more important things, like listening to The Moldy Peaches or writing sarcastic essays in my head. But I guess it's good for the baby. And for me, I guess. I mean, I don't want to be a giant whale forever.

Paul keeps saying it's about "self-care" and "preparing for motherhood." I think it's about him feeling better about himself. But whatever. I'll do a few squats and some arm circles if it keeps him happy.

It's not my *thing*, okay? I'm more of a "comfortable couch and a good book" kind of girl. But I'm trying. I'm trying to be a responsible adult. And that apparently involves pretending to enjoy pilates.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay, Mark and the guitar. That's…complicated. It's not like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It's more…awkwardly sweet. And revealing.

See, Mark's not exactly the most *expressive* guy. He's nice, and he's a good listener, but he doesn't really *say* what he's thinking. He kind of just…is. And then he started playing guitar. And suddenly, he's pouring all this stuff out through the music.

At first, it was just annoying. Like, I'm trying to have a conversation about, you know, life and impending motherhood, and he's strumming some sad song about lost love. It felt…avoidant. Like he couldn't actually *talk* about things, so he had to write a song about them.

But then I started to listen. Really listen. And the songs weren't about lost love, exactly. They were about…feeling lost. About being scared. About wanting to be a good person. And it was all directed at me, even if he didn't say it outright.

It made me see him differently. It showed me a side of him that he usually keeps hidden. It was vulnerable, and it was…kind of endearing.

It also made me realize I was doing the same thing. I use sarcasm and wit as a shield. It's easier to be funny than to be honest. But Mark's music, it kind of cut through all that. It forced me to confront my own feelings.

So, yeah, his guitar playing…it definitely impacted our relationship. It made us both more open, more honest. It created a connection that went beyond just words. It was a way for us to understand each other without actually having to *say* everything.

It's still awkward sometimes. He'll start playing a song and I'll just stare at him, trying to figure out what he's trying to tell me. But it's a good awkward. It's a real awkward. And it's definitely brought us closer.

It's just…Mark and his guitar. It's a whole thing.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about music? It's…everything, honestly. Like, seriously. It's the only thing that keeps me from completely losing it sometimes.

Look, being pregnant is weird. And unexpected. And kinda terrifying. And everyone has an opinion about what I should do. It's a lot. And sometimes, you just need to shut everything out and just…*feel* something.

That's where music comes in.

It's not about finding songs *about* being pregnant, you know? It's about finding songs that match how I'm *feeling*. If I'm feeling overwhelmed, I'll listen to something quiet and mellow, like Iron & Wine. If I'm feeling angry, I'll crank up The Clash. If I'm just feeling…sad, I'll put on The Moldy Peaches and cry it out.

It's like, music understands me in a way that people don't. It doesn't judge me. It doesn't tell me what I should do. It just…is.

Paul makes me mix CDs, which is kinda sweet, even if he doesn't always get my taste. And listening to them, it's like he's saying, "I get it. This is hard. But you're not alone."

And sometimes, when I'm feeling really scared about the future, I'll listen to something hopeful, like Regina Spektor. It reminds me that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still beauty in the world.

It's just…a way to process everything. A way to feel less alone. A way to remember that even though my life is changing, I'm still me. And that's important.

So yeah, music helps. A lot. It's my lifeline, basically. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's kinda embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a mess. A really big mess. And honestly, it still kinda stings to think about.

It wasn't about *them*, not really. It was about me. I was freaking out. Everything was happening so fast, and I hadn't even really processed everything with Paul and the baby yet. And then Vanessa and Mark started fighting, and it just…triggered something. It reminded me of my parents, always yelling and being miserable.

I just…panicked. I felt like I was suffocating. Like I needed to get away from all the drama and just breathe. It was stupid, I know. Really stupid. I should have talked to them, explained how I was feeling. But I'm not good at talking about my feelings, okay? It's a work in progress.

I just needed space. I needed to figure out what *I* wanted, without everyone else telling me what to do. I know it hurt them, and I feel terrible about that. I really do. But I was a mess, and I needed to protect myself.

It wasn't a mature decision, and I own that. I was a kid, dealing with a really grown-up situation. I just…cracked.

I eventually went back, obviously. And we talked. It was awkward, and uncomfortable, but we talked. And things got better. But yeah, that was a really bad moment. I still cringe when I think about it.

It just…sometimes things get too much, you know? And you just need to run. Even if it's the wrong thing to do.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…not a good day.

Okay, so, the conflict with Mark and Vanessa…it wasn't about the baby, not really. It was about…everything. About feeling like I was messing up, about being scared, about realizing that this wasn't just some abstract thing anymore. This was a real life, and I was responsible for it.

And then Mark just…laid it all out there. About how he wasn't ready, about how he was scared too. And Vanessa…she was just trying to be supportive, but it came off all wrong. It felt like everyone was talking *at* me, not *to* me.

And then I just…lost it.

I don't even remember exactly what I was sobbing about. It was just…everything. The weight of it all. The fear. The loneliness. The feeling of being completely overwhelmed.

It wasn't a pretty cry. It was ugly and snotty and embarrassing. I was trying to be cool and collected, you know? Like, "I got this, I'm totally fine." But inside, I was falling apart.

It felt like my whole world was crumbling. Like I'd made a huge mistake. Like I wasn't strong enough to do this.

I remember just wanting to disappear. To rewind time and make everything different.

It was…awful. Honestly. It was one of the worst moments of my life.

But…it was also kind of a turning point. Because after I cried it all out, I realized I wasn't alone. And I realized that even though it was scary, I could do this. I *had* to do this.

So yeah. That was how I felt. A mess. A complete and utter mess. And I'm still kinda cringing just thinking about it. Don't tell anyone I admitted that.

Ugh, okay, you want to bring *that* up? Fine. It's a good story, I guess. A little embarrassing, but whatever.

So, Paul, he was being all…Paul. You know? Trying to be deep and meaningful and talk about the future and stuff. And I was just…overwhelmed. I didn't want to talk about adoption and babies and responsibility and all that heavy stuff. I just wanted to eat a burger and pretend everything was normal.

We were at Jiffy Lube, getting his car oil changed, which is already a supremely unromantic setting, by the way. And he was trying to get me to talk about my feelings. And I just…snapped.

I grabbed a pen and wrote on the Jiffy Lube receipt: "Paul and Juno: Future Parents. P.S. I <3 Burger Phone."

It was a total impulse thing. A way to deflect. A way to be sarcastic and avoid the real conversation. The "I <3 Burger Phone" part was just…because I was hungry and it was a funny inside joke.

I handed it to him, and he just stared at it for a minute. Then he started laughing. Like, a really big, genuine laugh. And I laughed too.

It didn't solve anything, obviously. We still had to talk about the adoption. But it broke the tension. It reminded us that we could be silly and have fun together, even when things were hard.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, but it was also…kind of perfect. It was a Juno thing to do. And it worked. For a little while, at least.

Don't judge me. It was a stressful time. And I was really craving a burger.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Honestly? A lot of things. Mostly just a giant, swirling mess of "Oh. My. God. This is happening."

I mean, I knew Vanessa was…intense. But I didn't realize *how* intense. I thought she and Mark were, like, solid. You know? A cute couple. And then she just…completely lost it.

Part of me felt really bad for her. Like, genuinely. It's awful to find out your boyfriend is going to be a dad with someone else. Especially when you're trying to build a life together. But another part of me was just…terrified. Because that was *my* fault. I was the reason she was having that meltdown.

I was mostly just trying to not make eye contact. And trying to look small. And trying to not say anything stupid. Which, let's be real, is a constant struggle for me.

I remember thinking, "This is a disaster. A complete and utter disaster." And then I was worried about the baby. Like, what kind of life would this baby have with parents who were clearly a mess?

And then I felt guilty. Because I was worrying about the baby when Vanessa was the one who was hurting right now.

It was just…a lot. It was a really overwhelming moment. And honestly, I just wanted to disappear. I wanted to rewind time and not have written that note. But you can't, you know? You just have to deal with the fallout.

It was a really good reminder that life is messy and complicated. And that even when you think you're doing the right thing, things can still go horribly wrong.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me cringe. It was not a good day.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…rough.

It wasn't the *asking* exactly, it was the way she asked. Like she was already mourning a kid that wasn't even born yet. And she was all…perfect. Perfect house, perfect husband, perfect life. And I was just…me. A mess.

It felt like she was questioning my decision, like she thought I wasn't capable of doing the right thing. Like I was just being selfish or something. Which, okay, maybe I was a little bit selfish at first. But it wasn't about *not* wanting the baby, it was about knowing I couldn't give it the life it deserved.

I think I just got really defensive. I mean, I'd already made up my mind. I'd spent months thinking about it, talking to Paul, trying to figure things out. And then she just waltzes in and makes me feel like I'm a terrible person for choosing what I thought was best.

It made me feel small, you know? Like my feelings didn't matter. Like I wasn't strong enough to make a hard decision.

I probably came off way more snippy than I intended. I always do. It's a defense mechanism. I just…I needed her to understand. I needed her to see that this wasn't easy for me either.

It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize how much I really *was* going through with it. And how much I needed to be sure of my decision, not just for me, but for the baby and for Vanessa and Mark too.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. But it also made me stronger, I think. It forced me to confront my own feelings and to stand up for what I believed in. Even if it meant being a little bit of a jerk.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. Honestly, I wanted to punch him. Not, like, *actually* punch him, because that would be assault and probably ruin my life even further. But I wanted to. Badly.

It was…awful. I mean, I was already a mess. Trying to figure out what to do with everything, and feeling super awkward around Bleeker, and then *that* happens? It was like someone just kicked me in the stomach. And not the baby stomach, the emotional stomach.

I was so mad. Mad at Vijay for being a total jerk and saying something so unbelievably insensitive. Mad at Bleeker for just…standing there. Like a deer in headlights. And mad at myself for even letting myself get into this situation in the first place.

It felt like everyone was just looking at me, judging me. Like I was some kind of…mistake. And it was just so humiliating. I mean, I knew Bleeker wasn't the father, but having someone else bring it up like that, in front of everyone? It was just…the worst.

I tried to play it cool, you know? Like, "Oh, Vijay's just being Vijay." But inside, I was totally freaking out. It just made everything feel so much more complicated and scary.

It definitely made me question things. Like, was I making the right decision? Was I being selfish? Was I ruining Bleeker's life? It was a really dark moment.

And honestly, it made me realize how little some people actually think before they speak. Vijay just…blurted it out, without even considering how it would make me feel. It was just…thoughtless.

Yeah. It was a really bad night. I needed a lot of chocolate and a really long talk with Paul.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his whole…journey. It was…a lot. A *lot* of awkward.

Okay, so he's all suddenly super into being a "real man" after, like, five minutes of trying to be all sensitive and artistic? It was a complete 180. And the mustache? Don't even get me started. It was…patchy. And sad. Like a caterpillar trying to escape.

My initial reaction was mostly just wanting to crawl into a hole and disappear. It was mortifying. Like, I was already dealing with a whole mess of stuff, and now I had to navigate *this*?

I think I mostly just stared at him for a solid minute, trying to process what was happening. Then I probably said something sarcastic. Probably something along the lines of, "Oh, wow. A mustache. That totally changes everything." Or maybe, "So, growing facial hair automatically makes you a fully-formed human being now?" I tend to deflect with sarcasm. It's a coping mechanism.

Honestly, it felt like he was trying to prove something to himself, and he was doing it in the most ridiculous way possible. It was like he thought a mustache was going to magically fix all his problems.

It was also kind of…sweet, in a weird way. He was trying so hard. But it was also incredibly frustrating. I just wanted him to be himself, whatever that meant, without trying to fit into some outdated idea of masculinity.

I think I eventually just told him to do whatever made him happy, as long as it didn't involve me having to look at the mustache for too long. And then I changed the subject. Because seriously, the mustache. It was a whole thing.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing that up? Okay, fine. It's been, like, years, but I remember. It was mortifying.

The note… the note was for Paul. It was supposed to be a little… encouragement. He was getting all stressed about the adoption and feeling like he wasn't ready to be a dad, and I wanted to remind him why he was awesome.

It said something like, "You're a good egg, Paul. Don't let the pressure get to you. You'll be a great dad. And you smell good."

I know, it's cheesy. But I was trying to be supportive! And the "smell good" part was just… a thing I say. He smells good. Okay?

Vanessa found it when she was looking for a recipe for lemon bars. Lemon bars! Like, couldn't she have looked somewhere else? It was just sitting on the counter, and she read it out loud. It was *so* awkward.

She totally thought I was trying to, like, seduce Paul. Which I wasn't! He was going to be the baby's dad, not my boyfriend! It was just a nice gesture.

It was a whole thing. A really embarrassing thing. Can we please talk about something else now? Like, roller derby or something?

Ugh, okay, so you want to know what was stressing me out about people staying together? It wasn't like, a philosophical thing, okay? It was more…practical. And kinda scary.

See, my parents, they were…not exactly a shining example of marital bliss. They were good people, don't get me wrong. But they were just…different. And they stayed together for *me*. Which, I appreciated, I guess. But it also felt…fake. Like they were doing it out of obligation, not because they actually wanted to be together.

So, I was worried about Paul and Vanessa. They were, like, super into each other, but they were also really young. And I'd seen enough to know that young love doesn't always last. And I didn't want them to stay together just because they felt like they *should*. I wanted them to be happy. Even if that meant not being together.

It was kinda messed up, I know. I was pregnant and trying to find the perfect parents for my baby, and I was also judging someone else's relationship. But I just didn't want my kid to grow up in a house where the parents were pretending to be happy.

I wanted them to really *want* to be together. To choose each other, every day. And if they couldn't do that, then I didn't want them to stay together just for the sake of it. It's complicated, okay? Relationships are complicated. And babies make everything even more complicated.

Basically, I was worried about everyone ending up stuck in a situation they didn't want to be in. And I didn't want my kid to be a product of that.

Ugh, okay, you want to know who loves me, Juno MacGuff, for exactly who I am? It's not like I spend a lot of time thinking about that, you know? But…yeah, there are a few people.

First, obviously, there's **Paulie Bleeker**. He's…well, he's Paulie. He's kinda dorky and awkward, but he's also genuinely sweet and he *gets* me. He doesn't try to change me or tell me what to do. He just…likes me, even when I'm being a total mess. And he's always there, even when I push him away. That's a pretty big deal.

Then there's **Vanessa**. She's my best friend, and she's the one who always keeps it real with me. She doesn't sugarcoat anything, but she always has my back. She knows all my flaws and still thinks I'm awesome. That's a good friend.

And, surprisingly, **Mark and Bren**. My parents. They're…complicated. But they love me, even though I'm not exactly the daughter they expected. They're trying, and I appreciate that. They let me make my own decisions, even when they don't agree with them.

And, honestly, I think **Baby Jesus** kinda loves me too. Not in a religious way, but in a…cosmic way. Like, things are gonna work out, even if I don't know how yet.

It's not about a lot of people loving me, it's about the people who love me for *me*. The real me. The sarcastic, cynical, slightly messed-up me. And that's enough. It really is.

It's just…sometimes it's hard to believe. But they're there. And that's what matters.

Ugh, okay. Deep breaths. It's still kinda weird to even *think* about it, you know? Like, this is actually happening.

So, after the ultrasound… well, things are pretty much set. I've already talked to Mark and Vanessa, and they're still totally on board. They're amazing, honestly. They're gonna be really good parents.

The plan is, after I have the baby, I'm giving him – it's a boy, by the way – to them. They've got the nursery all ready, and they're just…excited. And that makes me feel good, even if it's also kinda sad.

I'm not gonna disappear or anything. I want to be in his life, you know? Like, an aunt or something. I just… I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I've got my own stuff going on, and I need to figure that out first.

It's not what I pictured for myself, obviously. But it feels…right. It feels like the best thing for everyone involved.

So yeah, after the ultrasound, it's just a matter of waiting. And trying not to freak out too much. And maybe eating a lot of cheese fries. Because stress eating is a perfectly valid coping mechanism, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It still stings, honestly. Even after all this time.

People have *opinions*, you know? Everyone does. And a lot of them were…not nice. Like, seriously? It's my life. My body. My decision. But suddenly everyone's an expert on what I should do with it.

My mom tried to be supportive, but even she didn't really *get* it at first. She wanted me to keep it, obviously. But she eventually came around. Paul was amazing, though. He just…listened. And didn't judge. Which was a huge relief.

But then there were the people at school. The whispers. The stares. The assumptions. Like I was just giving a baby away because I was irresponsible or didn't care. It's not like I didn't want a baby, you know? I just wasn't ready. I was sixteen! I had my whole life ahead of me.

It's hard to explain to people who haven't been in that situation. It's not a simple decision. It's the hardest decision I've ever had to make. And it was the right one. For me. And for the baby.

But it still hurts when people judge you. It makes you feel like you're doing something wrong, even when you know you're not.

I try not to let it bother me. I try to focus on the fact that I'm giving this baby a good life. A life that I can't give it right now. But it's hard. It really is.

So, how do I feel about it? I feel…complicated. I feel sad. I feel angry. I feel determined. And I feel like people should just mind their own business.

It's my life, and I'm doing the best I can. And that's all that matters.
