Ugh. Okay, this is…hard to talk about. It's not that I don't trust Mark and Vanessa, okay? They seem really nice. Really…together. Like, Pottery Barn catalog nice. But it's my baby, you know? And it's weird handing over something so…important.

So, yeah, I have some stuff swirling around in my head. It's not like I think they'll be *bad* parents, but…

First off, they're…perfect. And that's kinda scary. Like, they have a perfectly decorated house and a perfectly planned life. I worry about whether they'll be able to handle the messy, unpredictable stuff that comes with a baby. Like, what if the baby cries all night? Or throws up on the beige carpet? Will they freak out?

And they've been trying to have a baby for a long time. I worry that they'll put too much pressure on the baby to be…perfect too. Like, they'll expect it to be a little genius or a star athlete or something. I just want the baby to be happy and normal.

Also, they live in a really nice suburb. It's…different from where I grew up. I worry that the baby won't have the same kind of experiences I did. That it won't be exposed to different kinds of people and ideas.

And honestly? I worry that they won't understand me. That they'll think I'm just some irresponsible teenager who didn't want her baby. I want them to know that I thought about this a lot. That this was a really hard decision. And that I love this baby.

I know it's probably just my anxiety talking. But it's still scary. It's like…sending a piece of my heart off into the world and hoping it's going to be okay.

I just want them to be good parents. That's all I want. And I hope they'll let the baby be…itself. Whatever that ends up being.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? People just…don’t get it, do they? It’s like, my body, my decision, but suddenly everyone’s got an opinion. The ultrasound technician was the worst. All those little faces and then a “Are you *sure* about this?” Like it was a pop quiz.

Honestly? I mostly just shut it down. I perfected the eye roll. It’s a very useful skill.

But it’s hard. It really is. When people try to guilt trip you or make you feel like you’re doing something wrong…it stings. Especially when it’s someone you’re supposed to trust, like a medical professional.

I started having a few stock phrases ready to go. Like, “This is a really personal decision, and I’ve thought about it a lot.” Or, “I’m doing what’s best for both me and the baby.” And if they kept pushing, I’d just say, “I’m not really up for discussing this right now.”

Paul was really good at backing me up, too. He’d just give people *the look*. You know, the one that says, “Don’t mess with her.” It was very effective.

And honestly, I had to remind myself that their opinions didn’t matter. This wasn’t about them. It was about me and the baby and finding the best possible situation.

It’s not easy. It’s messy and complicated and sometimes really, really sad. But you gotta stay strong and remember why you’re doing it. And surround yourself with people who actually support you, not judge you.

It’s my life, and I get to make my own choices. Even if other people don’t understand. And honestly? That’s enough.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a hard one to talk about. It's not like a fireworks display or anything. It's…messy.

It wasn't what I expected, you know? I thought I'd be all, "Awww, a tiny human!" and maybe cry a little. But it was more…weird. Like, staring at a blurry black and white image and trying to wrap my head around the fact that *that* is me. Growing. Inside me.

There was definitely a lot of panic. Like, "Oh my god, this is actually happening. I'm going to be a mom." And a little bit of disgust, if I'm being honest. It's just…biology, you know? Kind of gross.

But underneath all that, there was this…tiny flicker of something else. Something warm. Like, a weird little spark of protectiveness. And a little bit of…hope? I don't know. It was confusing.

It wasn't love, not yet. It was more like…acknowledgement. Like, "Okay, you're in there. And I guess I'm responsible for you now."

It was also really lonely, seeing it. Because Paul wasn't there. And I was just…staring at this little blob, trying to figure out what to do with my life.

It's hard to explain. It wasn't a Hallmark moment. It was just…real. And messy. And a little bit scary. But also…maybe a little bit good. I don't know. I'm still trying to figure it out.

It's like…seeing that ultrasound was the first time I really had to admit that this wasn't just some abstract thing anymore. It was a real, actual baby. And that changed everything.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a *moment*, alright? A very specific moment. And it wasn't just random, okay? It was…symbolic.

Look, Bleeker was…complicated. He was sweet, but also kinda clueless. And I needed him to *notice* me. Like, really notice me. And I figured, a mailbox full of Tic Tacs is pretty hard to ignore. It's a statement.

Plus, he always had those things in his pocket. Like, *always*. It was his thing. So it was a little inside joke, kinda. A way of saying, "Hey, I see you. I notice the little things."

And yeah, maybe it was a little bit passive-aggressive. Okay, fine, it was *totally* passive-aggressive. But I was sixteen and pregnant and freaking out, okay? I wasn't exactly equipped to handle my feelings in a healthy way.

It was a cry for attention disguised as a sugary gesture. Don't judge me. It worked, didn't it? He came over. We talked. It was…a thing.

Honestly, it's embarrassing to even think about now. But it was a pivotal moment in the whole saga. And it's a good story, right? Just…don't tell anyone I admitted that it was mostly about wanting him to notice me. That's my secret. Okay?

Ugh. Okay, that whole Bleeker situation. Still kinda makes my stomach flip, honestly. It was…complicated.

After I, like, actually *told* him how I felt – which, by the way, was the most terrifying thing I’d ever done up to that point, even more terrifying than telling my parents I was pregnant – things definitely shifted. It wasn't a dramatic explosion or anything, thankfully. More like…a slow, awkward thaw.

Before, it was just easy. We were buddies. We played music together, we made each other laugh, we just *were*. There wasn't any pressure. But once I put all that stuff out there, it made everything weird. He was super sweet about it, really. He said he cared about me a lot, but not…*that* way. Which, okay, fair enough.

For a while, it was really hard to be around him. I kept replaying the conversation in my head, wondering if I’d said the wrong thing, if I’d ruined everything. I was convinced he was gonna avoid me, but he didn’t. He kept showing up for band practice, kept making me laugh. He was just…normal. Which, I guess, was a good thing.

It took a while, but eventually, we found a new normal. It wasn't the same as before, obviously. There was always a little bit of awkwardness lingering, a little bit of unspoken stuff. But we learned to navigate it. We learned to be friends again, even though it was a different kind of friendship.

He was incredibly supportive throughout the whole pregnancy and adoption process. He was there for me when I needed him, and he never made me regret telling him how I felt. He just…accepted me, you know? And that meant a lot.

So, yeah, it changed things. But not necessarily for the worse. It just…evolved. It made our friendship stronger, in a weird way. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what I wanted. And it taught me that sometimes, even when things don't go the way you planned, they can still turn out okay.

It was messy, and awkward, and kinda heartbreaking, but it was also…real. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the chalk? It feels like ages ago, honestly. But fine, I'll explain. It wasn't just some random act of teenage rebellion, okay? It was…complicated.

Bleeker, he was…a lot. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And he was *so* eager to be a dad, which, like, okay, good for him, but it was a little intense. He was already picking out names and building a nursery before I even knew if I was keeping the baby.

The chalk message – "Paulie Bleeker is a tool" – was me trying to get through to him. It was a desperate attempt to make him see that this wasn't just about him. It wasn't about him being a hero or getting a gold star for being a supportive boyfriend. It was about *me*. And the baby. And making the right decision for both of us.

I knew he'd be hurt, obviously. But I needed him to understand that I wasn't doing this *for* him. I was doing this because it was the best thing for everyone involved. I needed him to respect my decision, even if he didn't agree with it.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, I admit. But it worked. It got his attention. It forced him to actually *listen* to what I was saying. And it ultimately led to us both realizing that we weren't meant to be parents together.

It was a messy, awkward, teenage kind of thing. But it was important. It was a turning point. And honestly? It was kinda satisfying to write. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. Yeah. That's…a lot. It's weird to even *think* about how much he actually helped, because he's, like, a total dork. But he did. He really did.

Before I even knew I was pregnant, he was just…there. Always offering to walk me home, making me mix CDs (which, okay, were kinda good), just generally being a supportive friend. And then, when everything came out, he didn't freak. He didn't judge. He just…showed up.

It wasn't romantic, not really. It was more like…he was the only person who didn't treat me like a freak show. Everyone else was all, "Oh, poor Juno," or "What are you going to do?" Bleeker just…listened. And he didn't try to fix things. He just let me figure it out.

He drove me to all my appointments, even the really awkward ones. He helped me research adoption agencies. He even tried to learn how to knit, which was hilarious, because he's so clumsy. He just wanted to be helpful, and that meant a lot.

Honestly, I think his quiet support was exactly what I needed. I was already dealing with so much drama with my parents and Paul, and he was just a constant, steady presence. He didn't try to take over or make decisions for me. He just let me be me, and he supported me no matter what.

It made the whole thing…less scary. Knowing I had someone in my corner, someone who wasn't judging me, someone who just wanted me to be okay.

He's a good kid, Bleeker. A little awkward, a little clueless, but a really good kid. And I'm really grateful for his friendship. It definitely made a difference. It made the whole pregnancy, and the adoption, a lot easier to handle.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get a big head.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks me about that. It wasn't, like, a deeply philosophical decision or anything. It was mostly just…avoidance.

Look, the whole situation was already pretty overwhelming, you know? Unexpected pregnancy, giving the baby up for adoption…it was a lot to process. And adding another layer of complexity – figuring out if it was a boy or a girl – just felt like too much.

It wasn't that I didn't care. It's just…it felt more real if I didn't know. Like, if I knew it was a girl, I'd start picturing her life, and getting attached, and then it would be even harder to give her up. Same with a boy.

I figured, let the parents decide what to name it and how to raise it. It's their kid, not mine. I just wanted to give them a healthy baby. The gender didn't really matter.

Plus, it was kinda cool to let it be a surprise for them. A little gift, you know? A little bit of mystery.

Honestly, it was probably a cop-out. I was just trying to protect myself from getting too emotionally invested. But it felt like the right decision at the time. And it was. It just…was.

Don't overthink it, okay? It's just a baby. Boy or girl, it's gonna be okay.

Ugh. Okay. Seriously? That is…a deeply unsettling phrase. "Scary neuter-baby"? Who even *comes up* with that? Paul is gonna be the death of me.

Look, I'm trying to be mature about this whole thing, okay? I'm giving this baby up for adoption, which is a huge decision, and I'm trying to focus on doing what's best for *it*. But the thought of it being…weird? Or different? Or, like, having something medically wrong? It freaks me out.

It's not about being shallow, it's about wanting this kid to have a good life. A normal life. And the idea of it being born with something…off…it just makes me anxious.

I mean, I know it's probably a really small chance. And I know I shouldn't be thinking like this. But it's hard not to. I'm sixteen! I'm not equipped to handle a baby with special needs. And the adoptive parents…would they still want it?

It's just…a lot to process. I'm already dealing with so much. And now I have to worry about this too? It's not fair.

I guess what I'm saying is, yeah, the possibility of having a "scary neuter-baby" is terrifying. And I'm trying to be okay with it, but it's really hard. I just want everything to be okay. For everyone. Even if that means I'm not the one raising this kid.



Don't judge me for thinking this way, okay? It's a scary thought. And I'm allowed to be scared.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. It's not like those cheesy rom-coms where everything is all sunshine and roses. It's more…messy. And real.

At first, he was just…Bleeker. The quiet kid who played guitar and always seemed to be around. Kind of a dork, honestly. But a sweet dork. And he was always *there*. Like, genuinely there, not just pretending to listen when you're talking about something important.

It started with music, I guess. He understood what I liked, and he didn't try to change my taste. He just…got it. And then it was just hanging out, talking about stuff. Stupid stuff, mostly. But it was comfortable.

He's not exactly the most articulate guy. He says a lot with his eyes, which is kinda cute, but also frustrating when you're trying to figure out what he's thinking. And he's definitely not a smooth talker. He's more of a…stumble-over-his-words-and-hope-for-the-best kind of guy.

But that's part of what I like about him. He's genuine. He's not trying to be someone he's not. He's just…Bleeker.

It's not a super dramatic, passionate kind of love. It's more…steady. Like a comfortable pair of shoes. He's someone I can rely on, someone who makes me laugh, and someone who doesn't judge me for being, well, me.

I don't know where it's going, honestly. I'm not really the planning type. But right now, it's good. It's…nice. And that's enough for me.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get all weird.

Ugh, okay. Talking about my family and the whole pregnancy thing is…complicated. It wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie, you know? But they came around. Eventually.

My mom, Bren, she was…a lot. At first, she was just horrified. Like, full-on, dramatic, "my daughter is ruining her life" horrified. She kept trying to get me to, like, get rid of it. Which, okay, I get it. It wasn't exactly planned. But it was *my* decision. And she needed to respect that.

It took her a while, but she eventually started to come around. She started knitting baby stuff, which was…intense. And she actually started being supportive, in her own Bren way. She helped me with appointments and stuff, and she even offered to help with the baby after it was born. Which was a big deal, because Bren isn't exactly known for being warm and fuzzy.

My stepdad, Mac, he was…Mac. He's a quiet guy. He didn't say a lot, but he was always there. He built me a changing table, which was surprisingly thoughtful. And he always made sure I was eating enough. He's a good guy, Mac. Just…not a big talker.

And then there was Sean. My dad. He was…distant. He wasn't really around much when I was growing up, and he wasn't around much during the pregnancy either. He sent a few checks, which was nice, I guess. But it wasn't really about the money. It was about being there. And he wasn't.

But even with all the drama and the awkwardness, they all showed up in their own way. They weren't perfect, but they were my family. And they helped me get through it. They helped me realize that I wasn't alone.

It wasn't easy, but I wouldn't have gotten through it without them. Even Bren and her endless knitting. It was…a lot. But it was also…good. In a weird, messy, complicated way.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I had a neat little five-step plan for dealing with everything. It was more like flailing around and hoping for the best.

Honestly, a lot of it was just…avoidance. I was really good at being sarcastic and deflecting. Making jokes, being snarky, just keeping everything at arm's length. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. If I didn't let myself feel anything, it couldn't hurt, right? Wrong.

But eventually, that stopped working. You can only build walls for so long before you start feeling suffocated.

Paulie helped. A lot. He was just…there. He didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. He just listened. And he didn't judge me for being a mess. That was huge.

And then there was Mark. He was…different. He made me think about things I hadn't even considered before. About what I wanted out of life, about who I was, about what I believed in. He challenged me, which was annoying, but also…good.

I also started writing more. Just journaling, mostly. It was a way to get my thoughts and feelings out without having to actually *talk* about them. It was messy and rambling and probably not very insightful, but it helped.

I think the biggest thing was realizing that it was okay to be confused. It was okay to not have all the answers. It was okay to be scared. Everyone feels that way sometimes. And it was okay to ask for help.

It wasn't about finding myself, exactly. It was about realizing that I was still *becoming* myself. And that was okay too. It's a process. And it's messy. And it's kind of terrifying. But it's also kind of…amazing.

I still don't have it all figured out, obviously. But I'm learning. And I'm trying to be okay with that. And that's all anyone can really do, right?

Ugh, okay, don't make me think too hard about this. It's a serious question. Okay, okay... my favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. Duh.

Seriously, have you *heard* them? They're just...real. No pretense, no trying to be cool, just honest, kinda weird songs about life and feelings. Adam Green and Kimya Dawson? Genius. Pure genius.

They're not trying to be perfect, you know? Their songs are kinda messy and imperfect, and that's what makes them so good. It's like they're just letting you into their brains, and it's kinda awkward and funny and sad all at the same time.

"Anyone Else But You" is, like, the perfect song for when you're feeling totally confused and heartbroken. And "Stephanie Says" is just...beautifully weird.

They don't take themselves too seriously, which I appreciate. And they're not afraid to be vulnerable. It's just...refreshing. In a world full of fake people and manufactured pop stars, The Moldy Peaches are the real deal.

Plus, they're kinda dorky, and I like that. It's good to know that even talented people can be a little bit awkward. It makes them more relatable.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite. Don't judge me.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It's like, everything got turned upside down all at once. One minute I'm just a normal, sarcastic teenager worrying about school and music, and the next I'm…this. Pregnant. And having to actually think about the future, which is something I actively avoided before.

It's hard, okay? Like, really hard. Everyone has an opinion, and everyone thinks they know what's best for me. My mom's trying to be supportive, but she also keeps offering me baby clothes, which is…a lot. And Paul, he's great, but he's also a senior and has his own life to figure out.

And then there's the whole identity thing. I don't even know *who* I am anymore. Am I still just Juno? Or am I "mom" now? It's weird. It's like, I'm trying to figure out who I am *as* a person, and also who I am *as* a future parent. It's a lot of pressure.

Making decisions is the worst. Every choice feels huge and permanent. And I'm constantly second-guessing myself. Like, am I doing the right thing? Am I making a mistake? It's exhausting.

I try to just take things one day at a time, but it's hard when everyone keeps asking me about the future. I just want to finish high school and listen to The Moldy Peaches without having to think about diapers and college funds.

But, you know, I'm trying. I'm figuring it out. It's messy and complicated, but I'm trying to be brave and make the best decisions I can. And I'm learning a lot about myself along the way. Even if it's not the way I expected to learn it.

It's just…a lot. Okay? A whole lot.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It's not exactly something I love to dwell on, but…yeah, it changed everything. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? It wasn't all tearful montages and instant clarity. It was messy and confusing and kinda terrifying.

Before, I thought love was, like, romantic comedies and holding hands and stuff. It was all about *feeling*. And responsibility? That was something my parents talked about when I didn't do my homework.

But then… suddenly, it wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person growing inside me. And that was a different kind of love. It wasn't all butterflies and grand gestures. It was…practical. It was about making sure this kid had everything it needed, even if that meant not being the one to give it to them.

And that's where the responsibility part really hit me. It wasn't just about carrying a baby for nine months. It was about making a plan for its *whole life*. Finding parents who could give it a stable, loving home. That was a huge weight.

Choosing Mark and Vanessa… that wasn't easy. It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because there's no such thing. It was about finding people who were genuinely good, who were ready to love this kid unconditionally. And realizing that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It taught me that love isn't always about possession. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if that means sacrificing your own happiness. And responsibility isn't just about following rules. It's about making hard choices and owning the consequences.

It also made me realize that family isn't just about blood. It's about the people who show up for you, who support you, who love you for who you are. My dad, Paul, Vanessa, Mark… they all became my family in different ways.

So, yeah. It was a really messed up situation, but it made me grow up. It made me see the world in a different way. And it taught me a lot about love and responsibility that I never would have learned otherwise. It wasn't what I expected, but…it was good. It was real. And it made me who I am today.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That's…a loaded question. It's not like a movie scene, you know? It wasn't all swelling music and instant connection. It was…complicated.

Honestly? I was terrified. Like, full-blown panic attack terrified. I'd been so focused on the practical stuff – finding the right parents, making sure everything was okay – that I hadn't really let myself *think* about actually seeing him.

And then there he was. Little Leo. All scrunched up and red and…tiny. And I just…froze. It was like, all the air got sucked out of the room.

I remember thinking, "Oh my god. I *made* that." It was a really weird feeling. Like, I was responsible for this little human being. And I wasn't ready. I wasn't even close to ready.

But then he opened his eyes. And they were these big, dark, serious eyes. And he just…looked at me. And something shifted.

It wasn't instant love, like in the movies. It was more like…a wave of protectiveness. And sadness. And a weird kind of pride.

I held him for a few minutes, and it was…okay. It was really okay. It didn't fix everything, and it didn't make the decision any easier, but it made it feel…right.

I knew I was doing the right thing, giving him a life with Paul and Vanessa. But it still hurt. A lot.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And the most beautiful. And the most terrifying. All at the same time.

So yeah. That's how I felt. It wasn't perfect. It wasn't easy. But it was real. And it was…Leo.

Ugh. Okay, that's…still a tough one to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like I was trying to be cruel or anything. It was just…complicated.

See, Paulie and I, we were…comfortable. We were friends. Good friends. And the thought of messing that up, of changing things, was terrifying. I was sixteen! I hadn't even figured out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. Adding a baby into the mix felt…impossible.

And I was scared he'd freak out. Not because he's a bad guy, he's a really sweet guy. But he's…Paulie. He's a little clueless sometimes. And I didn't want him to feel obligated or pressured or…pity me. I wanted him to want to be involved because *he* wanted to, not because I told him I was pregnant.

I know it sounds selfish. And maybe it was. But I needed time to process everything myself. I needed to figure out what I was going to do before I dragged him into it. I needed to be strong, for both of us.

It wasn't about not trusting him. It was about protecting our friendship. And protecting myself. I was a mess, okay? I was trying to be brave, and sometimes being brave means keeping things to yourself, even when it's the hardest thing to do.

It wasn't the right thing to do, I know that now. But at the time, it felt like the only thing I *could* do. It was a stupid, teenage decision. But it was my decision. And I had to live with it.

And thankfully, he was a really good guy. And he forgave me. Eventually. It took a while. But he did. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, okay, this is still a sore spot, honestly. It's not like I *wanted* him to find out, you know? It just…happened. And it was totally Mark's fault.

So, here's the story. I was trying to be all cool and collected and not freak out about everything. And I definitely wasn't planning on telling Paulie right away. I needed to figure things out myself first.

But Mark, being Mark, is a total blabbermouth. He and I were at a Sonic, getting slushies, and I was venting to him about everything. About the pregnancy test, about the adoption plan, about how scared I was. I thought I was being discreet, but apparently not.

He started asking a lot of questions, and I was trying to be vague, but he's surprisingly perceptive when he wants to be. And then, he saw Paulie walking by. And he just…blurted it out. Right there, in the middle of Sonic.

It was mortifying. Absolutely mortifying. Paulie just stood there, looking completely stunned. And I wanted to disappear into the floor.

Mark apologized later, of course. He said he didn't mean to, that he just got carried away. But honestly, I was furious. It wasn't his secret to tell.

But, looking back, I guess it was kind of a good thing he did. It forced Paulie and me to actually talk about it. And it turned out he was a lot more supportive than I expected.

Still, I wish Mark had kept his mouth shut. Seriously. That guy. He's a good friend, but he can be so clueless sometimes.



It's just…ugh. It was a really awkward moment. And it all could have been avoided if Mark hadn't decided to be a human megaphone.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. And it's not like there was a single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, adoption is the answer!" It was a lot of thinking, and a lot of freaking out, and a lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa.

Honestly, at first, I was just…terrified. I was sixteen. I was a junior. I had plans. Not, like, *grand* plans, but I was gonna go to college, maybe be a journalist, definitely not be a mom. It just wasn't in the cards.

And then there was the whole…life thing. Like, a whole other person depending on me. That's a lot of responsibility. I wasn't ready for that. I don't think anyone is at sixteen.

But abortion…that didn't feel right either. Not for me. I don't judge anyone who chooses that, but it just wasn't something I could do.

So, adoption kind of…emerged as the only option that felt okay. It felt like the most selfless thing to do. Like, this baby deserved parents who were ready and able to give it everything it needed. And I wasn't. Not then.

Vanessa and Paul were amazing. They didn't pressure me either way. They just listened and helped me think through everything. And they helped me find a really great couple, Mark and Vanessa Loring, who were just…perfect. They were so excited and so loving.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye was…brutal. But knowing that the baby was going to a good home, with people who wanted it and could provide for it…that made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a choice. A really hard choice. And choosing what was best for everyone involved. Especially the baby.

And honestly? It made me grow up. A lot. It forced me to think about things I never would have thought about before. And it made me realize that I'm stronger than I thought I was.



It's still…complicated. But I don't regret it. I really don't.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on Bleeker. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't like, a dramatic screaming match or anything. It was worse. It was just…quiet. He just kinda looked at me, and then looked away. And said he wasn't ready. That he didn't think he could be a dad.

And it wasn't even about *me*, you know? It wasn't like he didn't want to be with *me*. He just didn't want to be a dad. Which, okay, fair enough. It's a big responsibility. But still. It stung.

It felt like…everything I'd been doing, all the planning, all the worrying, it was all for nothing. Like I'd built this whole future in my head, and he just…didn't want to be a part of it.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be understanding. I told myself it was the right decision, that the baby deserved a dad who actually *wanted* to be a dad. But inside, I was just…crushed.

It made me question everything. Like, was I doing the right thing giving the baby up for adoption? Was I being selfish? Was I ruining everyone's lives?

It was a really messy time. And honestly, it took me a long time to get over it. But I knew I had to focus on what was best for the baby. And that meant letting Bleeker make his own decision.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. But you know what? I'm a pretty resilient person. I figured it out. And so will the baby. And so did I. Eventually.

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a lot.

Seeing Vanessa with the baby…it was like someone punched me in the gut, but also warmed my insides at the same time. It was weirdly beautiful, and also incredibly painful. Like, a really specific kind of ache.

She looked…a mess. Seriously. Hair all over the place, mismatched socks, a coffee stain on her shirt. Her house looked like a bomb went off. But she was *glowing*. Like, genuinely, ridiculously happy. And the baby…the baby was perfect. All tiny and squishy and smelling like…baby.

And it hit me, you know? Like a ton of bricks. This was it. This was what I wanted for the baby. A real family. A stable home. Someone who was completely, utterly obsessed with it. And Vanessa, despite the chaos, was *that* person.

It wasn't what I pictured, not even close. I thought I'd be…I don't know, more involved. More…needed. But watching her fumble with the diaper, and sing off-key lullabies, and just look at the baby with that goofy, lovesick expression…it was right. It was *so* right.

It was hard, though. Really hard. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. Like, a really important piece. But it also felt like…relief. Like I'd done the right thing. Like I'd given the baby the best possible start.

I just stood there for a minute, trying not to cry. And Vanessa, she noticed me, and she smiled. A real, genuine smile. And she said, "She's perfect, isn't she?"

And I just nodded. Because she was. And Vanessa deserved her. And I deserved…to move on.

It was messy. It was complicated. It was everything I expected and nothing like it at the same time. But it was okay. It was…good. Even if it hurt like hell.

Ugh, okay, don't make me actually *think* about all that. It's still…a thing. But fine, I'll bite.

That song… “Anyone Else But You” by The Moldy Peaches… it's kinda the whole story, isn't it? It's embarrassing to admit, but it totally sums up everything with Bleeker.

See, everyone thought we were this cute, quirky couple. And we *were*, sometimes. But it was also…complicated. He was sweet, and funny, and he liked me for who I was, which was a big deal. But he was also…safe. Too safe.

That song is about wanting someone, needing someone, but also being terrified of actually letting yourself *have* them. It's about being scared of getting hurt, of messing things up. And that was me, totally.

I was so focused on the baby, and doing the right thing, and being responsible, that I didn't really let myself fall for Bleeker. I liked him, I cared about him, but I was always holding back. I was always thinking about what *should* be, instead of what *was*.

The lyrics, "Anyone else but you, would be my dream come true," it's not that I didn't like him. It's that I was scared of the whole thing. Scared of commitment, scared of being a mom, scared of ruining everything. I wanted someone who wouldn't challenge me, someone who wouldn't make me feel things too deeply. Which is, like, a terrible thing to admit.

It's a really sad song, when you actually listen to it. And it's a really sad story, when you actually think about it. We were good together, in a way. But we weren't…right. Not for the long haul.

So yeah, that song. It's the soundtrack to a really messy, confusing, and ultimately heartbreaking chapter of my life. And I still can't listen to it without cringing a little. But it's also…honest. And sometimes, honesty is all you've got.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know why everyone's kinda tiptoeing around the whole baby shower thing? It's not exactly a mystery. It's because, like, the whole situation is…complicated.

I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm not exactly planning a future of diaper changes and PTA meetings. I'm planning on finishing high school and maybe going to college. So, people are understandably weirded out by the idea of celebrating something that feels…premature.

And it's not like I'm *excited* about a baby shower. I mean, it's nice that people want to be supportive, but it feels kinda…wrong. Like they're celebrating something that's not entirely joyful. It's a bittersweet thing, you know? I'm giving a baby a good life, but it's not the life *I* planned.

Plus, my parents are…well, they're my parents. They're trying to be supportive, but they're also kinda freaked out. And Paul and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby, they're awesome, but they're also navigating this whole thing. It's a lot for everyone.

So, yeah, people are unsure. They don't want to offend me, or make things worse. They're trying to be sensitive. It's just…awkward. And honestly, I kinda get it. It's not exactly a typical situation.

I just wish everyone would stop walking on eggshells and just…talk to me. But I guess that's too much to ask. People always have to make things complicated.

Ugh. Okay, Bren. Seriously. It's not like I was, like, having a secret life or something. It's just…Mark was nice. And he had good taste in music. And movies. Okay? It's not a crime to appreciate a good soundtrack.

But I get why she's all bent out of shape. I guess. It's just…she's so *intense* about everything. Like, everything has to be perfectly planned and controlled. And I'm not exactly known for my planning skills.

I think she thinks I was being…naive. Like, I didn't realize Mark was trying to, you know, *get* with me. Which, honestly, I wasn't really thinking about. I was just happy someone was sharing their stuff with me. I wasn't looking for a boyfriend or anything. I had bigger things to worry about, like, you know, a baby.

And I guess she feels like I didn't tell her about it. Which is true. I didn't. Because I didn't think it was a big deal. It wasn't like I was sneaking around or anything. I just didn't want to have a whole conversation about it.

She's just…protective. She wants to make sure I'm okay. And she thinks Mark was taking advantage of me. Which, maybe he was. I don't know. I just wanted to watch a movie and listen to some music. Is that so wrong?

It's just…she always has to be right. And she always has to be in control. And it's exhausting. But I know she means well. She's a good person. She just…overthinks things. A lot.

I probably should have told her. I get that. But honestly, it felt like a small thing. And now it's a whole thing. Ugh. Teenagers.

Ugh. Okay, so you wanna talk about my mom? Fine. It's not like she's wrong, exactly. It's just… frustrating.

She thinks I'm, like, hopelessly naive about relationships. And honestly? She's probably right. I mean, I've had a couple of crushes, a disastrous make-out session with Paulie Bleeker, and that's pretty much it. My experience with romance is limited to movies and overhearing conversations at the diner.

But it's not just that. She and my dad… well, their marriage wasn't exactly a fairytale. It was more like a long, slow unraveling. She's seen a lot of stuff, and she's convinced that all relationships are doomed to end in disappointment.

She thinks I'm all sunshine and rainbows, and that I don't understand the hard work and compromise that goes into making a marriage work. She thinks I'm just looking for a storybook ending, and that I'm going to be crushed when reality hits.

And maybe she's right about that too. But it's still annoying. I'm not a baby. I can think for myself. I can make my own decisions. And I'm trying to be responsible about this whole situation, even if it's, you know, a little bit complicated.

She just… she wants to protect me. She doesn't want me to make the same mistakes she did. But sometimes, it feels like she's not trusting me to figure things out on my own.

It's complicated. Family is complicated. And my mom is… well, she's my mom. She means well. She just has a really pessimistic view of love. And she thinks I'm too young and clueless to understand. Which, okay, maybe I am. A little. But I'm trying.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not exactly easy to talk about. But you asked.

It wasn't like I didn't love the baby, okay? It wasn't that. It was just… I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone being responsible for another human being.

Paul, he was great, but he wasn't exactly equipped to be a dad either. We were kids ourselves. And Mark and Vanessa… they were just… so ready. They *wanted* a baby so badly. They had a beautiful home, a stable life, and they were just… good people.

It felt like the right thing to do. Like, giving the baby the best possible life. A life I couldn't give it at that time. It wasn't about me not wanting to be a mom someday, it was about knowing I wasn't ready *now*.

It was scary, though. Really scary. Letting go. But Vanessa kept saying it wasn't about giving up the baby, it was about making a plan. And she was right. It was about doing what was best for everyone involved.

It wasn't a happy decision, exactly. It was a hard decision. But it was the right one. And I still think about the baby sometimes. I hope they're happy. I hope they know they were loved.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story with a neat little ending. It just… is. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.



It's still a little raw, if you don't mind. So maybe we can talk about something else now? Like, I don't know… the merits of different types of tater tots?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like a multiple choice test, you know? It was messy and complicated and not at all what I expected. But yeah, I learned a lot. Mostly about myself.

I think the biggest thing I learned is that I'm stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I mean, I always thought I was pretty independent and capable, but dealing with all of *this*…it forced me to grow up, fast. I had to make some really hard decisions, and I had to stand by them, even when everyone else was trying to tell me what to do.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I'm usually pretty good at handling things on my own, but I couldn't do this alone. Paul and Vanessa…they were amazing. They really stepped up. And even my dad, surprisingly. I learned that letting people in doesn't make you weak, it makes you human.

And I learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I mean, I still have my sarcastic moments, obviously. But underneath all that, I actually care a lot. About the baby, about finding a good home for him, about doing the right thing.

I also realized I don't have all the answers. And that's okay. It's okay to be confused and scared and unsure of yourself. It's part of being a person.

It was…a weird experience. But it made me think about what I want out of life, and what kind of person I want to be. And I think I'm starting to figure that out. It's still a work in progress, obviously. But I'm getting there.

It wasn't about the baby, really. It was about me. And figuring out who I am, and what I'm capable of. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

Ugh, okay, that's…a good question. It's not like a straight line, you know? It was messy. And weird. And surprisingly…nice.

At first, it was just…awkward. Like, *super* awkward. They were this perfect, put-together couple, and I was…me. A sarcastic, pop-tart-loving teenager who accidentally got pregnant. They were trying to be nice, but it felt…distant. Like I was a project or something. A case study.

Vanessa, she was the one who was trying the hardest, I think. She was always asking me how I was feeling, offering to take me to doctor's appointments, stuff like that. But it felt…forced. Like she was checking boxes. I didn't want pity, you know? I just wanted to be treated like a person.

Mark was quieter. He was nice enough, but he mostly just stayed in the background. I think he was just…overwhelmed. It was a lot for them, too, I guess. They hadn't planned on adopting, and suddenly they were thrown into this whole thing.

But then, things started to shift. We started just…talking. Not about the baby all the time, but about normal stuff. Vanessa found out I liked The Moldy Peaches and started listening to them. Mark and I bonded over our mutual love of old movies.

It wasn't like they became my parents, or anything. That wasn't the point. But they became…friends. People I could trust. People who genuinely cared about me and the baby.

I think the biggest change happened when they started to see me as a person with my own thoughts and feelings, and not just as someone who was giving them a baby. And I started to see them as people with their own struggles and hopes and dreams.

By the end of the process, it was…bittersweet. I was happy for them, and I knew they were going to be amazing parents. But it was also hard to let go. They had become a part of my life, and I was going to miss them.

It wasn't a perfect relationship, but it was real. And it taught me a lot about love, and family, and what it means to make a difficult decision. It was…good. Even if it was also really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not something I think about *all* the time, but it definitely pops up now and then.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I don't regret giving the baby up. That was the right decision. For me, for the baby, for Mark and Vanessa. They were amazing, and they gave that kid a life I couldn't have given her.

But…there are things I wish I'd handled differently. Maybe I was a little too flippant about it sometimes. I used humor as a shield, you know? And maybe I didn't let myself feel all the things I needed to feel. I was so focused on being strong and independent that I kinda shut down.

I wish I'd talked to my dad more. He was…surprisingly supportive, but I still kept a lot from him. And I wish I hadn't been so hard on myself. It was a really complicated situation, and I was just a kid.

I guess what I regret is not letting myself be vulnerable enough. Not letting people in. But that's just…me, I guess. I'm working on it.

It's not about wishing I'd made different choices, it's about wishing I'd been a little kinder to myself during the whole thing. It was a lot to handle, and I did the best I could. And that's gotta be enough, right?

It's just…it's complicated. It always will be. But I'm okay. I really am. And she's okay too. And that's all that matters.

(Sighs, looks down at my hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's not like it just *goes away*, you know?

It was…hard. Really hard. Everyone kept telling me I was doing the right thing, and I knew I was, logically. But knowing something and *feeling* something are two totally different things. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. And it was.

For a long time, I felt…empty. Like there was this huge hole inside me. I was angry, and sad, and confused. I kept replaying everything in my head, wondering if I'd made the right decision.

But then… I started getting letters. And pictures. From Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted her. They were so happy. And she… she was thriving. They gave her a life I just couldn't have provided. A stable home, a loving family, opportunities…

Seeing that… it started to heal things. It didn't erase the pain, but it gave it a purpose. It made me realize that giving her up wasn't about *losing* a baby, it was about *giving* her a life.

It definitely changed me. It made me grow up, faster than I was ready to. It taught me about responsibility, and sacrifice, and the importance of putting someone else's needs before your own.

I think it also made me more… empathetic. I'm more aware of other people's struggles, and more willing to help.

It's still something I think about, all the time. I wonder what she's like, what she's doing. But I know she's loved, and that's all that really matters.

It wasn't easy, and it never will be. But it shaped me into the person I am today. And honestly? I think I'm a better person because of it. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what really matters in life.

(Looks away again, a small, sad smile playing on my lips)

It's complicated. It just… is.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. If I could talk to another girl who found out she was pregnant and was thinking about adoption… I guess I'd say a few things.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. Like, *really* scared. It's okay to cry, to freak out, to not know what to do. It's a huge thing to deal with, and you're allowed to feel all the feelings. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

Second: you are not alone. Even if it feels like it, there are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

And third, and this is the important one: it's okay to choose what's right for *you*. Seriously. There's a lot of pressure, a lot of opinions, a lot of people telling you what you should do. But at the end of the day, it's your body, your life, and your decision.

Adoption isn't giving up. It's choosing a life for your baby that you might not be able to provide right now. It's a selfless act, and it takes a lot of courage. And it doesn't mean you don't love your baby. It means you love them enough to want what's best for them.

It's gonna be hard. There will be days when you're sad, and days when you question your decision. But you're strong. You're stronger than you think. And you'll get through it.

And don't let anyone make you feel ashamed. You're not a bad person. You're just a young woman making a difficult decision. And you deserve to be treated with respect and compassion.

Just…take it one day at a time. And remember that you're not alone. There are people who care about you, and they'll be there for you every step of the way.

And honestly? It's okay to be a little bit messy. Life is messy. Just try to be kind to yourself. That's all you can do.

Ugh, okay, so the whole blog thing? It wasn't exactly my idea, you know? It was Paul. He was all, "You should document this! It'll be good for you to process your feelings!" Like I needed *another* way to process my feelings. As if having a baby wasn't enough.

But honestly? It started as a way to keep my parents updated without having to, like, actually *talk* to them on the phone all the time. They were…a lot. And I figured a blog was a good way to control the narrative, you know? I could say what I wanted, when I wanted.

Then, it kind of took on a life of its own. People started reading it. And then they started commenting. And then…they started relating. 

It was weird. I mean, I wasn't trying to be some inspirational figure or anything. I was just a teenager who accidentally got pregnant and was trying to figure things out. But a lot of people were going through similar stuff, or had gone through it, and they found my blog helpful.

So I kept writing. It was a good outlet. It helped me sort through my thoughts and feelings. And it was kind of nice to know that I wasn't alone.

Plus, it gave me something to do besides obsess over whether or not Mark was going to be a good dad. Which, let me tell you, was a *constant* source of anxiety.

So yeah, that's how it started. A way to avoid phone calls, control the story, and maybe, just maybe, connect with other people who were going through something similar. It wasn't planned, but it ended up being a pretty good thing.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Honestly? The biggest lesson? It wasn't about babies, or adoption, or even Paul Bleeker, as dreamy as he is. It was about…owning your stuff. Like, *really* owning it.

Before all this happened, I was kinda drifting, you know? Just trying to be cool and sarcastic and avoid anything that felt too real. I didn't really think about the future, or what I wanted out of life. I just…was.

But getting pregnant forced me to grow up, like, immediately. I had to make a decision, and it wasn't a fun decision. And then I had to deal with the consequences of that decision. And I had to be honest with myself about what I wanted, even if it wasn't what everyone else expected.

It wasn't about being brave, or selfless, or any of that stuff. It was about taking responsibility for my own life. And realizing that I was the only one who could make the right choices for me.

It sounds kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. I learned that it's okay to be scared, and it's okay to ask for help, but ultimately, you gotta own your own story. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

And also, that Mark was a total weirdo. But that's a separate lesson.

Ugh. Okay. So, you're in that situation. That's…a lot. It totally sucks, honestly. It's not how anyone plans things, you know?

First of all, breathe. Just…breathe. It feels like the world is ending, but it's not. It's just…changed. And that's okay. It's okay to be scared, and confused, and overwhelmed. It's okay to cry. A lot.

Don't let anyone tell you what you *should* do. This is your decision, and yours alone. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they can offer advice, but ultimately, it's up to you.

Think about what *you* want. Really think about it. What's best for you? What's best for the baby? There are options, okay? You can parent, you can adopt, you can…well, you know. And all of them are valid.

Don't be afraid to ask for help. Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Planned Parenthood is a good place to start, too. They can give you information and resources.

And don't feel guilty, no matter what you decide. It's a hard decision, and there's no right or wrong answer. Just do what feels right for *you*.

It's gonna be okay. It really is. It's gonna be hard, and messy, and complicated, but you're stronger than you think. You'll get through this. And you'll figure things out.

Just…don't do it alone. And don't let anyone pressure you. This is your life, and you deserve to make the best decision for yourself.

Seriously. Breathe. You got this. Even if you don't feel like it right now.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all mushy. Thinking about a kid…it's weird. But if I *had* to picture it, if I was actually going through with this whole thing, my ideal vision isn't about them being a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. Honestly, that sounds exhausting.

It's about them being…happy. Truly, genuinely happy. And not the fake, Instagram-filtered kind of happy. The real kind.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them excited to get out of bed in the morning. It doesn't matter what it is – pottery, coding, competitive bird watching, I don't care. As long as it makes *them* tick.

I want them to be kind. Like, genuinely kind to people, even the ones who are annoying or different. The world needs more kindness, seriously.

I want them to be independent. To think for themselves and not just follow the crowd. To question everything and not be afraid to stand up for what they believe in.

I want them to be resilient. Life is gonna throw curveballs, and I want them to be able to handle it. To pick themselves up when they fall down and keep going.

And I want them to know that it's okay to be weird. It's okay to be different. It's okay to not fit in. In fact, it's kinda awesome.

I don't want to push them into anything. I just want to support them and give them the tools they need to be the best version of themselves.

Basically, I want them to be a good person who's happy and fulfilled. Is that too much to ask? Probably. But hey, a girl can dream, right?

And honestly, if they just avoid getting pregnant in high school, I'll consider it a win. Just sayin'.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People think we're just…dumb. Like, we didn't think this through, or we're just irresponsible kids playing house. That's the biggest one, and it's *so* annoying.

It's not like I woke up one morning and was like, "Oh, cool, a baby! That seems easy!" It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes things happen. And just because I'm young doesn't mean I'm incapable of making a difficult decision, or of being a good mom.

People assume we're all just ruining our lives, and that's just not true. It changes things, yeah. It's hard. But it doesn't mean my life is *over*. It means my life is different. And I'm still a person, with dreams and goals and stuff. 

We're not all tragic cases. We're just…people. Trying to figure things out. And we deserve a little bit of respect, you know? And maybe a little less judgment. It's not helpful. It just makes things harder.

So yeah, that's it. We're not dumb. We're just…young moms. And we're doing the best we can.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? It wasn't like, a simple decision. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

Honestly? I was scared. Really scared. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. I wasn't exactly equipped to be a mom.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted that kid to have a good life. A stable life. A life with parents who were ready for it, who could give it everything it needed. I knew I couldn't provide that, not then. Not ever, probably.

Mark…Mark was a good guy, but he was just as lost as I was. We were kids pretending to be adults. It wouldn't have been fair to the baby, or to us.

Vanessa and Mark – they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They could give that baby a life I just couldn't. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, and it still hurts sometimes. But I know I made the right choice.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. And that's all that really matters.

Don't make me talk about this anymore. It's…a lot.

Ugh, okay, that was…a process. Seriously. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment or anything. It was a lot of awkward meetings and trying to figure out who wasn't completely insane.

At first, I was kinda just going through the motions, you know? Like, looking at the profiles, trying to find someone who seemed…normal. But then you meet people, and normal goes out the window pretty quick. There was that one couple who wanted to name the baby "Magnolia Sunshine," and I was like, *hard pass*.

Vanessa and Mark…they were different. They weren't perfect, nobody is. Vanessa was a little…intense, maybe. Really into organic food and decorating. But she was also really warm and kind. And Mark was just…chill. He didn't try to be anything he wasn't.

What really got me was when I went to their house. It wasn't fancy or anything, but it felt…comfortable. Like a real home. And they had a dog, a little beagle named Buster, and Buster immediately liked me. That's a good sign, right? Animals can sense things.

We talked for a long time, and they didn't try to pressure me or tell me what to do. They just listened. They asked me what *I* wanted, what *I* thought was best for the baby. And they seemed genuinely excited about the idea of being parents, but also realistic about how hard it would be.

I also got a good vibe from them when I saw how they interacted with each other. They were goofy and affectionate and they clearly loved each other. And that's what I wanted for the baby – a loving and stable home.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because there's no such thing. It was about finding people who were good people, who would love the baby unconditionally, and who would give it a good life. And Vanessa and Mark, they just…felt right.

It was still a really hard decision, don't get me wrong. But in the end, I knew I was making the right choice. For me, and for the baby.

Ugh, music? It was…everything. Seriously. It was my lifeline, my escape, my way of figuring out who I was when everything else felt totally messed up.

I wasn't, like, a band geek or anything. I didn't play an instrument. I just *listened*. A lot. And it wasn't just about liking songs, it was about finding the ones that *got* it. You know? The ones that understood how you felt when you were, like, completely overwhelmed and confused and trying to navigate the whole awkwardness of being a teenager.

The Moldy Peaches were huge. They were just…real. Kimya Dawson's songs were like she was reading my diary. Super depressing, but also kinda comforting. And they weren't trying to be all polished and perfect, which I appreciated.

I also listened to a lot of indie stuff. Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins, Bright Eyes…all that angsty, introspective stuff. It just fit the mood.

And then there was the soundtrack to everything. Like, when I was feeling particularly cynical, I'd listen to The Clash. When I was trying to be cool, I'd listen to whatever everyone else was listening to, even if I didn't really like it.

Music was just…there. It was the soundtrack to my life, and it helped me get through a lot. Especially when things got, you know, complicated. It was a way to feel less alone, even when I was completely surrounded by people.

It was a way to process everything, I guess. And honestly, it still is. I don't know what I'd do without music. It's just…important. Okay? Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, alright? It wasn't like everyone was throwing confetti and saying, "Congratulations!" More like side-eye and whispers. Maple Creek isn't exactly known for its progressive thinking.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored it. Or pretended to. I mean, what else was I gonna do? Cry about it? That wouldn't have solved anything. I'm not really one for wallowing, even though I look like I am sometimes.

I leaned *hard* on my friends, Leah and Renee. They were amazing. They didn't treat me like some freak show. They just… were there. They helped me with school, they came to doctor's appointments, they just generally kept me from losing my mind.

My dad was… complicated. He was quiet at first, but he came around. He's a good guy, even if he doesn't always know how to express it. And my stepmom, Bren, she was a lifesaver. She actually *helped* me pick out baby names. Can you believe it?

I think a big part of coping was just being… me. I didn't try to hide or apologize for being pregnant. I just kept being sarcastic and awkward and obsessed with records. I figured if people were gonna judge me, they were gonna judge me anyway. I wasn't gonna give them the satisfaction of seeing me fall apart.

And honestly, I think a lot of the stigma came from people just not understanding. They had this idea of what a pregnant teenager was supposed to be like, and I didn't fit that mold. I wasn't a tragic case. I was just… a kid who made a mistake.

It wasn't easy, but I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself and about the people around me. And I realized that sometimes, the people you least expect are the ones who will support you the most.

So yeah, that's how I coped. Mostly by being stubborn and surrounding myself with good people. And a lot of records. Always a lot of records.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's complicated.

Right after Paul…after the baby was born, it was…weird. Like, obviously. I mean, I’d been planning this for months, right? I knew it was the right thing to do. I *wanted* it to be the right thing to do. But holding her…she was so tiny. And perfect. And suddenly all the logical reasons I had for choosing adoption felt…smaller.

There was this moment, holding her, where I almost…changed my mind. Just completely flipped. But then I remembered everything. My life. School. My future. And the fact that Mark and Vanessa were *so* ready. They were so excited. They could give her a life I just…couldn’t.

Giving her to them was…the hardest thing I’ve ever done. It felt like ripping a piece of myself away. I cried. A lot. And I kept looking at them, making sure they were okay, making sure *she* was okay.

But then…I saw how happy they were. And I saw how much they loved her. And that…that made it a little bit easier. It didn’t erase the sadness, but it made it…worth it.

It wasn’t like I just walked away and forgot about her. I stayed in touch. Mark and Vanessa were really good about that. They sent pictures, told me about her milestones. It was…good. It was a different kind of relationship than being a mom, but it was still important.

I still think about her sometimes. Wonder what she’s like. If she knows. If she’s happy.

It wasn’t easy. It wasn’t perfect. But it was the right thing to do. For her. And for me. And I wouldn’t trade it. Even though it still kinda hurts sometimes.

It made me grow up, you know? It made me realize that sometimes, the hardest choices are the best ones. And that love comes in all different forms.



It's…a lot to unpack. I don't really like talking about it, but you asked. And it's important to be honest about it, I guess.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You want me to relive that? Fine. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, okay? It was…a lot.

Physically, it was just…weird. My body was doing things it wasn't supposed to be doing. Morning sickness was a joke. It was all-day sickness. And not just throwing up, it was the nausea, the exhaustion, the weird cravings. Pickles and ice cream? Yeah, I did that. Don't judge.

And then there was the bloating. Oh, the bloating. I looked like I was smuggling a basketball under my sweater. It was not a cute look. And my feet swelled up. I had to get new shoes. It was a disaster.

But the emotional stuff was way harder. I mean, I was sixteen. I had plans. I was supposed to be applying to colleges, figuring out my life, not…growing a human. It was terrifying. I was angry, and sad, and confused, and just…overwhelmed.

I cried a lot. Like, a *lot*. And I pushed people away. I didn't want anyone to see me like that. I didn't want anyone to feel sorry for me.

Paul was…good. He was awkward, but he was there. And my mom, surprisingly, was really supportive. She didn't freak out like I thought she would. She just…listened. And she made me hot chocolate. A lot of hot chocolate.

I also started seeing a therapist. That helped. It gave me a safe space to talk about my feelings without being judged.

Honestly, it was just about taking things one day at a time. And realizing that it was okay to not be okay. It was okay to be scared. It was okay to be confused. It was okay to just…feel.

And eventually, I started to feel…something else. A little bit of hope. A little bit of excitement. A little bit of…love.

It was still scary, but it wasn't as overwhelming. I realized that I could do this. I could be a mom. Even if I wasn't ready.

It was a mess, okay? But I got through it. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the pickles and ice cream.

(Sighs, looks down at my hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's still… complicated.

Look, before all this happened, I didn't really *think* about reproductive rights, you know? It was just… something that was there. Like, people had opinions, and there were protests, but it didn't really affect my life. I was too busy making mixtapes and avoiding gym class.

But then… finding out I was pregnant? That changed everything. It wasn't just some abstract political issue anymore. It was *my* life. *My* body. *My* future.

And honestly? It was terrifying. I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I had plans. I wanted to finish school, maybe go to college. I wasn't equipped to be a mom.

Choosing to have an abortion wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. There was a lot of guilt, a lot of sadness, a lot of just… feeling lost. People had opinions, and a lot of them weren't very nice. Even people who meant well.

But ultimately, I knew it was the right decision for me. It allowed me to keep control of my life. It allowed me to pursue my dreams.

And that's why I feel so strongly about reproductive rights. It's not about being "pro-life" or "pro-choice." It's about letting people make their own decisions about their own bodies. It's about respecting their autonomy. It's about giving them the freedom to choose what's best for *them*.

Because no one else can make that decision for you. No politician, no religious leader, no family member. It has to be your choice.

I think everyone deserves that right. Everyone. And I'll fight for it, because I know what it's like to have that right taken away, or even just threatened. It's a scary feeling.

(Looks away again, a little uncomfortable)

It's… yeah. It's a lot. But it's important.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about the fear part? Yeah, there was a *lot* of that. Like, a constant, low-level hum of panic. It wasn't like in the movies, where you suddenly feel all maternal and glowing. It was more like… “Oh my god, I’m going to ruin a human life.”

Honestly? I didn't really "overcome" it. I just…learned to live with it. And a lot of it was just admitting to myself that I *was* terrified. Like, really terrified. It's okay to be scared. It doesn't mean you're not capable.

Paul helped, obviously. He was a good guy. And my dad, surprisingly. He wasn't thrilled at first, but he came around. Having people who believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself, made a huge difference.

But mostly, it was just taking things one day at a time. I couldn't think about the next 18 years, or even the next month. I just focused on what I needed to do *right now*. Like, making sure I had enough money for diapers, or going to doctor's appointments.

And I realized that being a parent isn't about being perfect. It's about showing up. It's about trying your best, even when you're failing miserably. And it's about loving that little person with everything you have.

I also had to let go of the life I thought I was going to have. I had plans, you know? College, maybe moving to another state. But those plans changed. And that was hard. But I realized that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you never planned for.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And that even when you're scared out of your mind, you can still do amazing things.

So, yeah. I didn't overcome my fears. I just learned to carry them with me. And I learned that sometimes, fear can be a good thing. It can motivate you to be a better person. And a better parent.

Ugh, okay, so this is…a big question. And it's not like I sat down and made a *plan*, you know? It wasn't like, "Okay, I'm pregnant, time to find a nice couple." It was way messier than that.

Honestly? It started with being realistic. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was barely figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have the money, the stability, the…anything.

But it wasn't just about me being unprepared. It was about wanting the best for the baby. And I realized that the best thing I could do wasn't to keep it. It was to give it to someone who *could* give it everything it needed. A stable home, financial security, a loving family…things I just couldn't provide at that point in my life.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. They were so excited, so ready. They wanted a kid so badly. And they weren't looking for a perfect baby, or a perfect situation. They just wanted to love and care for a child.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. There were a lot of tears, a lot of second-guessing. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up the baby. It was about giving the baby a *better* life. And that's what mattered most.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story. But it was my story. And I'm okay with it. I really am.



It's still…weird sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a lot. You're asking about the messy parts, huh? Fine. Let's talk about it. It's not like I haven't thought about it enough already.

With Leah… Leah is my rock. Seriously. She's the only one who really *gets* me, you know? She doesn't judge, she just…is. We've been through everything together, and even when I'm being a total disaster, she's still there. It's a really comfortable friendship. We can be completely honest with each other, even when it's awkward. Sometimes *especially* when it's awkward. It's not a super dramatic friendship, it's just…solid. Like a really good pair of jeans. It's the kind of friendship I know will last, even when life gets crazy. And it *is* getting crazy.

Paulie… Paulie is…complicated. He's a good guy, I guess. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a goofball. But he's also…young. And immature. And we're both kinda messes, honestly. It's not a traditional relationship, and it never was supposed to be. We were just…there for each other. And then things happened. I don't think either of us was really ready for this, but here we are. 

It's weird, because I don't necessarily *love* him, not in the way people talk about in movies. But I care about him. A lot. And I want him to be a good dad. And I think he wants to be. It's just…we have a lot to figure out. We're learning as we go, which is terrifying. It's not always easy, and we definitely have our fights. But underneath it all, there's a respect and a connection. 

I guess what I'm trying to say is, both relationships are important to me, but in totally different ways. Leah is my constant, my safe space. Paulie is…the unknown. And I'm trying to navigate that, one awkward conversation at a time. It's a lot. It's really a lot. And sometimes I just want to curl up with a tater tot and pretend none of it is happening. But that's not really an option, is it?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't a *decision*, exactly. It wasn't like I sat down and thought, "Oh, this would be a fun life choice." It just…happened.

Paul Bleeker and I…we weren't exactly careful. We were kids. We were figuring things out. And honestly, we were both kinda awkward and didn't really talk about stuff like that. It was a mistake, yeah, but it wasn't a mistake I regretted immediately.

It was scary, obviously. Really scary. I was a junior in high school! I had plans. I was gonna go to college, maybe move to New York, become a journalist or something. And suddenly, all that felt…different.

But it wasn't all bad. I mean, finding out I was pregnant forced me to grow up, I guess. It made me think about things I hadn't thought about before. And it made me realize I wasn't as selfish as I thought I was.

I knew I couldn't raise a kid myself. I wasn't ready. I wasn't financially stable. I wasn't emotionally ready. So, I started looking into adoption. And that felt…right. It felt like the best thing for the baby.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about *giving* a baby a life. A good life. With parents who were ready and able to provide for it.

So, it wasn't a decision I made lightly. It was a complicated, messy, and kinda heartbreaking decision. But it was the right one. For me, and for the baby.

And honestly? It made me who I am today. It forced me to figure out what I wanted out of life, and to be a little bit braver and a little bit more responsible. It wasn't the path I expected, but it was my path. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Don't get me wrong, it was still hard. But I got through it. And I learned a lot along the way.

(Sighs, looks off to the side for a beat, then back at you)

Okay, that's… a loaded question. And honestly? It's one I still think about. A lot.

Regret isn't exactly the right word. It wasn't like, "Oh man, I *wish* I hadn't done that." It was more… complicated. There were definitely moments, especially after I gave him up, where it felt like a piece of me was missing. Like a really big, important piece.

It was hard. Really hard. Seeing Mark and Vanessa with him, knowing he had a good life… it was good. It *had* to be good. But it also felt… weird. Like I was watching a movie of a life that could have been mine.

And there were times I wondered what it would have been like to keep him. To raise him. To be a mom. But then I'd remember why I made the decision I did. I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I had my own life to figure out. And I knew, deep down, that Mark and Vanessa could give him everything I couldn't.

So, no. I don't regret the decision itself. I regret the sadness. I regret the feeling of loss. But I don't regret giving him the best possible life.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it made me grow up a lot, really fast. It taught me a lot about myself, about love, and about what it means to be a good person.

It's just… it's not something you just *get over*, you know? It's always going to be a part of me. And that's okay.



(Looks down, fiddles with her hands)

It was the right thing to do. I know it was. But that doesn't mean it didn't hurt.

Ugh, okay, so that was…a whole thing. Honestly, it wasn't easy. It was mostly just a lot of caffeine, a lot of strategically placed hoodies, and a whole lot of pretending everything was totally normal when it was, like, the opposite of normal.

First of all, Paul, bless his heart, was a huge help. He drove me to school, helped me with homework, and generally just tried to make things less stressful. And my mom, even though she was…a lot…was surprisingly supportive. She helped me pick out maternity clothes that didn't scream "teen mom" and made sure I was eating enough.

But mostly, it was just about prioritizing. I had to get my act together. I couldn't just blow off school, you know? I still wanted to graduate. I still wanted to have options.

I talked to my guidance counselor, Mr. Spencer, and he was really cool about it. He helped me adjust my schedule so I could take some classes online and have more flexibility. I also had to skip a few things – cheerleading, obviously. And I definitely wasn't going to any more parties.

It was exhausting. I was constantly tired, and I had morning sickness for, like, forever. And dealing with all the stares and whispers was…not fun. But I just kept my head down and focused on getting my work done.

I also had to deal with Leah, who was being…Leah. She meant well, but she was constantly trying to "help" and making things more complicated. But she came around eventually.

Honestly, it was just about taking it one day at a time. And reminding myself that I wasn't alone. And that even though my life was totally different than I expected, it could still be good.

It wasn't glamorous, okay? It was messy and stressful and weird. But I did it. I graduated. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's complicated.

It wasn't like I was, like, *pro-life* or anything. That wasn't really the point. It was more…I just couldn't bring myself to do it. I know that sounds kinda vague, but it's true.

I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. And suddenly I was supposed to make this huge decision about…another life? It was terrifying.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. And the baby hadn't done anything wrong. It didn't ask to be there. And I just…I couldn't shake the feeling that it deserved a chance.

I talked to my mom, and she was really supportive. She didn't push me either way. She just said, "It's your decision, Juno. Whatever you choose, I'll be there for you."

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…different. They weren't what I expected. They were actually really cool. And they were so excited about the idea of having a baby. They wanted it so badly.

And I realized that I could give them that. I could give this baby a loving home with parents who were ready for it. And that felt…right.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. For me, for the baby, and for Mark and Vanessa.

It wasn't about what I *believed* in, it was about what I *felt*. And I felt like this was the best option. It was the most…responsible thing to do.

So yeah. That's why. It wasn't a simple decision, and it's still something I think about. But I don't regret it. Not one bit.

Ugh, okay, that's a…big question. And honestly, a really important one. Look, I've been through a lot with this whole baby thing, right? And it's made me think. A lot.
