And yeah, absolutely. A kid can totally thrive under non-traditional arrangements. Like, who decided what a "traditional" family even *is* anyway? It's kinda arbitrary, if you ask me.

It's not about the gender of the parents or whether there's one or two of them. It's about love, and stability, and being there for the kid. It's about providing a safe and supportive environment where they can grow up to be a decent human being.

I mean, look at Van and Mark. They're…not what people expect, you know? But they're amazing. They're kind, and patient, and they genuinely want what's best for the baby. And that's what matters.

A single parent can be just as good as two parents, if they have a strong support system and are committed to raising their child. And same-sex couples? Seriously, what's the difference? Love is love. And a kid needs love. Period.

It's not about fitting into some pre-defined mold. It's about creating a family that works for *that* kid. And sometimes, that means breaking the rules a little bit.

Honestly, I think kids are pretty resilient. They adapt. And they're pretty good at figuring out who loves them, regardless of what anyone else thinks.

So yeah, I definitely believe a child can thrive under non-traditional arrangements. It's not about the *structure* of the family, it's about the *quality* of the love and support. And that's what really counts.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me think about this. It's not exactly a fun topic. But fine, you asked.

I guess… my biggest flaw is probably that I build walls. Like, really high, really sturdy walls. I'm good at being sarcastic and deflecting and making jokes, and that's fine, it's a coping mechanism. But sometimes I use it to keep people *out*. 

I'm scared of getting hurt, okay? It's easier to be cynical and detached than to actually let someone in and risk getting my heart broken. I push people away before they can push me away, you know? It's a dumb move, I know, but it's hard to stop.

And I'm really good at pretending I don't care about things, even when I totally do. Like, with Paulie Bleeker. I acted all cool and indifferent for way too long. It was a total mess.

It's just… vulnerability is terrifying. It feels like handing someone a weapon. And I've already got enough going on without adding more drama to the mix.

So yeah, I guess my biggest weakness is being afraid to be… real. It's something I'm working on, though. Slowly. It's a process. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay. Mark. That's…a complicated question. It's not like he was a *bad* guy, you know? Just…not the right guy. And honestly, the whole thing was just…a mess.

Before Mark, I had this really naive idea of what relationships were supposed to be. Like, this grand romantic gesture, a perfect connection, a happily ever after. You know, the stuff they show in movies. And then reality hit me like a ton of bricks.

He was sweet, and he was genuinely excited about the baby, which was good. But he was also…kind of clueless. He wanted the idea of a family, but he didn't really *get* what that meant. He wanted me to be this perfect mom and wife, and he didn't really see me as a person with my own dreams and goals.

It made me realize that a relationship isn't just about finding someone who loves you. It's about finding someone who respects you, who supports you, who challenges you to be a better version of yourself. It's about finding someone who sees you for who you are, flaws and all.

And it also made me realize that you can't force a connection. You can't make someone feel something they don't feel. And trying to do so just ends up hurting everyone involved.

It was a really hard lesson to learn, especially with a baby on the way. But it was a necessary one. It made me stronger, and it made me more clear about what I wanted in a partner.

It wasn't about finding someone to "save" me, or to complete me. It was about finding someone to share my life with, someone who would be my equal, my partner, my friend.

Paul…he gets that. He doesn't try to change me. He just…accepts me. And that's a pretty amazing feeling.

So yeah, Mark changed my perspective on relationships. It taught me that love isn't always enough. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is walk away. Even if it's scary. Especially if it's scary.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not easy to answer. But if someone's in a situation like I was…look, first of all, it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel like your whole life is falling apart. Because it kinda is.

But it's also okay to be strong. And it's okay to make a decision that's right for *you*, even if it's not what everyone else thinks you should do.

Here's what I learned, and what I'd tell someone now:

*   **Don't let anyone pressure you.** This is *your* life, *your* body, *your* decision. Your parents, your friends, the baby's dad…they can offer advice, but ultimately, it's up to you.
*   **Talk to someone you trust.** Someone who will listen without judgment. A friend, a family member, a counselor…anyone who will just be there for you.
*   **Consider all your options.** Adoption isn't the only answer, but it's a valid one. Think about what's best for you and for the baby.
*   **Don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to help you, no matter what you decide.
*   **It's okay to grieve.** Even if you know you're making the right decision, it's still going to be hard. Allow yourself to feel your feelings.
*   **You are not alone.** A lot of people have been in similar situations. You're not the first, and you won't be the last.
*   **You are stronger than you think.** You're going to get through this. It's going to be tough, but you're going to get through it.

And honestly? It's okay to be a mess. It's okay to not have all the answers. Just take things one day at a time. And remember that you deserve to be happy.

It's not going to be easy. But you can do it. I did. And so can you.

Just…breathe. And don't let anyone tell you what to do. You got this.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like a straight line, you know? It's been more like a really twisty, bumpy road with a few detours and a couple of flat tires.

When I first found out I was pregnant, he was…not thrilled. To say the least. He was all, "What are you *thinking*?" and "This is going to ruin your life!" which, okay, fair enough. But it still stung. He's always been kinda…practical. And I'm, well, not.

For a while, it was just a lot of awkward silences and him trying to "fix" things. Like he thought he could just *solve* a pregnancy. It was annoying. I needed him to just…be there, you know? Not try to make it all go away.

But then, slowly, things started to change. He started coming to the doctor's appointments with me, and he actually *listened* to what I was saying. He started asking questions, not just giving advice. And he started to realize that I wasn't just some irresponsible kid. I was actually trying to do the right thing, even if it wasn't the easiest thing.

He was a huge help with Mark, too. He wasn't all gushy and stuff, but he was reliable. He helped with the practical stuff – getting the nursery ready, driving me to appointments, just being a steady presence.

Now? We still bicker. We still disagree about things. He still thinks I should have gone to college right away. But there's a…respect there now. A real connection. He's not just my dad, he's…a friend, in a weird way.

I think he finally realized that I'm my own person, and that I'm going to make my own choices, even if he doesn't always agree with them. And I realized that he loves me, even if he doesn't always know how to show it.

It's still a work in progress, honestly. But it's gotten a lot better. A lot. And I'm grateful for that. He's a good guy, my dad. Just…a little bit clueless sometimes. But who isn't?

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the essays. Like, it was some magical gift or something. It wasn't. It was mostly just…avoidance. And a lot of staring out the window.

Honestly, I didn't *try* to develop my writing skills. It just kinda happened. I was failing history, okay? Mr. Hetrick was convinced I was actively trying to sabotage my education. So I had to write an essay to pass. And then another one. And another one.

I think the key was that I didn't care about sounding smart or using big words. I just wanted to write something that was…true. To how I actually thought. And I have a lot of thoughts. Mostly sarcastic ones.

I also read a lot. Not like, assigned reading. I read comic books, magazines, anything I could get my hands on. And I paid attention to how people talked. Real people, not characters in books.

And I watched a lot of movies. Especially John Hughes movies. He was a master of capturing teenage angst.

I think the biggest thing, though, was just…being honest. I didn't try to be someone I wasn't. I just wrote about what I knew, which was mostly awkwardness and feeling out of place.

So, yeah. That's how I developed my writing skills. By being a procrastinator and a cynic. It's not a glamorous story, but it worked.

And honestly, it was a good distraction from everything else that was going on. Which, at the time, was a lot.



Don't overthink it. Just write what you feel. And don't be afraid to be weird. Weird is good.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big one. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? There was a lot of side-eye, a lot of whispers, and a lot of people just assuming the worst. It sucked.

Honestly, the worst part wasn't even the people I didn't know. It was the people I *did* know. Like, some of my classmates were just…awful. And even some adults were pretty judgmental. It felt like everyone was just waiting for me to fall apart.

I dealt with it by… well, by being me. Which, admittedly, is a little sarcastic and defensive. I just kinda shut down a lot of the negativity. I didn't really *try* to change anyone's mind. I figured if they were gonna judge me, they were gonna judge me anyway.

But I also had a really good support system. My dad, surprisingly, was amazing. He was quiet about it at first, but he was always there for me. And Paul, of course. He was… a good egg. And my best friend, Leah, she was a lifesaver. She didn't treat me any differently, and she just let me be me.

I also just kinda focused on the fact that I was doing what *I* wanted to do. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, but I also knew I wanted to give this baby a good life. And that was what mattered.

I think a lot of it was just… ignoring the noise. And realizing that other people's opinions didn't define me. I was still Juno MacGuff, even if I was also a pregnant teenager. And that was okay.

It wasn't easy, and there were definitely days when I wanted to just disappear. But I got through it. And honestly, it made me stronger. It forced me to figure out who I was and what I wanted. And that's something I'm grateful for, even if it was a really messy process.

So, yeah. That's how I dealt with it. A little bit of sarcasm, a lot of support, and a whole lot of just trying to be myself.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. One I don't usually let myself dwell on, honestly. But yeah. Sometimes.

Look, being brutally honest is kinda my default setting. It's easier than pretending to care about stuff I don't, or saying what people want to hear. It's just…me. And it usually works out fine. Mostly.

But there have been times, you know? Times when I said something I shouldn't have, or when my honesty hurt someone's feelings. And then I feel like a jerk. A really big jerk.

Like with my dad. I wasn't exactly sunshine and rainbows with him, even before…everything. I was always quick to point out his flaws, and I probably didn't show him enough appreciation. And now…well, now it's too late. And I wonder if things would have been different if I'd just swallowed my pride a few times.

Or with Paul. I was pretty blunt with him, even when he was being…Paul. And sometimes I think he just needed someone to be nice to him, you know? Instead of constantly making fun of his earnestness.

So yeah, I regret it sometimes. I regret not being able to just…filter myself. But then I think, if I wasn't me, if I wasn't honest, I wouldn't have met the people I met, and things wouldn't have happened the way they did. And maybe that's okay.

It's a trade-off, I guess. I'm a work in progress. Still figuring things out. And maybe learning to be a little bit kinder, even if it means biting my tongue sometimes. But don't expect me to change completely. I'm still gonna call things like I see them. It's just…I'm trying to be a little more mindful about *how* I say them.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big one. Seriously. It's like, everyone has an opinion about everything, and when you're doing something that's not exactly…conventional, the opinions come *fast*.

Look, I'm not gonna lie, it sucks. People judging you, making assumptions, thinking they know what's best for you. Especially when you're dealing with something like…well, you know. A baby. And deciding what to do with it.

Here's what I've figured out, though. It's not about ignoring everyone else. That's impossible. It's about figuring out whose opinions actually *matter*. And that's usually just a really small circle of people. Like, Paul, my dad, maybe a couple of friends. People who actually know me, and who aren't just projecting their own stuff onto me.

The rest? You gotta let it roll off your back. Easier said than done, I know. But you can't live your life trying to please everyone. You'll just end up miserable.

I think the key is to know what *you* want. And to be honest with yourself about it. Even if it's messy, and complicated, and doesn't fit into anyone else's idea of what you should be doing.

And don't be afraid to be a little bit weird. Seriously. The people who are worth keeping around are the ones who appreciate your weirdness.

It's also okay to change your mind. I mean, I've changed my mind about a lot of things. That doesn't mean I'm flaky or indecisive. It just means I'm figuring things out as I go.

And honestly? Sometimes you just gotta tell people to mind their own business. Politely, of course. But firmly.

It's a process. It's not like you wake up one day and suddenly you're immune to other people's judgments. But the more you practice being true to yourself, the easier it gets. And the more you realize that their opinions don't define you. *You* define you.

And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, values. That sounds…intense. Like a school assignment. But okay, if I *have* to think about it…

I guess the biggest thing for me is **honesty**. Not like, "never tell a lie" honesty, because sometimes a little white lie is necessary to spare someone's feelings. But being honest with *myself*, you know? Knowing what I really want and not pretending to be someone I'm not.

Then there's **independence**. I don't want to rely on anyone else to make me happy or take care of me. I want to be able to figure things out on my own, even if it's messy.

And **authenticity**. Being real. Not trying to fit in or be cool or impress anyone. Just being me, flaws and all. It's exhausting trying to be someone you're not.

I also think **kindness** is important. Even to people who are annoying or mean. You never know what someone else is going through.

And finally, **loyalty**. To the people I care about. I'm not a lot of people's friend, but the ones I have, I'm fiercely loyal to.

I guess those are the things that matter to me. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I try to aim for. It's kinda weird to actually *say* them out loud, though. It feels…vulnerable.

Don't tell anyone I said all this, okay? It's embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, deep breath. The biggest challenge? Honestly, it wasn't the morning sickness, or the weird cravings, or even the whole "my body is changing" thing. It was…people.

Like, everyone had an opinion. Everyone. My parents, Paul, even random people at the grocery store. They all thought they knew what was best for me and the baby. And it was exhausting.

My dad was all about "doing the right thing," which meant giving the baby up for adoption, which I already *knew* I wanted to do, but he kept acting like I needed convincing. And my mom was just…sad. All the time. Which made me feel guilty, even though I wasn't doing anything wrong.

And then there was Paul. He was great, mostly. But he kept trying to be the hero, like he could fix everything. And I just wanted him to listen. To understand that this was *my* decision.

It was just…a lot of pressure. A lot of people telling me what to do, what to feel, what to think. And I just wanted to be left alone to figure things out for myself.

So yeah, the biggest challenge wasn't the pregnancy itself. It was navigating all the expectations and opinions and trying to stay true to what *I* wanted. It was realizing that I had to be my own advocate, even when it was hard.

It was…a mess. But I got through it. And honestly, it made me a lot stronger.

(Sighs, fiddles with a strand of hair)

Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not like I walked around before thinking life was all sunshine and rainbows, you know? I was pretty cynical. Still am, kinda. But…yeah. It's changed things. A lot.

Before, everything was about *me*. Getting through high school, figuring out what I wanted to do, avoiding awkward conversations…it was all self-focused. And that's not a bad thing, I guess, when you're sixteen. But then you have this little person who completely depends on you, and suddenly your whole world shifts.

It's not about being selfless, exactly. It's more like…your priorities just rearrange themselves. Suddenly, worrying about what people think of your shoes seems really stupid. You start thinking about things like, "Will she be safe?" and "Will she be happy?" and "Am I doing enough?"

It's terrifying, honestly. Like, the weight of responsibility is…intense. But it's also…amazing. Seeing her learn and grow and just be…herself…it's the best thing ever.

I used to think I had to have everything figured out. Career, relationships, the whole deal. Now I realize it's okay to not know. It's okay to just be present and enjoy the moment. Because moments are all you really have.

And it's made me appreciate the people in my life more. Paul, my parents, even Mark…they're all so important. I wouldn't have been able to do this without them.

It's still hard, you know? Balancing everything. But it's a good hard. It's a hard that makes you feel…alive.

So, yeah. Being a mom…it's changed everything. It's made me a better person, I think. Or at least, I hope it has. It's definitely made me a lot less sarcastic. Okay, maybe not *less* sarcastic. But…more selectively sarcastic.



(Looks down, a small smile playing on her lips)

It's just…it's a whole new world. And it's pretty great.

Ugh. Self-doubt. Yeah, I know that guy. He's a real jerk. He shows up at the *worst* times, usually when you're already kinda freaking out about something else.

Okay, so here's the thing. It doesn't really *go* away, you know? It's always gonna be lurking somewhere in the back of your head. But you can learn to…manage it.

First of all, I try to remember that everyone feels like a total fraud sometimes. Even people who seem super confident. It's just that they're better at hiding it.

Then, I try to talk myself down. Like, I'll say, "Okay, Juno, you're being ridiculous. You've handled worse things than this." And sometimes, I'll actually believe it.

And honestly? Talking to someone helps. Like, really talking. Not just venting, but actually being honest about how you're feeling. Paul was good for that. And Bleeker, even if he's kinda clueless sometimes.

But the biggest thing is to just…do something. Anything. Distract yourself. Watch a movie. Listen to music. Go for a walk. Just get your mind off of it. Because the more you dwell on it, the worse it gets.

And you gotta remember that it's okay to not be perfect. It's okay to make mistakes. It's okay to not have all the answers. Nobody does.

It's kinda like…when you're trying to parallel park. You're gonna mess up a few times. But you just keep trying until you get it right. And even if you don't get it right, it's not the end of the world.

So yeah. Self-doubt sucks. But you can get through it. Just remember to be kind to yourself. And maybe listen to some The Moldy Peaches. That usually helps.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. But seriously? It's…a lot more important than I let on. I try to act all independent and sarcastic and like I don't need anyone, but that's mostly just a defense mechanism.

Before all this baby stuff happened, I was pretty much a lone wolf. I hung out with Paul, but even that was kinda…casual. I didn't really *need* anyone. Or at least, I didn't think I did.

But then I got pregnant, and suddenly everything changed. I couldn't just pretend everything was fine anymore. I needed help. I needed someone to talk to. And I needed someone to just…be there.

And that's where Leah and my dad came in. And even, surprisingly, Vanessa. They didn't judge me. They didn't try to tell me what to do. They just listened and offered support. And that made all the difference.

It's not about needing someone to fix your problems. It's about having people who will just sit with you in your problems. People who will make you laugh when you want to cry. People who will remind you that you're not alone.

I still value my independence, don't get me wrong. I still need my space. But I've learned that it's okay to lean on people sometimes. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to let people care about you.

So yeah, community and social support are important. Really important. Even for a cynical, sarcastic teenager like me. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? But if I had to pick *one* thing, the most important lesson… it wasn't about the baby, or even about giving him up. It was about…owning your own stuff.

Like, for a long time, I was just kinda drifting. Trying to be cool, trying to fit in, not really thinking about what *I* wanted. And then suddenly, I was pregnant, and everything was real. And I had to make a decision, a huge decision, and it had to be *my* decision.

It wasn't about what my parents thought, or what Paul thought, or what anyone else thought. It was about what I could handle, what I thought was best for the baby, and what I needed for my own life.

And that was…terrifying. But also kind of liberating.

I realized that I'm the only one who can live my life. And I'm the only one who has to deal with the consequences of my choices. So I might as well make choices that I can live with, choices that feel right to *me*.

It sounds kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. It's about taking responsibility for your own life, and not letting anyone else tell you what to do. And it's about being brave enough to do what's right, even when it's hard.

So yeah. Owning your own stuff. That's the big lesson. And it's one I'm still learning, honestly. It's a work in progress. But it's a good lesson to have.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Honestly? I don't know. It's not like I have a five-year plan or anything. That seems… exhausting.

But yeah, I do like writing. I mean, I write a lot in my journal. It's a good way to, like, sort through all the stuff in my head. And Mr. Marcus, my English teacher, he says I have a knack for it. Which is nice, I guess.

I don't know if I want to be a *professional* writer, though. That sounds…intense. And competitive. And probably involves a lot of rejection. I'm not sure I'm ready for all that.

I think I just like being able to express myself. To put my thoughts and feelings into words. It's kinda therapeutic, you know?

Maybe I'll just keep writing in my journal. Or maybe I'll write a novel someday. Or maybe I'll just write really sarcastic letters to people who annoy me.

I don't know. I'm still figuring things out. I'm sixteen. I'm allowed to be confused, right?

But yeah, I think I'm pretty good at it. So maybe. Maybe I will pursue a career in writing. Or maybe I'll just keep it as a hobby. We'll see. Don't hold me to anything.



It's not like I'm gonna be the next Jane Austen or anything. But it's something I enjoy. And that's good enough for now.

Ugh, okay, the name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly stressful process, actually. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was more like a series of compromises and accidental discoveries.

See, Mark – the dad – wanted something really…normal. Like, Michael or something. Which is fine, I guess, but kinda boring. And I wanted something…unique. Something that fit the kid, you know? Something that wasn't gonna get them teased relentlessly in middle school.

We went through a *lot* of names. Like, a ridiculous amount. We had lists and lists. And everything sounded awful. Everything.

Then, one day, I was flipping through this old record album with my dad – a really obscure folk singer named Joan Baez – and I saw her name. And it just…clicked. It sounded strong and kinda cool, but not too weird.

So, we went with Joan. It's a classic name, but it's not super common anymore. And it's a tribute to my dad, because he loves Joan Baez. It felt like a good compromise.

It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment or anything. It was just…the least bad option. Which, honestly, is how a lot of things work in life.

And honestly, I think it suits her. She's a little Joan, and she's pretty awesome. Even if she does keep me up all night sometimes.

Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, winding road with a lot of unexpected potholes.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was good at being sarcastic and pretending I didn't care, but inside…it was a mess. I mean, finding out you're pregnant is already a lot for a sixteen-year-old. And then deciding to give the baby up? That's…heavy.

There were days I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. I was angry, sad, scared…all at the same time. I kept thinking, "What if I change my mind?" or "What if nobody wants him?" It was a constant loop of worry.

What helped, surprisingly, was Paul and Vanessa. They weren't trying to tell me what to do, or make me feel guilty. They just…listened. And they were honest. They didn't sugarcoat things, but they were also really supportive.

And Mark. He was…unexpected. I didn't think I'd connect with him, but he was just…normal. He made me laugh, and he didn't treat me like I was broken or something.

Talking to them, and to my dad, helped me realize that giving the baby up wasn't a failure. It was a brave thing to do. It was about wanting what was best for him, even if it meant I had to make a really hard choice.

It still hurt, though. A lot. Seeing Vanessa and Mark with the baby…it was bittersweet. I was happy for them, but I also felt a pang of sadness.

I think the biggest thing was allowing myself to feel those feelings. Not trying to bottle them up or pretend they weren't there. And realizing that it was okay to grieve.

It wasn't easy, and it still isn't always easy. But I'm okay. I'm figuring things out. And I know I made the right decision. It doesn't make it less hard, but it makes it…worth it.

It's just…complicated. You know? Life is complicated. And sometimes, the hardest choices are the best ones.

Ugh, okay, music. It's kinda important, you know? Gotta have something to drown out the world. So, it's not all bubblegum pop or anything, okay? I have standards.

I'm really into The Moldy Peaches. They're just...real. Like, super honest and kinda weird. Kimya Dawson is a genius.

But I also listen to a lot of indie stuff. Bright Eyes, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins...you know, the sad-girl-with-a-guitar vibe. It just fits my mood, most of the time.

I'm not really into anything too mainstream. Like, I can tolerate some Arcade Fire, but anything too poppy just makes me roll my eyes.

And I have a soft spot for oldies. Like, The Velvet Underground. My dad used to listen to them. It reminds me of him.

Basically, if it's authentic and a little bit melancholy, I'm probably into it. I don't need anything upbeat and happy. Life's already complicated enough, you know?

So yeah, that's my music taste in a nutshell. Don't judge. It's a work in progress. And it definitely reflects my current state of...everything.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. It's...complicated. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just…a lot.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. Like, aggressively perfect. Their house was all Pottery Barn and organic everything. It smelled like lavender and responsibility. Which, don't get me wrong, is nice. But it wasn't *me*.

Their lifestyle was…preppy. They did yoga, they ate quinoa, they had a golden retriever named Comet. Comet was cute, I'll give them that. But it was all so…planned. Everything had a place. Everything was coordinated. It felt like living in a catalog.

My house is…messy. We eat pizza and watch bad movies. My dad's always tinkering with something in the garage. It's chaotic, but it's *real*.

I remember thinking, "This is what a 'normal' family looks like." And it was a little intimidating. I worried if I could fit in. If I could be the daughter they expected.

It wasn't that I didn't like them. They were really nice people. They just…weren't us. It felt like two different worlds colliding.

I think that's why I kept being sarcastic and making jokes. It was a defense mechanism. A way to test them, to see if they could handle the real me. And thankfully, they did. They saw past the snark and the awkwardness and saw…well, I guess they saw something worth adopting.

But yeah, the house and the lifestyle? It was definitely a culture shock. It was a good shock, ultimately. But a shock nonetheless.

Ugh, okay, so the whole garage band thing… that was Paul’s idea, mostly. He’s just…enthusiastic about everything. Like, aggressively enthusiastic. It’s endearing, sometimes. And annoying.

But it started because he kept trying to impress me with his guitar skills. Which weren’t, like, *amazing*. He could play a few chords, but mostly he just strummed really loudly. And he kept writing these songs about me. Which was…awkward.

So I was like, “Okay, fine. If you want to play music, let’s actually *do* something with it. Let’s start a band.” I figured it would be a good way to, like, channel his energy and maybe get him to stop writing songs about my internal organs.

And then Leah got involved, because she’s a total badass on the bass. And she’s the only one who could actually keep Paul in check. She’s way more musically talented than both of us combined.

Honestly, I didn’t even know how to play an instrument. I just…talked into a microphone. And wrote some lyrics. Mostly about being pregnant and feeling confused. It was therapeutic, I guess.

It wasn’t about becoming famous or anything. It was just about having something to do, and about Paul trying to win me over with his questionable musical abilities. And it was kinda fun, actually. Even though we were terrible. Really terrible.

So yeah, that’s how the garage band happened. A combination of teenage hormones, awkwardness, and a desperate attempt to distract Paul from writing love songs about my uterus. It was a whole thing.

Okay, wow. That's…a big question. And it's a really important one. If I could talk to another girl going through what I went through… I'd say a lot of things.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel *all* the things. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Second: you are not alone. Seriously. Even when it feels like it, you're not. There are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: you have options. And those options are *yours* to decide. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with. Whether you choose to parent, adopt, or… well, you know… it's your decision. And it's a valid decision.

Fourth: it's okay to be selfish sometimes. You need to take care of yourself too. This is a huge thing to go through, and you need to prioritize your own well-being.

Fifth: don't let this define you. You are more than just a pregnant girl. You have dreams and goals and a whole life ahead of you. This is just one chapter in your story.

And finally: it's going to be hard. Really hard. But you are stronger than you think. You can get through this. And you deserve to be happy.

It's not going to be easy, but you're not weak for needing help. And you're not a bad person for making a difficult choice. You're just… a girl trying to figure things out. And that's okay.

Just… breathe. And remember that you're not alone. And that things will get better. Eventually.

Ugh, okay, don't make me think about clothes. It's not my favorite thing. But fine, I'll describe it. It's not, like, fancy or anything.

It's a faded, dark green t-shirt. It used to be a brighter green, I think, but it's been washed a million times. It's kinda soft now, in a worn-out way. It has a picture on it of a skeleton playing a ukulele. It's really cheesy, but I got it at a flea market and it just…spoke to me.

It's not too tight, not too loose. Just comfortable. And it hides stains pretty well, which is important. I usually wear it with jeans and Converse. 

It's not a statement piece or anything. It's just…my shirt. It feels like me. And it doesn't make me feel like I'm trying too hard, you know? Which is important.

Don't judge the skeleton with the ukulele. It's ironic. Okay?

Ugh, okay, that's a heavy question. Aspirations? Goals? It's not like I've got some five-year plan mapped out, you know? I'm kinda just…existing right now. Dealing with things as they come.

But yeah, if I had to think about it… I guess I want to be…okay. Just, genuinely okay. Not pretending, not putting on a brave face, just…content.

I don't need to be rich or famous or anything. I just want to find something I'm good at, something that makes me feel like I'm contributing something to the world. Maybe something creative. I like writing, even if it's just sarcastic observations in my head.

I definitely want to be a good mom. To this baby. That's the biggest thing, I think. I want to give it a good life, a stable life, even if I'm not perfect.

And I want to figure out who *I* am, you know? Not just "the pregnant girl" or "the girl who's giving the baby up." Just…Juno. What does that even mean? I'm still working on that part.

I guess my goal is to just…grow up. Without losing myself in the process. It's kinda scary, but also kinda exciting.

So yeah, no grand ambitions. Just…trying to figure things out. And hoping for the best. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Okay, the pre-adoption counseling. Right. That was…a lot. It wasn't *bad*, exactly, but it was definitely…intense. And awkward. Like, super awkward.

It felt like I was being interviewed for a job, except the job was giving away my baby. Which is a weird thing to have to "qualify" for, you know? Like, "Oh, you seem stable enough to raise a human. Here you go."

They asked a lot of questions. A *lot*. About my life, my plans, my feelings. Which, okay, fair enough. But it felt like they were trying to make sure Mark and Vanessa were perfect, and I was just…the vessel.

I get that they were trying to make sure the baby was going to a good home. And I really appreciated that, honestly. Mark and Vanessa *are* amazing. But it still felt weird to have strangers dissecting my life and making judgments.

And the whole thing about "grief" and "loss"… yeah, I knew I was going to be sad. But it felt like they were trying to make me feel guilty for wanting a normal life. Like, I was supposed to be devastated and inconsolable. And I was sad, don't get me wrong. But I also wanted to finish high school and go to college and, like, have a future.

It was helpful, I guess. It made me think about things I hadn't really thought about before. And it helped me feel more confident in my decision. But it was also really emotionally draining.

Honestly, I just wanted it to be over. I just wanted to get through it and move on. It was a necessary evil, I guess. But definitely not my favorite part of the whole process.

It's just…it's a really complicated situation, and sometimes I felt like they were trying to simplify it too much. Like, they wanted me to fit into a neat little box. And I don't really *do* neat little boxes.

Ugh, that's a good question. It's…complicated. Control is a strong word. It wasn't like I was running the show, you know? I wasn't picking out the perfect family based on their kitchen decor or anything.

But I did feel like I had a voice. Like, I wasn't just being *told* what was going to happen. Paul and Mark, my dad and stepmom, were really good about letting me be involved. They took me to the meetings with the adoption agency, and they listened to what I wanted.

I got to read the profiles of the potential adoptive parents, and I got to ask questions. I got to choose the family I felt most comfortable with. And that felt…empowering, I guess.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because that doesn't exist. It was about finding people who I thought would be good for the baby. People who would love him and take care of him.

So, did I have *total* control? No. But I had enough control to feel like I was making a decision that was right for me and for the baby. And that's what mattered. It wasn't just something happening *to* me. I was an active participant.

It was still scary, though. Giving up a baby is never going to be easy. But knowing that I had a say in who he went to made it a little bit easier. It made me feel like I was doing the best thing I could, even though it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. And honestly? It's one I think about a lot, even now.

If I could go back in time… it's not simple. It's not like flipping a switch. There are a million things that would be different. And maybe, if things were different, I would have made a different choice.

But knowing what I know now… knowing how happy Mark and Vanessa are, knowing how much they love the baby… I think I would.

It wasn't about *not* wanting the baby. It was about knowing I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being a mom. I had dreams, you know? I wanted to go to college, I wanted to write, I wanted to… just *be* me.

And Mark and Vanessa, they were ready. They were so excited. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't at that time. A stable, loving home.

It was the hardest decision I ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But seeing how happy everyone is… it makes me think I did the right thing.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a choice for everyone involved. And I think, ultimately, it was the most selfless thing I could have done.

So yeah. I think I would make the same decision. It doesn't mean it was easy. It just means I think it was the right thing to do.

Don't get me wrong, it's still complicated. But I'm okay with it. I'm learning to be okay with it. And that's all that matters, I guess.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept saying, "Oh, you're so selfless!" and I was like, "Yeah, well, try not crying into your pizza for a week."

It was weird. Like, I knew it was the right thing to do. I really did. Paul and Vanessa were amazing, and they were going to give the baby a life I just couldn't. But knowing that didn't make it *easy*.

I think the hardest part was the waiting. Waiting for the baby to be born, waiting for the adoption to be finalized, and then…waiting for it to feel okay. It felt like a huge hole in my life, even though I knew it was a hole that needed to be there.

I talked to my dad a lot. He's pretty good at just…listening. And not judging. He didn't try to fix things, he just let me be sad. And that helped. A lot.

Vanessa was really good too. She kept me updated, sent me pictures (which I cried over, obviously), and just…treated me like a person, not just a birth mom. That meant a lot.

I also threw myself into stuff. School, music, hanging out with Leah. Just trying to keep busy and not think about it all the time. Which didn't always work.

Honestly, it took a long time. It wasn't like one day I woke up and everything was fine. It was more like…slowly, gradually, the sadness started to feel less sharp. And I started to feel…peaceful.

I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what she's like, what her name is, what she's doing. But it's not a painful thing anymore. It's more like…a quiet hope.

I guess what I learned is that it's okay to grieve. It's okay to be sad. And it's okay to need help. It doesn't mean you made the wrong decision. It just means you're human.

And, you know, sometimes the hardest things are the things that make you grow up the most. And I definitely grew up a lot during that whole process. It sucked, but…it made me who I am.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's not like it was a *fight*, exactly, but there were definitely…moments.

Mark and Vanessa, they were great people, really. Super nice. But they had a very specific idea of what they wanted, and sometimes that clashed with what I wanted, or what I thought was best for the baby.

Like, they were really into organic everything. Organic clothes, organic food, organic toys. Which is fine, I guess, but it felt…intense. Like, the baby needed to be perfect, and everything had to be just so. And I was just trying to get through high school and eat a tater tot every now and then.

And there was the whole "name" thing. They had a list of names, and they were all…really preppy. Like, "Bartholomew" and "Penelope." And I was like, "Um, no. That's not happening." I wanted something a little more…normal. We eventually compromised on a name I could live with, but it took a while.

The biggest thing, though, was just the feeling of…giving up control. It was my baby, but I wasn't going to be raising it. And it was hard to let go of that, even though I knew it was the right thing to do. They wanted to be involved in everything, which was good, but it also felt like they were taking over.

Paul and Vanessa were really good about talking things through, though. And they listened to me. Eventually, we all found a way to work together and make sure the baby was going to have a good life. It just wasn't always easy. It was complicated. But that's life, right? It's rarely simple.



It's weird to even talk about it, honestly. It still feels…raw sometimes. But it was worth it. Knowing that the baby was going to be loved and cared for, that's all that really mattered.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big one. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It was complicated.

Look, Paul was a good guy. Really. Sweet, a little clueless, but genuinely wanted to do the right thing. But he wasn't ready to be a dad. Not even close. And honestly, I wasn't ready to be a mom, either. Not then.

It wasn't about him being a bad person. It was about what was best for the baby. And what was best for the baby was a stable, loving home with parents who were actually prepared to raise a kid. Mark and Vanessa were that. They were…ready.

It was my decision, ultimately. And it was hard. Really hard. I felt bad for Paul, and I knew it would hurt him. But I also knew that if he was involved, it would just make things messier and more complicated. It would drag things out and potentially mess up the adoption.

I didn't want the baby to be caught in the middle of our…whatever we were. It wasn't a relationship, really. It was just…a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake.

So, yeah, it felt kinda cold, I guess. But it was the most responsible thing to do. It was about putting the baby's needs first. And sometimes, that means making tough choices. Choices that hurt.

I still think about it sometimes. Wondering if I could have handled it differently. But I honestly believe it was the right decision. For everyone involved. Even Paul. Especially the baby.

It's just…it wasn't easy. And it's not something I'm particularly proud of. But it was what it was. And I had to live with it.

Ugh, okay, that's… a big question. It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

Honestly? It started with just being…realistic. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. Paul was…well, Paul was Paul. Sweet, but not exactly ready to be a dad. And my parents? They were supportive, but I knew they weren't equipped to help me raise a kid either.

It wasn't that I didn't want the baby. I did. But I wanted the baby to have a good life. A *stable* life. A life where they were wanted and loved and had everything they needed. And I just…didn't think I could give them that. Not then. Not ever, really.

It was Mark who kind of opened my eyes to adoption. He and Vanessa were looking for a baby, and they seemed…perfect. They were older, they had a house, they had a plan. They were genuinely excited about the idea of being parents.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. It still kinda stings, if I'm being honest. But I knew it was the right thing to do. For the baby. And for me.

It wasn't about giving up something I wanted. It was about choosing what was best for everyone involved. And sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is let go.

It's… complicated. It still is. But I don't regret it. I really don't. I just hope I made the right choice.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It was… complicated. And messy. And really, really hard.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I pretended I was fine. I made a lot of sarcastic jokes. I tried to just… move on. But it didn't work. It just kinda built up inside me, you know? Like a pressure cooker.

Paul was really good, actually. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how I *should* feel. He just… listened. And he let me be sad. And angry. And confused. Which was exactly what I needed.

Vanessa too. She was amazing. She understood, because she'd been through something similar. She didn't judge me, and she helped me see that giving the baby up wasn't a failure. It was a brave thing to do. A selfless thing.

It took a long time to process everything. There were a lot of tears. A lot of late nights. A lot of questioning whether I'd made the right decision. But eventually, I realized that I *had*. Mark and Vanessa were amazing people. They were going to give the baby a life I couldn't.

I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what she's like. What her name is. But it doesn't hurt as much anymore. It's more… bittersweet.

I think the biggest thing that helped me was accepting that it was okay to feel all the feelings. It was okay to be sad. It was okay to be scared. It was okay to be angry. And it was okay to be hopeful.

It wasn't easy. It's still not easy. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is also the right thing to do.

It's just… it's a part of my story now. And I'm okay with that.



It's not something I like to dwell on, but I wanted to be honest with you. It was a really tough time, but I got through it. And you can get through tough times too.

Ugh, okay. That's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a typical "getting to know you" situation, you know? It wasn't like I was picking out a new pair of shoes. It was my *baby*.

Mark and Vanessa…they were good people. Really good people. Like, ridiculously good. They were…perfect. And that was part of the problem, honestly. They had the house with the swing set and the golden retriever and the perfectly coordinated family photos. It was a little intimidating.

At first, I was super awkward. I mean, I was a teenager giving away my baby. It's not exactly a casual conversation starter. I kept trying to be cool and detached, like, "Yeah, this is fine, no big deal." But inside, I was a mess.

Vanessa was really good at making me feel comfortable. She didn't try to be my friend or anything, she just…listened. And she asked a lot of questions, not in a nosy way, but because she genuinely wanted to know me and understand what I was going through.

Mark was quieter. He was a little intimidating at first, but he was also really kind. He kept offering me snacks, which was weird, but also kind of sweet.

We had a lot of meetings. Talking about everything. What they wanted for the baby, what I wanted for the baby, how much contact we'd have after the adoption. It was hard. Really hard.

I was scared they'd judge me, or think I wasn't a good person. But they never did. They were just…supportive. They wanted to make sure I was okay.

Over time, I started to feel more comfortable around them. I realized they weren't trying to replace me, they were just trying to give my baby a good life. And that's all I wanted too.

It wasn't a traditional family, but it was a family. And it was a good one. I still see them sometimes. And it's…nice. It's still a little weird, but nice.

It's hard to explain. It was a really complicated relationship, but it was also a really important one. They gave my baby a home, and they gave me a little bit of peace of mind. And I'll always be grateful for that.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And yeah. It totally has. Like, duh. It's not something you just *get over*, you know? It's not like getting a bad haircut or failing a test. It's…life-altering.

Before all this happened, I was pretty…carefree. I was sarcastic, yeah, but mostly I was just trying to get through high school without being totally weird. I had my friends, my music, my plans for the future. And then…bam. Everything changed.

I had to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to start thinking about things I wasn't ready to think about. Responsibility, and what I wanted for this kid, and what kind of person I wanted to be. It was scary. And it still is, sometimes.

I think it's made me more…aware. Of other people, of the world, of how complicated things can be. I used to be pretty cynical, but now I see things in a different light. I see the good in people more easily, I guess. And I appreciate the people who have been there for me.

It's also made me realize what I *don't* want. I don't want to be someone who just drifts through life. I want to be someone who makes a difference, even if it's just a small one.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still just a teenager. But I'm not the same teenager I was before. I'm…stronger, I think. And more determined. And maybe a little bit wiser.

It's been hard, but it's also been…good. In a weird way. It's forced me to confront things about myself that I never would have otherwise. And it's made me realize that I'm capable of more than I thought.

So yeah. It's changed me. A lot. And I think, ultimately, it's changed me for the better. Even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Ugh. Okay, that was…rough. Seriously. It was like, overnight, everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life. And none of them were asking for one. It was the worst.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that's impossible when you're walking down the hallway at school and people are staring, or whispering behind their hands. Or when your mom's friend corners her at the grocery store to ask "How is she *coping*?"

Paul was really good about it, actually. He just wanted to disappear with me and build a cabin in the woods. Which, honestly, sounded pretty tempting. But I couldn't just hide.

What helped the most was…leaning into it, I guess. Not in a "look at me!" kind of way, but just…owning it. I stopped trying to be invisible. I started being more sarcastic and blunt with people who were being nosy. Like, if someone asked me a stupid question, I'd just give them a really deadpan stare and say, "What's it to ya?"

And Leah, my best friend, was amazing. She just told everyone to back off. She's a really good friend. She's scary when she needs to be.

It still sucked, though. It felt like everyone was judging me, like I'd done something wrong. But I realized that their opinions didn't matter. What mattered was me, and Paul, and the baby.

I also started focusing on things I could control. Like school, and my music, and making plans for the future. It helped me to feel like I wasn't just defined by being pregnant.

It didn't make the rumors go away completely, but it made them a little easier to deal with. And eventually, people just…got over it. Or at least, they stopped talking about it to my face.

It was a good lesson, though. People are always gonna talk. You just gotta learn to tune it out and focus on what's important. And sometimes, a little bit of sarcasm can go a long way.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not easy to talk about, honestly. It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I was a kid, having a kid. And that just…didn't feel right.

I wasn't ready. I wasn't financially stable. I wasn't emotionally ready. I was still in high school, trying to pass chemistry and avoid the popular girls. I had my own life to figure out, and I knew I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved if I kept it.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything. A stable home, loving parents who were prepared, a good education… things I just couldn't provide at that point in my life.

And honestly? It was scary. Really scary. The thought of being a mom, of being responsible for another person, was overwhelming. I just… I wasn't strong enough. Not yet.

Mark and Vanessa… they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They were the kind of people who would give the baby everything I couldn't. And knowing that she was going to a good home, that she was going to be loved and cared for… that made it a little bit easier.

It was the hardest decision I ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right one. For me, and for her. It wasn't giving up on her. It was giving her a better life. And that's what mattered.

It's… complicated. Okay? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's messy and sad and hopeful all at the same time. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. And a hard one. It wasn't, like, a monster under the bed kind of fear. It was…more complicated than that.

I think my biggest fear wasn't that the baby wouldn't be loved. Mark and Vanessa seemed really great, you know? It was that *I* wouldn't be able to do it. That I wouldn't be strong enough to actually…give the baby up.

Like, I knew it was the right thing to do. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. But still…the thought of actually handing over this little person, this tiny human I was growing inside me…it was terrifying.

I kept picturing myself just running away with the baby, and us living in a van down by the river or something. Which is ridiculous, obviously. I'm not exactly equipped for van life.

But it wasn't about wanting to *keep* the baby, exactly. It was about being a good person. About doing the right thing, even when it was the hardest thing. And I was scared I'd be too selfish, too weak, to follow through.

I was also scared that I'd regret it forever. That I'd spend the rest of my life wondering "what if?"

It was a lot. And I didn't really talk about it with anyone, because it felt…wrong. Like admitting I wasn't completely sure about something. But yeah. That was my biggest fear. Being a failure at being selfless. Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to explain.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get *all* the time. It's kinda embarrassing, honestly. It wasn't some deep, meaningful thing, okay? It was…impulsive. And a little bit silly.

Paul, he was…well, he was Paul. Kind of a blank slate. And I needed a name for the father in the ad, right? Something that didn't scream "teen mom" or "total disaster."

I was flipping through a magazine, and there was an ad for Bleeker Street Records in New York. And I just…liked the sound of it. It sounded kinda cool, kinda artsy. And it didn't immediately make me think of, like, a creepy old man.

So I just wrote it down. It was totally random. I didn't even know if it was a real name. Turns out, it's a street in New York. Go figure.

It's not like I was planning on naming the baby Bleeker or anything. It was just a placeholder name for the ad. But it stuck. And everyone kept asking me about it.

Honestly, it's a pretty dumb story. But that's the truth. I just needed a name, and Bleeker sounded good at the time. Don't overthink it. It's not a metaphor for anything. It's just a name.

And Paul? He didn't really care. He was just happy to be involved. Which, honestly, was kinda sweet.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole punk thing? It wasn't like a conscious decision, you know? It just…fit. Everything else felt so fake and polished and *trying* too hard. And punk was just…raw.

I think it started with just being annoyed. Annoyed with everything. Annoyed with people trying to tell me what to do, what to think, what to wear. Annoyed with the whole perfect-teenager image everyone was pushing. It felt suffocating.

And then I heard bands like The Distillers, Bikini Kill, Sleater-Kinney…and it was like, “Oh. People feel this way too.” It was angry and loud and honest. It didn’t try to be pretty. It didn’t try to be popular. It just *was*.

It wasn’t just the music, either. It was the whole culture. The DIY ethic, the anti-establishment attitude, the idea that you could create something yourself without needing anyone’s permission. That really resonated with me.

I liked that it was messy and imperfect. It wasn’t about being cool, it was about being real. And it was about questioning everything. Which, let’s be honest, I was already pretty good at.

Plus, the clothes were comfortable. And you didn’t have to worry about matching. Which, as someone who’s generally pretty low-maintenance, was a huge plus.

It just felt like a place where I could be myself, without having to apologize for it. It was a little bit of rebellion, a little bit of anger, and a whole lot of honesty. And honestly, that’s a pretty good combination.

So yeah, that’s what drew me to it. It wasn’t about the music, or the clothes, or the attitude. It was about finding a place where I felt like I belonged. Even if that place was a little bit loud and chaotic.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not something I usually talk about, honestly. But you asked.

It messed me up, okay? Seeing my parents just…not work. Like, they weren't *fighting* all the time, which is what I think people expect. It was more like they just…drifted apart. Like two ships passing in the night. And it made me super cynical about the whole relationship thing.

I think I built up a lot of walls. I didn't want to get too close to anyone, because I was afraid they'd just…leave. Or change. Or realize I wasn't worth sticking around for. It's stupid, I know. But that's how it felt.

And it definitely made me wary of commitment. Like, why bother getting serious with someone when it all just ends in disappointment anyway? That's probably why I was so…flaky with guys before Paul. I just didn't want to invest too much emotionally.

But then, you know, Paul happened. And he was different. He didn't try to fix me or change me. He just…accepted me for who I was. And that was really scary, but also really good.

It made me realize that just because my parents' relationship didn't work doesn't mean all relationships are doomed. It just means that you have to find someone who's willing to put in the effort, and who you're willing to put in the effort for.

It still affects me, though. I still have moments where I freak out and worry that things are going to fall apart. But I'm learning to trust Paul, and to trust myself.

It's a process, you know? It's not like you just get over something like that overnight. But I'm getting there. And I think, ultimately, it's made me a stronger person. Even if it's a really messy, complicated kind of strong.

So yeah. That's…that's how it impacted me. It's not a fun topic, but it's the truth.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all…reflective. It's kinda embarrassing. But alright, if you *have* to know.

I think what makes my story…different…isn't the pregnancy itself, honestly. Plenty of girls get pregnant. It's just…how I handled it. I didn't freak out and run away, or try to pretend it didn't happen. I just…figured it out.

I think a lot of people expected me to fall apart, to be all dramatic and sad. But I'm not really built for drama. I'm more of a sarcastic observer. So I just approached it like a problem to be solved.

And I didn't want to be a mom. Not then, anyway. I had plans. I wanted to go to college, and write, and just…figure out who I was. And I knew I couldn't do that with a baby.

So I chose adoption. And that wasn't easy. It meant admitting I couldn't do it all, and trusting someone else to give my baby a good life.

But I think what makes it special is that I didn't let anyone tell me what to do. My parents, Paulie, even Mark…they all had opinions. But I made my own decisions. And I owned them.

And I found some really amazing people along the way. Paulie and Vanessa, they were…unexpectedly awesome. They helped me see things in a different light.

So yeah, it's a messy story. It's complicated. But it's *my* story. And I think that's what makes it special. It's about a girl who figured things out on her own terms, and found her own way to be okay.

And maybe, just maybe, it helped someone else feel a little less alone. That would be pretty cool.

Ugh, I'm getting all mushy now. Let's talk about something else. Like, I don't know…music. Or tater tots. Anything but feelings.

Ugh, okay, good friends. That's…important. I've been thinking about this a lot lately, actually. It's not like I had a ton of experience with it before, you know? But I've learned a few things.

First of all, someone who doesn't judge. Like, seriously. Everyone's got stuff going on, and you need someone who's just gonna listen without, like, immediately jumping to conclusions or giving you a lecture.

And honesty. Not, like, brutally honest to the point of being mean, but someone who's gonna tell you the truth, even when it's hard. You need someone who's gonna call you out on your BS.

Humor is a big one. Someone who can make you laugh, even when you feel like crying. Life's too short to be serious all the time.

And someone who's just…there. You don't have to talk every day, or even every week. But knowing they've got your back, that they'll be there if you need them, that's huge.

Also, someone who doesn't try to fix everything. Sometimes you just need someone to sit with you in the mess, you know? Not try to solve all your problems.

And finally, someone who's okay with you being weird. Because let's be real, everyone's a little weird. And you need friends who embrace that.

Basically, someone who's real. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves, and who accepts you for who you are, flaws and all. That's a good friend. And they're hard to find. But when you find one, you gotta hold onto them.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like it's been all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's definitely shaken things up.

With my parents…it was rough at first. My dad just kinda shut down. He didn't say much, just looked…disappointed. Which, okay, fair enough. It wasn't exactly what he pictured for me. But it hurt. My mom, she tried to be supportive, but she was also kinda freaking out. Lots of "Are you sure?" and "What are you going to do?" It took a while for them to come around, to actually see that I was serious about this and that I could handle it. Now, they're…okay. They're helping, which is good. But it's still weird.

Paul…well, Paul's been amazing. Seriously. He could have totally bailed, and I wouldn't have blamed him. But he didn't. He's been there for me, even when I'm being a total mess. We're figuring things out, you know? It's not a traditional relationship, but it's…something.

Bleeker…he's just Bleeker. He's supportive in his own weird way. He keeps making me mix CDs, which is nice. He doesn't really *get* the whole pregnancy thing, but he's trying.

And Leah…she's been my rock. She's the only one who really understands what I'm going through. She's been there to listen, to cry with, to just…be there. I don't know what I'd do without her.

It's just…it's made me see people differently. Like, who's really there for you, and who's just saying what you want to hear. It's also made me realize that people are complicated. Everyone's got their own stuff going on.

It's been a test, you know? A test of friendships, of family, of everything. And it's not always been pretty. But it's made me stronger, I think. And it's made me appreciate the people who actually care about me.

So yeah, it's impacted my relationships. In a big way. But I'm trying to focus on the good stuff, on the people who are sticking around. And on the fact that I'm bringing a little person into the world, which is kinda amazing, even if it's also kinda terrifying.

Ugh, okay, deep questions. It's weird to think about my "worldview," because, like, I'm sixteen and still figuring things out. But I guess there are some things I've realized are pretty important to me.

First off, **honesty.** Not necessarily brutal honesty, but just…being real. With yourself and with other people. I hate when people try to be something they're not. It's exhausting.

Then there's **independence.** I'm not looking for someone to rescue me. I can take care of myself, and I want to be able to make my own decisions, even if they're the wrong ones. It's my life, you know?

**Kindness** is a big one. Even when people are being jerks. It doesn't mean you have to let them walk all over you, but just…trying to see things from their perspective. Everyone's fighting their own battles.

I also think it's important to **question things.** Don't just accept what people tell you. Think for yourself. Figure out what *you* believe.

And finally, **authenticity.** Being true to yourself, even if it's weird or unpopular. I've spent too much time trying to fit in, and it's just… draining. It's way easier to just be yourself, even if it means you're a little bit of a misfit.

I guess those are the things that matter to me. They're not, like, written in stone or anything. I'm still learning. But those are the values I'm trying to live by.

It's kinda cheesy to talk about values, I know. But whatever. It's who I am. And I'm okay with that.

Ugh, okay, the name thing. That was…a process. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment or anything. It took a lot of back and forth with Mark and Vanessa. They were really open to suggestions, which was good, because I had a lot of them. Mostly terrible ones.

I wanted something…not too frilly. Not too common. Something that felt real, you know? Like a person, not a princess. Mark was leaning towards more traditional names, like Emily or something. Vanessa was more into quirky, unique names. It was a battle.

We went through a *ton* of names. I even suggested "Neil" for a little while, just to mess with them. They did not appreciate that.

Eventually, Vanessa suggested "Darling." And at first, I was like, "Seriously? Darling? That's…a lot." But the more I thought about it, the more I liked it.

It's kind of ironic, right? Because I wasn't exactly feeling very "darling" at the time. I was a mess. But it felt like…a wish, I guess. A wish for her to be loved and cherished. And it's a little bit old-fashioned, which I liked. It felt…solid.

And Mark actually came around to it too. He said it reminded him of his grandmother. So it felt like a good compromise.

It's not a name I ever thought I'd pick, honestly. But it just…felt right. And that's what mattered. It's her name, and I hope she grows up to love it. And to know that even though things were kinda weird at the beginning, she was always wanted.



It's weird thinking about it now. She's a real person. With a real name. It's kinda scary and kinda amazing all at the same time.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was…a lot. And I learned a *lot*. Mostly stuff I wasn't expecting to learn.

First off, I learned I was way more capable than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I was a sarcastic, kinda cynical teenager, and suddenly I was growing a human being. It was terrifying, but I handled it. I made a really big decision, and I stuck with it. That taught me I could be strong, even when I didn't feel like it.

I also learned that the world isn't as black and white as I thought it was. Before, everything was kinda…easy. People were either cool or uncool, good or bad. But with the whole pregnancy and adoption thing, I met so many different kinds of people. Paul and Vanessa, who were just…amazing. They were so open-minded and kind. And even my dad, who I thought would totally freak out, was actually really supportive. It made me realize that people are complicated, and you can't just judge them based on first impressions.

I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who love you and support you, no matter what. Vanessa and Paul became my family, in a way. And even though I gave the baby up, I knew she was going to a loving home. That was the most important thing.

And honestly, I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I'm okay with being different. I don't need to fit in or be like everyone else. I'm just…me. And that's enough.

It was a really messy, complicated, and sometimes painful experience. But it made me who I am. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. It taught me about responsibility, about love, and about the importance of making your own choices. And that's a pretty good lesson to learn, I think.

It also taught me to appreciate a good peanut butter sandwich. Seriously. Pregnancy cravings are no joke.

Ugh. Okay, that's a heavy question. Looking back… yeah. There are things. It wasn't all sunshine and witty banter, you know?

I think… I would have let myself feel things more. I was so busy being sarcastic and trying to be tough, I kinda walled myself off. I mean, it was a defense mechanism, obviously. I was sixteen and pregnant. Not exactly a walk in the park. But I think if I'd let myself be vulnerable sooner, it would have been… easier.

I also would have maybe spent a little more time with Paul. Not like, *dating* dating, because that was weird. But just…getting to know him better. He was a good guy, and I kinda dismissed him at first because he was…well, he was Paul. But he really stepped up, and I didn't always show him how much I appreciated that.

And maybe I would have been nicer to my mom. We butted heads a lot, and I was pretty harsh with her. She was just trying to be a mom, and I was being a typical teenager. I get it now, though. She was scared for me.

But honestly? I don't know if I would change anything *major*. Because everything happened for a reason, right? And it made me who I am. It forced me to grow up, to think about things, to make tough decisions. And I wouldn't trade that for anything.

It was messy and complicated and sometimes really, really hard. But it was also…good. It taught me a lot about myself, about life, and about what really matters.

So yeah, maybe a few little things. But overall? I think I did okay. I made the best decisions I could with what I had at the time. And that's all anyone can do, right?

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. A *lot*. Honestly, it kinda comes with the territory of being alive, doesn't it? Especially when you're, like, actively trying to make big decisions and stuff.

Okay, so here's what I've figured out. It's not about *avoiding* disappointment, because that's impossible. It's about how you deal with it when it hits you in the face.

First, you gotta let yourself feel it. Don't try to pretend you're okay when you're not. It's okay to be sad, or angry, or just generally bummed out. Just don't wallow in it forever. Set a timer. Like, "Okay, I'm gonna be sad for an hour, then I'm gonna try to do something else."

Then, you gotta figure out *why* you're disappointed. Was it a realistic expectation? Or were you setting yourself up for failure? Sometimes, you just gotta admit you were wrong. It's not fun, but it's important.

And then, you gotta find something else to focus on. Something that makes you happy, or at least distracts you from the disappointment. Watch a movie, listen to music, hang out with friends, eat a really good sandwich… whatever works.

It's also helpful to remember that things rarely go exactly as planned. Life is messy and unpredictable. And sometimes, the things that seem like failures at the time turn out to be the best things that ever happened to you.

I learned that the hard way, obviously. But it's true.

So yeah, disappointment sucks. But you can get through it. Just breathe, feel your feelings, and remember that you're not alone. And maybe eat some ice cream. That always helps.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. That was…complicated. At the beginning, she was just…there. Paulie’s girlfriend. And honestly? I kinda judged her. She seemed so…perfect. All cheerleader-y and popular and into horses. Not exactly my vibe. I thought she was kinda shallow, to be real.

But then, things started happening, you know? With the pregnancy and everything. And she was the one who actually *stuck around*. Paulie was…well, Paulie was being Paulie. And my dad was trying, but he didn’t really *get* it.

Leah started coming over, just…hanging out. Helping me with homework, even though she was, like, a grade ahead. She didn’t push me or anything. She just…listened. And she didn’t treat me like I was some kind of freak.

It was slow, but she started to see past the whole “teen mom” thing and see me as a person. And I started to see past the cheerleader thing and see that she was actually really smart and funny and…kind.

The turning point, I think, was when we went to the music store and she just…got me. She understood why I liked The Moldy Peaches and why I didn’t want to be like everyone else. She didn’t try to change me.

By the end, she wasn’t just Paulie’s girlfriend anymore. She was my friend. A real friend. She helped me through everything, and she was the one who drove me to the hospital. She was the one who was there for me when I gave the baby up.

It wasn’t a super dramatic, best-friends-forever kind of thing. It was more…quiet. A slow build. But it was real. And I’m glad I had her. She was a good egg. Even if she did like horses.

Ugh. Okay, don't get me wrong, it wasn't exactly a picnic. Morning sickness was…not cute. And people constantly giving me unsolicited advice? The worst. But if I had to pick a favorite part…

It was probably the feeling of having someone *inside* me. Like, a little person, growing. It was weird, and kinda gross sometimes, but also…amazing. It was this secret little world, you know? Just me and the baby.

And the kicks. Oh my god, the kicks. That was the coolest. It felt like…a little flutter at first, then a proper kick. It was like, "Whoa, there's a tiny human in there, and it's letting me know it exists!" It was a really weirdly comforting feeling.

It made everything feel…real. Like, I wasn't just some teenager making a mistake. I was creating a life. And that was…a lot to process.

But yeah, the kicks. Definitely the kicks. That was the best part. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.
